reviewText:
I'd love to recommend this game I really would...
It has all the hallmarks of a great game, but there's just one snag and unfortunately that one snag is the size of a continent:

This game is far too glitchy to recommend (at this time).

It honestly feels like I'm playing a beta test and not even a late beta at times.

I don't think I've come across an area in the game that, at some point, doesn't glitch, be it the busted AI, the ships that change class when you upgrade them or the research that decides Nah
date: y'alright" when you've finished an area of research but to name a few examples..\n\nEDIT - Best glitch yet: I invaded a planet with my troops
recommended: when it came to the land battle for the planet I was put in charge of the defensive force whilst the AI attacked for control of the planet with my troops...\n\nAt some point I'll make a list for the developers and send it over
hoursPlayed:
but it's going to be a long list and it's going to be a while before I send it...

"Why am I moaning about things rather than helping fix them?" you may ask.

Simple. I paid for the game

reviewText:
I've played Masters of Orion 2 (One as well, but 2 a LOT more) it's, in my humble opinion, the best 4X game ever.

After that, I've played many, many more: Galactic Civ, Alpha Centauri (Rants about Civ ripoff) Sins of a Solar Empire, Endless Legend, etc, etc ,etc. None gave me such a new or enhanced experience as MOO2.

Then: Stardrive. WOHAAAA! Great! it's like MOO2, but with everything better: Cooler ship design, better tech thingies, more exploration, tactical combat, flavorful events. Terriffic!

The downside, and for me the number one reason to never play again (Please, make a patch, expansion, DLC, ANYTHING): there is only one way to win: total conquest. So after hours of playing I have to destroy my friends. No economic, diplomatic, cultural, 'who has the most bunnies' or anoher origional victory at all.

So I own 60% of the planets, the biggest fleet and most technical advancements (Ok, I was playing 'normal', sue me) and have to spend hours conquering planets. No fun at all.

One small thing when you're make a patch: Please give an end-of-turn warning when a planet is doing nothing or convert the excess labor in coins or anything. It's frustrating to discover after 5-6 turns you forgot to give one planet new construction orders.

When the victory thingie is solved, it will be a A+ recommendation from me!

With kind regards,

Sebastiaan.

reviewText: SD2 is a decent game but it doesn't really add anything to the 4x genre and feels restrictive due to the small maps ( 100 system maximum ).  This means that you will meet other races pretty quickly and all of a sudden are rushing production as the AI appears to be able to pull fleets out of it's hat at will.  This turns what should be a strategic game into a I can field more ships than you" slugfest.  The various ( we want to eat your granny ) type races ensure that diplomacy is no more than an afterthought and certainly not a means to an end as they will attack you anyway.\n\nI decided not to recommend this game as there are better 4x titles out there.  For those that want strategic depth without worrying too much about graphics there is distant worlds.  For those that want the 3D combat coupled with decent strategy there is Sots or Sots 2.  For those that want an RTS feel there is Sins of a Solar Empire or Star ruler 2 and for those that want a more traditional 4x then Galciv 3 is just around the corner.  SD2 tries hard but it doesn't excell at anything and in what is becoming an ever more packed marketplace it is doomed to fall by the wayside.  That is not to say that it can never rise to the top.  With more development
recommended: much better diplomatic systems and better strategy overall it could be a winner.  At the moment though
hoursPlayed:
close but no cigar.

With Sector Zero DLC:
I didn't think it possible that this game could be any less desirable than it is already but I was wrong.  Sector Zero takes what was already there ( and flawed ) and adds a liberal dose of absolute boredom while not repairing or addressing any of the previous ♥♥♥♥ed up systems.  Diplomacy is still ♥♥♥♥
voteText: The Ai can still create fleets out of nothing etc. etc.  To the developer I can simply say:\n\nYou obviously have talent.  You obviously have some good ideas and a fertile imagination but ffs bring a few more people in so that you can bounce some of those ideas off them and gain different perspectives.  Maybe then you will end up with a product worth playing instead of this pile od detritus."

reviewText:
This game shows a lot of promise but its certainly not finished, theres no way to ally with other races simply peace, its severly flawed with many bugs practically breaking your game.

Once i had a planet switch races, one turn it was mine the next with no battle no war and no warning one of my worlds simply joined a different faction, I regulary in ground battles find myself controlling the other side, or unable to move troops with no reason why, i played the game on normal and got through to the end it was challenging but i won, i thought id play another game on easy quickly and found it harder to play than normal. Races defined as evil will simply ask for anything and if you decline at any point war will follow within a few turns, occassionally war will follow the next turn regardless of how much they like you.

this game needs a lot of work to be playable and then a lot added to it to be enjoyable, true ship customization is good but finding out which tech to get to get the right things for your ship is difficult,

Overall wait a long time and dont spend anywhere near £20 for it, i wish i could return it

reviewText:
The basic format for this game is superb.  I can see it becoming very adictive.  The management and expansion of colonies is interesting without being complicated, and the ship designing is enjoyable, if time-consuming.

HOWEVER, this game is NOT ready for release, and definitely not at this price.  It has extremely frustrating bugs that need to be worked out.  For example (and this is only one of many), there are sections where you have no choice but to forfeit a battle, even if you are winning, because an immovable message panel obscures the part of the screen that you need to see.

I am going to set it aside until I see a patch available to make it more functional.

reviewText:
I made a race of photosynthetic treehugging cybernetic (trans)humans, killed space eels, found an eerie asteroid, experimented on my own citizens to create a zombie plague from said asteroid, lost Earth to a space wolves sneak attack through a wormhole while my main fleet was capturing my robotic enemy's homeworld. Then I turned the space wolves core systems into a zombie infested plague quarantine zone and retook Earth with space eel-cannon-armed-battleships produced by my new robot servants. After that the samurai space bears started a border war with me and things got interesting.

10/10 would terrorize the galaxy again with zombie plague fleet mounting space-eel-cannons.


Seriously though, this is a good game. Great? No. Good? Yes. Bugs? Yes, but they are consistently being stomped and progress is happening quickly.
A little bit about me, I have played probably every major space 4X game made. MoO1-3, Space Empires 2-5, Galactic Civilizations 1-2, Sword of the Stars 1-2, Sins of a Solar Empire, Imperium Galactica 2, Endless Space, Distant Worlds, and many many more. I also was a Beta Tester for a couple of the Distant Worlds expansions and you can see my name in the credits. So you could say that I have been around the space 4X block, and I really enjoy this game, warts and all. Let me break it down a little. Keep in mind the next few things throughout my review:

A - this game is made by one developer (goes by the handle Zero")

reviewText:
Star Drive 2 takes allot of what made the original star drive fun. Improves on it, then changes the game into more of  a traditional 4X experience, with turn based game play.

The Good:
Ship design - This is very deep with a level of subtlety and customization which no other game seems to have, at least in terms of whats on your ships and how they behave in combat.

Personallity - The races all have distinct ship models and very distinct personallities. There is a bit of cheesy humour in the game and allot of pop culture referencing which is worth a laugh. *spoiler* I got to weld guns to a t-rex's head and then use it to eat people!!!*

AI - After about 8 hours I have come to appreciate the difficulty of the AI, they wait till your fleets are out of position and attack core worlds, will try and undermine you diplomatically and have varied personallities ranging from homicidal to just the nicest little plant people ever. They also seem to adapt to your ship building strategies and it seems very difficult to cheese the AI in this game.

Empire Management - This is HARD and requires allot of thought. Managing some worlds to be food producing worlds and others to be ship producers or science worlds is an interesting balance and sometimes having more population on your homeworld is not the best choice. This means that a variety of adaptive stratagies are required, absed on your surroundings. This adds allot of replayabillity as games can vary wildly.

Fleet Combat - very pretty, plenty of strategy and a bit of point and click. Not one of those games where i want to autoresolve every battle.

The Bad

Ground combat - Can still be fun but is not quite up to the standard or polish that the rest of the game seems to have. There is however a suprising degree of strategy in what looks at first to be a very simple minigame. Especially when you take the variability of some of the races into account. I freaked out when i realized the squid men could squirt ink into peoples eyes......

Some balance on certain weapons - Overall ship modules are well balanced with few weapons ever truly becoming obsolete which is AWESOME. However there are some modules (Im looking at you plasma cannons) which could really use a buff.

The Ugly:

Haters - There are ALLOT of haters after some of the issues with SD1. Personally I can see where they are coming from but i easily got my 30 bucks worth outa the game. BUT i swear i am sick to death of the illiterate streams of untruthfull vitriol that get posted about this series. This is the onlly reason i wrote this review. I am a busy person, but i got so sick of all the polarized BS i felt i had to write something.

To Sum-up: Stardrive 2 is a difficult game with a steep learining curve that has deep and rewarding systems. Its not for the feebleminded. Some of the production values in certain areas of the game are a little low but otherwise it feels like a AAA game. I would heartily reccomend this game to any lover of 4x or grand strategy games and to anyone as obsessive as i am about building the deadliest ship ever.

reviewText:
Unfortunately, the enemy AI is set to psychotic. I find that trade and relations have very little meaning in this game. The entire Diplomacy/Relations system should be either scrapped, and any illusions of species having traits/personalitys discarded, or have it completely overhauled.

As is, a faction that is 'warm with you', has trade agreements with you, and shows every indiciation of having great relations with you (on top of having research done that improves your relations) will all of a sudden decide to demand you give them a planet......

Just the other day, I was thinking about how we requested from our good friends and neighbor in Canada to cede vast swaths of their most productive territory, because we are such good friends with a long history of trade.......Wait, that didn't happen.

reviewText:
When I bought this game I was initially very impressed because of some superficial resemblances in the research tree to the classic Master of Orion 2 and thought the developer was inspired by and trying to make a worthy successor to that game.
Now my view on the developer's intent is somewhat more cynical.

After playing the game for a while it seemd to me that much of the research tree is not well thought out and balanced but just thrown together willy-nilly with a superficial resemblance to the original MOO2.
Much of Stardrive2 strikes me this way: hastily thrown together design decisions, numbers arbitrarily plucked out of thin air and various pieces of code cobbled together with little thought of balance and overall design.

Much about the game design is astonishingly poorly thought out, such as the massive imbalance of ship design layouts between races and the huge investment in time and preparation to perform even simple espionage missions(I could conquer the entire civilization militarily in less time) as well as the incredibly overpowered Mass Driver weapon.
And let's not mention the horribly repetitive and childish ground combat.

I have put a lot of hours into this game; aspects of it are quite fun for a while.
I stuck with it as I was finding ship design interesting, even as I was hoping that the developer would address some of the game's many design flaws. However, it became apparent that the developer had little interest in doing any more than fixing some of the glaring bugs and has more or less abandoned the game's development.
Much leaves me wondering if the author ever actually sat down and played the game.

Uninstalled.

reviewText:
Edit: The game has improved considerably since the review that follows.  I still don't recommened it but not nearly so definitely.
-----------------------------------------------------

Pros:
1) Pretty RT space battles
2) Very much a MOO2 feel for the nostalgic old farts like me
3) Turn based empire management
4) More relatable and presentable alien races than one usually sees
5) The UI is solid, except for missing production
6) Graphics are sleek
7) Runs well, no glitches I could see

Cons:
1) Diplomacy is broken by the usual fickleness of 4X games. This exacerbates
2) The pain when large and powerful fleet of enemy ships (who were all confetti and chocolates a few turns ago) that rock up once your economy is almost functional to smash you to bits, which is particularly onerous when you are playing on
3) Easy mode.  Not.  Nope.
4) Ugly and moderately difficult ground battle in an ultra-simplified Xcom style
5) Most of all though falling for this twice.  Twice.  It's one thing to make a bad choice.  We all do that from time to time. It's another to chew on the fishhook a second time.  I was that stupid fishy.
6) I researched an issue with my planet in a tidal lock.  It killed the planet.
7) The sounds are a bit sparse and the GNN (news that pops up) is a shock in comparison to regular gameplay
8) The AI can reach me at the other side of the galaxy when I can't even reach the next cluster properly.

The game is fun at first.  As those first few turns burn away while presumably the AI builds those battleships you have a sense this game might be a good one, or at least ok.  But no.

I don't actually care if the AI cheats or not.  I don't care if my gameplay skills are sucky or brilliant.  I care that it simply isn't fun and that's the core of the not recommend for me.
voteText: 191 of 267 people (72%) found this review helpful 18 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I have played a lot of 4x games(Master of Orion, Master of Orion 2, Ascendency, Master of Magic, Fantasy Empires, The Civilization Games, Heroes of Might and Magic 1-5, Galactic Civilizations, Imperium Galactica II, and probably a bunch more that I don't remember right now), and the reviews for this one seem a bit more enthusiastic rather than accurate.

It borrows heavily from other games but to the point where it feels derivative of them rather than being a synthesis of them.  Moreover it is so blatant about it that it feels like it is flirting with the breaking the fourth wall not something I am a huge fan of.

The game has a lot of potential in the ship design and strategic aspect of space and ground combat and the level of depth that it allows you to manipulate your empire.

I will say that it was better than MOO III in general fun and striking a balance between allowing depth and getting carried away with it.

My big gripes about the game are as follows.

Technological advance doesn't yield significant upgrades until you get very very far along in the trees.  I almost always had better luck researching a few basic (tier one or two technologies), the pumping everything into producion ships and troops and conquering the galaxy without ever doing more than cursory reasearch.

The AI literally cheats on basic settings, I have tested rich homeworlds on small maps with optimized industrial output and the AI will invariably massively outcolonize me and outproduce me (in terms of fleet and fleet size) very quickly in the early game.  You can still win by being clever or cheesy in your builds, but the fact that it literally plays by a different set of rules on default settings really really bothers me.

The technologies are poorly balanced to create a stable empire.  The game forces you specialize each of your planets because of prohibitive maintanence costs (making one planet that has all upgrades and buildings your empire is capable of will put a big dent in your wallet).  Basically I find myself skipping almost all of my unlocked buildings on most colonies just because of what it costs to maintain them.  The way various technolgies interact and overlap with each other just makes a lot of them feel useless or redundant or only of use on a very small proportion of your colonies.

I do think the game has a whole lot of potential and with some patches or balance changes could be more fun.  Essentially my complaint it that it forces you to play in one of a few very specific ways if you want to avoid getting wiping out quickly on default difficulty.  It felt more like how well can I implement this strategy which I know will be the only viable one for this map/race selection rather than what type of empire would I like to build this time. It feels like the game has mechanics for amazing strategies and fun but makes it impossible for you to implement them before you have already taken control of the map.

Bottom Line I just didn't have fun playing it.

reviewText:
Updated to consolidate thoughts after all the time played so far

If you are interested in a military 4X game with a heavy focus on extermination then Stardrive 2 is recommended.  However, if you want to play a more peaceful or diplomatic game then I would not recommend it as it’s really not possible to play that way at the moment.

The Good
There are various early game opponents and some events with nods to sci-fi fans.

The AI is strong early game and I had to reload during my first game a few times to improve my strategy before winning on Normal difficulty.

The technology tree really does feel like Master of Orion 2 and I enjoyed mulling over the options.

The Battle Arena has been good fun to test designs and weapons and the combat is generally a highlight.

I've encountered no major bugs and while there were some minor bugs, there was nothing gamebreaking.

In some ways it is an improved game over Stardrive 1 but there is plenty of room for improvement.

The Bad
The technologies and weapons need to be better balanced.  Once you've tested them in the Battle Arena it becomes apparent some are worthless.

The late game is really tedious.  Colony governors are needed particularly for the mid to late game as it becomes micro intensive.  There are no defaults for troop loadouts so you have to do every one manually.  Late game AI ship designs are very weak so the battles become trivial and nowhere near as much fun as the early game.

The ground combat is weak.  Automatic resolution comes at a high price as it leads to excessive losses compared to manual combat even when you have a massive advantage, so it essentially forces the lame ground combat or bombardment to avoid it.

The AI’s are far too aggressive in responding to expansion.  The AI's are very similar and it's difficult to avoid anything other than Total War.  The tolerance mechanic used in diplomacy is good but needs to be increased as currently diplomacy is a bit of a side show.

Brutal difficulty is not hard enough once you get familiar.  In fact once you learn the mechanics this is the easiest 4X game I can remember.

The Lowdown
I had a lot of fun with the early game and Battle Arena.  As a result of the time I've played the game, I'll stick with a recommend, but without more serious improvements I don't see myself wanting to load the game up again (and I tend to play genuinely good 4X games much longer than this).

reviewText:
This game's problem is...it 'tries too hard to be MOO2 without understanding what made MOO2 fun and balanced'. Having played through and done some reading I will point out some glaring flaws.

AI is hyper-aggressive stupid expansionist. It will gobble up as much as it can as fast as it can and use that to produce as many junk ships as it can to throw at you the instant it detects weakness. That's ALL it will do - the ships it uses are pre-designed and total junk. It makes no attempt at clever diplomacy or alliances. It doesn't use starbases. No hiding in the trees to do a devastating flank attack here - no sir it will conga line straight into your wall-o-doom in the puddle size combat arenas.

Constant escalating attacks by 'NPC factions' - remnants and pirates and space crystals that don't attack the AI, so you have to dedicate a fleet to defending against them while the AI out-expands you then sends a fleet of doom at you.

Diplomacy is a joke. Half the races Want To Eat Your Granny and will declare war right away if they have more ships. Every other species is going to demand/threaten right off the bat, sometimes your homeworld, and if you don't give it to them they'll declare war if they have more ships. If you do they'll declare war anyway a few turns later if they have more ships. More ships >>> diplomacy.

Balance is...nonexistant. Tech 0 lasers and tech 2 mass drivers are all you ever need, maybe gauss later. They aren't the best weapons in the game because you can use them to flank or do ninja flips and death from above the command center, they are the best weapons in the game because their stats are better than anything else you can research. Some traits are grossly overpowered - subterranean + more money per pop. The optiris have ships that are TWICE as large for the same CP cost as the vulfar.

Ground invasions are 3rd wheel. What is a stripped down Xcom doing in my 4x? Ugly, simple, beyond mindless, pointless, click-fests that can be avoided at no cost by having one ship filled with nukes. Seriously, you'll need a ship with nukes and one trooper per fleet and that third of the game can be safely ignored.

The bugs! Oh God the bugs! And I don't mean the hivers. Ranging from game-breaking (autoresolve with many losses) to devastating (can not scroll systems in leader-assign screen) to merely annoying (deployment area does not auto-size for fleet).

Do Not Buy. Will update in 6 months if they fix stuff, it's gonna need at least that long. Unless the dev abandons it like he did his first game.

As I played this game, all I could think was that I would rather be playing SD1.

The game looks pretty, I can have an open mind when changing to a turn based campaign, but found that SD2 was lacking in alot of details ,and had something of an identity crisis.

The camera is stuck, you cant rotate or see any planets and even zooming is quite limited in choices; far away or in your face, cant have anything in between. Diplomacy is sadly 1 dimensional and boring, lots of options, but few applications.
The AI is a mess. I tried about 10 attempts now as humans and got completely steamrolled by massive fleets or rampant monsters in more than 6 of those attempts, in under 100 turns. This is on easy..You wont have a nice relaxing get to know you" experience here

reviewText: I want to love this game but it won't let me.  Numerous bugs, bad UI, rare crashes, half baked ground combat.  This game is unfit to be called a finished product.  A good beta maybe.  Needs polish, lots of polish.\n\nYou can tell that love went into this but it did not come with an equal measure of design skill.  Fleets will frequently overshoot their targets without engaging/parking.  Ground battles will sometime bug out, switching control of you and the AI's forces.  Real time space battles are unforgivably disorganized and nearly impossible to command in any meaningful way without 10+ minutes of pre battle formation micro management that you have to do every-single-battle.  Save your formation?  Nope, F U.  Simply clicking on a ship and telling it to fly here" is absurdly difficult when large fleets are present.  Planetary production Governors?  Nope.  All micro.  Insta scroll game text with a click?  Nope.  Get used to watching the letters crawl across the screen like a legless orphan eating crayons.  Enemy transports will bug out in/near wormholes

reviewText:
OverviewIt's fun for a bit, but after awhile it gets repeatitive and it's errors come to surface. Not saying it's a terrible game, but it's not in the top 5 list.PROsDecent graphics on the galactic map and ship tactical combat.
Ship design is fun to play with.
Good enjoyment for the most part, for awhile...CONsAI is not balanced and isn't very intelligent. They basically get to cheat.
Economy isn't tweaked one can say it's bugged. Example: You can have eight farmers, but if you remove five farmers the three remaining farmers will produce more then the eight.
Ground combat isn't to entertaining. Limited weapons and useless upgrades that'll never be used. No strategy required. Late game you'll start hitting your head on your desk because of the ground combat. YES there's an AUTO option, but with all other aspects the AI is terrible and you'll find yourself loosing half your troops.
Ground combat AGAIN. I don't know what causes this but theres been a few times where I'm defending a planet and the game switches my units with the attackers units (ie. I have control over the invasion force and the AI has control over MY defenders).
Large fleet battles (70+ CP) becomes all but unplayable due to framerate drop. Even when I drop the graphics to the lowest setting this happends. I do have a decent rig (AMD 6-Core, 2GB GeForece GTX 760, 16GB Ram, running on SSD). This is simply bad and unoptimized coding plain and simple.My Rating
AreaScoreGraphics5 Some areas are done well, others seem to have gotten the short stick.Gameplay6 It's fun at the start, but it soon becomes repitive.Immersion5 You really get into it at the start. Towards the middle and end it's errors and repitiveness shows.Value3 Numerous bugs, Bad AI and generally un-balanced and un-optimized.OVERALL4.75ClosingI would love to recommend this game, I really would. But with the numerous bugs, bad AI, un-balanced, bad/un-optimized coding, and what I would consider a product that's not fully completed... I just cannot recommend this game. Yes it's fun, but it soon becomes a chore and that's not what a game is supposed to be.Wait until it's patched up and completed further before buying this game, or when it's on sale.

reviewText:
Honestly this game is far from the game I thought it would be, and quite honestly is one of the most disappointing games I have ever bought.

When I got hooked on the original StarDrive, I couldn't help but be amazed at the scale and customization options the game offered. Sadly, the game had been abandoned, but with the help of some very awesome people who made some very awesome mods, I was able to enjoy the game to whole new level than before.
I was extremely excited when I opened up the store one day and found out that it was the launch day for StarDrive 2. I'll admit I wasn't following it much, so I was surprised. There came the first problem though. After StarDrive one had been abandoned, many of us who had bought the game expecting big things were not only disappointed, but also felt a little betrayed. With StarDrive 2 out, I thought we would get a pretty sizable discount on it... we did, but only a third of the price. For how much we had paid for the original, not only was this disappointing, but perhaps in the back of my mind I knew this was one of the many problems to come.
Read some other reviews and you will quickly realize how many things are wrong with this game. From performance issues, to really lame options regarding diplomacy. Balancing issues regarding hull sizes from faction to faction is the thing I hate the most. Even customization has taking a turn for the worse compared to the original. In fact, the original I would say is far superior to this one.
I'm not a person that holds a grudge, or even forms one often, but I cannot even start to tell you how bad of a job the developer (Zero) is doing. All I read from him is how terrible the community is." He fixes issues that the minority only cares about
date: and never listens to real problems. He denies that he "abandoned" the original game
recommended: even though the main problems are easily fixed by a few mods.\nI gave him a second chance after abandoning StarDrive 1

reviewText:
I regret buying this.  I loved the first game.  It was so close to being perfect, but it had some very game breaking problems that I feel could have and should have been fixed.  Instead Zero left it broken and made this.

This is quite obviously unfinished.  Lack of balance, basic UI bugs, crazy strong AI that loves to kill you a little too much and seems like it's cheating.  At the very least, I'd wait a month or two for some patches.

Beyond the lack of polish, I feel, lies a game that is just inferior to the first.  The turn-based systems lack the amount of control that the real-time systems did.  For example, you can't reinforce your ships during combat, or position your forces around an enemy before attacking, or make any kind of hit and run moves.  Just seems like it loses a lot and gains little, which I think sums everything up perfectly.  Can't say i recommend it, and I wish I hadn't supported them.

column27: XCOM. Luckily there is an auto-resolve option that lets you skip this part of the game.\n\nTalking about combat: space combat is of course still a big part of StarDrive 2
column28:
but you have to micromanage a lot more than in StarDrive 1 since there does not seem to any sort of "attack-move". Without input your ships will just sit at their spawn location. You have to manually assign targets because your ships won't automatically pick their own target (you can defince a "typical behaviour" in the ship editor but that only seems to affect the way the enemy AI is utilizing the ships).


TL;DR:
StarDrive 2 goes from RTS to turn-based. Fleet sizes seem to be severly limited due to a command point limit. Space combat is still in real time but you have to micromanage and babysit your ships a lot (which some people probably find appealing). A lot of the ingame art
column29: ships and weapons have been lifted from StarDrive 1
column30: and while the introduction of turn-based
column31: XCOM-esque ground combat might set the game apart from other 4X games
column32: I found it very tedious.\n\nOn the plus side
column33: the ship editor has been improved greatly and the game seems to be more stable (at least for me) than StarDrive 1.\n\nAgain
column34: I would give the game an average score if I could (but for now Steam is lacking this option). Overall I was hoping for a continuation of StarDrive 1 (think different hulls & weapons
column36: but what I got was basically "StarDrive 1 - the turn based edition"."

reviewText:
Star Drive 2 looks like it would be a really good game.  Strong Master of Orion 2 resemblance and all.

Unfortunatelly the developper believes that his customers are paying beta testers.  He realeases a game so buggy that it's almost unplayable.  Every aspect of the game from ground combat, planet capture, diplomacy, tech, UI, game balance  is buggy and/or flawed.

To make matter worse, instead of working on fixes for those bugs, the dev is working on expansions for the game.  Dev never fixed the problem in Star Drive 1.  Seems like he decided to do the same in SD2.

Just buy something else, this is a waste of money.

reviewText:
So many good points, but let down by the finer details which ruin the game.

TLDR - wait for the Moo remake due later on, you will end up frustrated by this game.

I don't expect the AI to be as good as me, but if I select auto resolve I expect the AI to do a reasonalble job, example: I had 6 cruisers, the best I had, auto resolve and I lost all ships and took down 0 of theirs, reloaded the turn before and took control myself and I utterly stomped them, I did not even lose sheilds on 1 ship never mind lose 6, before people think I employed advanced tactics, I had rail guns, I did nothing, I issued no commands, default deployment and watched only and won hands down, WTF did the AI do to lose that? I can only assume it turned off all the guns and sat there and died slowly as there is no other method.

The AI is scewed against the player, all random events attack them and not the other AI, in Moo2 for example the anteries attacked the strongest player, in this one they just attack the player, regardless of how well they are doing.

The AI in general for other empires is heavily flawed, it boils down to, regardless of how powerfull you are: give us tribute or we will declare war to the point of our own death, even if you have 20 planets and a huge fleet, they have 1 ship and 1 planet they will still give diplomacy options as if roles were reversed.

Many basic options of that of a 4x are missing.

ground combat is a joke, I would have avoided it totally but if you don't then the same as space combat, you can win it with 0 losses, let the AI 'auto resolve' and you lose all your troops, shocking really.

terrible UI whereas selecting planets and fleets can be a total nightmare, trying to click a fleet and taken to the planet menu is something you will be used to after playing a short time.

As said soo many good things, the ship design is epic and great to play with, but the small botched ideas ruins the whole thing.

Stay away, save your cash for a sale and get it for alot cheaper.
voteText: 37 of 45 people (82%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: I would like to start off saying I would have loved to love this game. I liked the original Stardrive, even though the developer left it unfinished and buggy,  only using the titles mangled corpse as a springboard for the sequel, Stardrive 2, leaving many of the games backers with nothing but an unfinished game and buyers remose. While the game is fun in it's current semingly incomplete state, it requires a beefy computer to even finish a campaign due to the massive fleet size. The game's AI is overly warlike and game itself is entirely riddled with bugs. All of this aside, what really pushes this review into the negative is the utter dissapointment I have for the developer after so many people gave them a second chance with Stardrive 2 after the failure and abandonment of Stardrive. Stardrive 2 is in a buggy and what feels like downright incomplete state. Instead of fixing the problems in the games, or adding better and more exciting content the developer has chosen to lock away these things behind a DLC paywall for the game, forcing any loyal fans to purchase the game a second time, or even third time if you wish to count the original Stardrive, to even continue receiving updates to it. This is very saddening as I had hoped the abandonment of the original Stardrive would be the last of the poor consumerism choises made by the developer of the Stardrive series, I am clearly mistaken.
voteText: 49 of 66 people (74%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I spent a lot of time playing the original Stardrive and I loved it. Although a few hours in it's very obvious that it's not a finished game. I had oversight with that because of two facts, the game is simply great from a 4x point of view (though somewhat lacking in the diplomacy departmeant), and it was developed by one guy. Stardrive 1 captured my interest with a non-turn based system, it's wonderful shipdesigner where you can put modules pretty much anywhere in your ships making them, essentially, your design. The tech tree was wonderful and the empire managemeant was comprehensive.

Stardrive 2 threw out the ship designer, the non-turn based system, the meat and potatoes of the game in my opinion. In place they put in a turn based system and a dumbed down version of the ship designer. The diplomacy has been improved but at a fatal cost, at least to me. The ground combat is somehow worse than the first game and the battles now take place in a seperate scenario where when you encounter enemy fleets load into a combat screen where you duke things out in real time. This eliminates the dynamic open world combat with on the spot micro, retreating somewhat easily, reinforcing with ships on the way or being built mid fight. It results in a game which boils down to biggest highest tech fleet wins the game. I bought StarDrive 2 hoping it would beat the odds again only to be met with a turnbased, dumbed down StarDrive 1.

Now when I want to play a 4x space empire game, I play StarDrive 1, because to me, it's simply better.

reviewText:
Let me just say I do not like to giva bad ratings, ever, but I have to here.

This game is hopefully getting patched along the way, but my initial and honest opinion is that the game feels 89 percent finished.

When engaging ground attacks, you can fire through the walls, and you can be trapped in a never-ending turn going (it was my own fault for placing shields to block myself in. The shield will never dissappear untill destroyed -by enemies only.)
The space battle ui is hard to use, as you mostly cannot enable the specials of the ships in a group -you have to select each ship one-by-one, and enable. Also, the game at simple gfx setting is hakking, and also a bit lagging when going on a large scale battle, I think I counted 16vs20 ships.

I might be doing something wrong, and have no experience with the game, but as a former MOO fan, I wanted to try out this game.

The game is fun, ofc, but it simply doesn't feel worthy the high pricetag.
If on a large sale, sure.

I am sorry for not recommending the game, but it is too much of a price for a game which seems unpolished, indie or not.

reviewText:
Unfinished, unpolished, unoptimized and unbalanced. After 40 hours or so of playing that is my conclusion. Now let me explain some of the reasons why I honestly cannot recommend StarDrive 2 at this moment (version 1.1).

When building something with the construction ships (Listening posts, subspace projectors or fueling stations) they CANNOT be destroyed. I mean not even by you.
You will notice how irritating this is when you accidentally click the construct icon when the ship is on top of your planet. If you try building space highways" with the projectors you can goof it up so bad that your ships can get stuck in an eternal loop when it's trying to reach it's destination. Basically what happens the projector accelerates your fleet to high speed
date: it shoots past it's target (for example a planet)
recommended: turns around and repeats. Yes I have had this happen
hoursPlayed:
more than once. Also path finding IGNORES subspace projectors completely so basically they're completely useless and a broken concept.
Ship modules and their descriptions (What they actually do and what other modules they affect) are vague to the point that I had to dig through the game files to find out what weapons were point defense weapons (prioritize incoming ordnance over enemy ships).
No auto build option for colonies (After you reach a certain point of colonies this becomes TEDIOUS).
Unique leaders where some can engage in space and/or ground combat. Sadly for space combat their ships become outdated really quick and no way to update/upgrade them. Not even the modules in them like armor.
Ground combat is a joke. It's a huge chess board with absolutely NO tactics involved. There are some weapons
voteText: some protective items and some utility items. You can select 3 of them for your ground unit. Guess can you create a "default" item set for new ground troops? Nope. The whole ground combat part seems more like an afterthought to try and get more sales.\nAI is

heavy armor at the front but no weapons. What does the AI do with that ship. It retreats right after the start of a space battle. And when there can be over 10 of those ships in the enemy fleet... well just picture a facepalm and you I'm sure you get my meaning. This is yet another glaring show how little the developer actually puts effort in the game.
Space battles eventually turn into lagfests. Picture the enemy might have 30-50 corvettes or frigates. Each of those ships can have several rockets/missile launchers firing a rocket/missile every few seconds. Now please answer the question below.
Does the above mentioned rocket/missile spam lag the *BEEP* out of the battle no matter what hardware you're running?
[ ] YES
[ ] NO

Good you answered correctly.
It does not matter what your computer specs are. In the end battles will become slideshows and turns start to take more and more time. If you think Civilization V end game turns took long
commentsCount:
compare them to this and re-evaluate. That is if you want to waste your money on this game.

What I mentioned are just some of the things that came into my mind while writing this review. It's not a complete list and hardly even a partial list of what's wrong with StarDrive 2. I have played StarDrive 1 and I liked it. I really wanted to like StarDrive 2 but the more I play it the more annoyed I get with the multitude of irritating things in the game.

There are a lot of problems in the game currently and I do not believe that the developer can

reviewText: After a few hours of play through I have to say that the game has a ton of potential. That potential, at least without the expansion (which I haven't purchased) is not realized. If you are a fan of Master's of Orion 2 you'll feel right at home. The graphics are obviously better and the combat has been reworked, but otherwise the races have been borrowed from heavily and the technology tree is nearly copied in its entirety. All of this wouldn't be an issue were it not for the staggering amount of bugs that are still present in the game. I've not managed to get even a single play through to last more than an hour or two without running into a bug that causes the game to lock up. These are issues that are being caused by normal game play and I, like other reviewers, am amazed that they never game up in beta testing. In fact, they make the whole game feel like it is an early release as opposed to a fully completed product. Hopefully they will continue to work on fixing the bugs, but until then I wouldn't pick the game up unless it's massively on sale.

reviewText:
The game is fun, if you havent played original Star Drive, you can try and have fun with this - most customisable interior of ships ever.

Battle system was simplified, - the power plants dont explode anymore taking out parts of your ship, making the whole experience a bit more casual, then again this removed the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like enemy t1 ships kamikaze into your dreadnaughts taking them out by their heroic sacrifice.

There are now ground battles  which are not enjoyable one bit. Its a welcome addition but it will need a LOT of work if it is ever going to make it. The problems with ground battles start from randomising the troops instead of allowing for 1 standartised troop type you want to take into battle wiht you; ♥♥♥♥ing up your carefull planning of team at some point * i honestly dont know  when * by randomising what they carry in battle despite meticulous repicking of what they have. But that doesnt matter, the enemy AI is ♥♥♥♥ poor. All you have to do is sit at starting point and accumulate points, then ai rushes in with nothing and you get what is 2 turns of firepower unleashed on them before they have a chance to respond,... then just mop it up.

Ive seen a lot of people complain about how the game is hard and ai might even be cheating. Truth is AI is horrible in macro map aswell and it does indeed cheat at least somewhat. For this was made an experiment ( you can confirm this yourself btw ) -> create TINY map with extremely limited resoures and max ai. Reload till you have good starting place, since rest of galaxy sucks ♥♥♥ AI will be attracted to what your system has to offer and might 'scout' it with colony ship. Thats right! Its 'very lucky' with guessing where good planets might be. Incredible feat. Same goes for assuming firepower. AI knows what you have at all stages without scouting anything. If it saw you on map and met you you ♥♥♥♥ing bet it knows what you have.

Does it matter that it knows? No it does not. AI has no ♥♥♥♥ing clue what is going on macro wise and all it cares about is Command points and total ship count. Suppose you have 4 stationed tier 5 ships outfitted to the maximum of capability, just imagine 2500-3k worth of manufacturing. Thats about 8 CP if you play your cards right. And just 4 ships. In AIs mind you have NOTHING AT ALL. ITS A FREE WIN TOWN BABY WOOOOOOOOOOOO! TIME TO PILLAGE. And then they get destroyed. It wont stop them. No sir! They will keep spamming the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little ships untill their last planet dies. It refuses to adapt it refuses to utilise the technology they have. Hell i GAVE them tech for tier 4 and 5
date: gave them schematics for weapons and armor for free to what my diplomacy allowed. Gave them 100 turns and went to war with them. 200 turns later they still dont have anything bigger then tier3 ships with swarmers. Ai ♥♥♥♥ing loves swarming.\n\nAnd its  the ultimate cancer
recommended: you see in late game you will be facing say 200 CP (command point) fleet. Are you excited for some epic showdown of 2 mighty fleets? You better not be because you will be autoresolving the battle. If not prepare for 1 fps for next 15 minutes because ai will be carrying as many corvettes it can
hoursPlayed:
and the t3 ships will be filled up with viper fighters spamming up everything. Do you have NASA supercomputer? Well too bad for you the game doesnt give a ♥♥♥♥ you will still be lagging.

AI never changes tactics in any form or shape. Ive also never seen pirates spawn and attack AI how it does happen against player. then again maybe my scouts and listening posts are not all seeing so i might have missed it.

Lets focus on the positive -> the diplomacy window for reactions is great! Its charismatic

reviewText: Full disclosure: I am a Stardrive 2 closed beta tester, but I have not received any compensation for my testing or for this review. I'm really just a 4x gaming fan at heart who was lucky enough to be given access to Stardrive 2 during its development :)\n\nI highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a galactic empire building game featuring that just one more turn" itch that some of the great 4x games of the past have offered. This is definitely a game that can keep you up late at night
date: constantly clicking end turn just to see what lies ahead in the development and struggles of the star nation you've spent hours carefully building.\n\nRight from the start
recommended: you'll be faced with interesting events
hoursPlayed: encounters
voteText: and anomalies that will drive you to spread your chosen species farther out amongst the stars. You'll research interesting technologies
helpfulPercent: some of them unique to your species and others totally random in nature. You'll find valuable resources to claim through colonization and exploration. You'll design and build your own starships to conquer your enemies and protect all you've gained. You'll engage in diplomacy and espionage with/against a variety of interesting and unique alien species all with their own agendas. You'll meet minor species to either befriend
votesHelpful: enslave
votesTotal: or exterminate.\n\nThe combination of turn-based empire management with real-time space combat helps to break up the pace of the game into enjoyable yet distinct pieces. Being able to see a newly researched weapon help your ships blaze a path of destruction across an enemy fleet in real-time combat helps to tie the entire game together and makes it feel like every decision you've made matters. The ship designing and customization are definitely high points of Stardrive 2. The space combat is visually impressive and always fun to play. The ground combat is turn-based
votesFunny: with an X-Com Enemy Unknown feel to it
commentsCount: which I've come to really enjoy as an entirely separate mini-game within Stardrive 2.\n\nIn short
column16: if you're looking to escape from reality for hours at a time by putting on the hat of a space emperor and building your very own interstellar civilization this is the game for you!"

reviewText:
I will not be playing this expansion as the core issues that make the game unplayable for me have not been adressed.

Ships have ridiculous balance. A vulfar fleet of 6 ships gets easily outgunned by two pollop cruisers. Even two vulfar battlecruisers will lose to two pollop cruisers. You can imagine that when the NPCs are these races, the vulfar will ALWAYS LOSE. ALWAYS. The Ralyeh Titan ship is smaller and less utilizable than their battlecruiser. What. The Kulrathi are actually decently balanced, HUGE but not usable for proper artillery guns and they're slow, so if you can pick them off before they reach you that's a great strategy. Bring flak against their fighter spam, I like how that race plays out. The Humans have small ships, and early on do not have the money to keep them. Not really a ship issue, but they've got issues with them and are easily halted to a stop early on. The Draylok are another all-right race, their ships are decently sized beyond their frigates. The Codrazine dew the shortest straws together with the vulfar, their slots are insanely hard to utilize and their titan is tiny. The Chukk are basically a better vulfar. They scale decently in the game and their titan is quite big (even though it's not exactly very usable) and their early frigates in a player's hands can hold off early fleets. As an NPC however, they are incredibly aggressive with ♥♥♥♥ ships so they're usually a joke. The Opteris are also really insane. Everything is very square so lots of usable space, their frigates can fit like six large cannons or five fighter bays iirc, have tons of port side capability for close combat and are quite fast, same goes for all of their ships really.

So basically, the Opteris and Pollop are insane, the Kulrathi are close, and the rest are always doing incredibly bad and in a player's hand (Besides the draylok, they're usable if you abuse mechanics) give you a really big disadvantage.
Untill this is addressed, I will not recommend it to ANYONE. You'll love the game initially, until you realise that only three races are playable without severe disadvantage on any real difficulty without abusing mechanics.. Purely from a combat perspective. This makes every game you play exactly the same with three races doing alright, one being a diplomatic switzerland sitting quietly in their part of the universe and a few pirate races that are the laughing stock of the universe. Randomizing anything including traits only ♥♥♥♥s up the balance even more and regardless of what you do, a mid game pollop fleet will win any battle with a much larger vulfar fleet without any casualties.

EDIT: the new DLC doesn't change anything to address this.

reviewText:
I see quite a few negative reviews on here talking about the difficulty of the game, so I'll share my point of view on that. So far I've played a number of games over 11 hours (normal) and have lost every single one. You know what though? I get a little bit better every time, and I know I'm getting close to winning. The first time I conquer the galaxy I will feel like I earned it. The AI doesn't cheat, it's not entirely ruthless towards you as long as you dont take the repulsive trait because you want the easy 4 points.

People get upset because they lose. The fun is in the challenge of rising to the top. I think it's quite fitting that the first few times you try to conquer the galaxy you get slapped around.

It's a game that takes practice, turn it on to easy if you are struggling and make sure you understand the mechanics of the game.  There is a tutorial which lots of people ignore and several help sections in the game. Some mechanics are a little obscure, for example how your empire generates galactic credits beyond population is not explained very well.  However, there is an insane amount of tooltips explaining anything you mouse over which makes it really easy to find information.

Combat is really fun, though the fact that the default ships are designed incredibly efficiently probably contributes to the difficulty new players are having.  However you can easily see the default layouts (which again are quite good) and can work on designing your ship from there. There are a few performance issues with large scale battles, but I hope to see them ironed out in the future. There are a large variety of weapons and options for those weapons, as well as support systems so you can design ships any way you like them. It also looks pretty damn good too. I hope to see more activatable abilities in the future, but right now space combat is a solid tactical experience.

The economy is good. It's really irritating that people are complaining about the map size, because I can't imagine playing on something like a 150 system map. There would be too much to do. I think a few people loaded the game and said what
date: 70 stars default?" without understanding the depth of the economy. You'll be really busy managing your empire with even a few systems. You can specialize your planets and they also develop over time
recommended: gaining unique traits depending on what you do with them. High research planets attract universities
hoursPlayed: big farming planets will eventually attract a farmers market
voteText: etc.\n\nThere is more I could go on about but overall I'm happy with my purchase. I'm excited to see a few balance passes over the next few weaks

reviewText: As a long time fan of Master of Orion 2, this game at first seemed to scratch an itch.  So many 4x games try and fail, this one seems to be great at the beginning then totally falls apart.  A nice ship design system, an okay tech tree and interesting racial options.  Where it falls apart is in its AI, it knows where everything is, and doesn't even try to hide it.  That one planet at the back of your nation that has never been scouted, the one without a star base, yup every enemy you have will attack it again and again and again.  Combine that with the ability for the AI to build huge fleets in a handful of turns, and sneak them around, and the inability to intercept said fleets because they go right past yours without combat, it totally ruins the experence.  I like the front end changes of this game vs moo2, but the depth just isn't there.

reviewText:
I just finished watching a live stream of the dev playing the game and learned a lot from it. I still have my reservations about the game, however Zero is patching the game to address some of the concerns I've had about difficulty.

Truth is if you play the game 'smart', you can win. Having said that, I tend to turtle. I like games with a slow burn to them. I don't like getting into wars very early. Maybe that's where my frustration comes from. I would still like to be able to refine AI behaviors much more and tune them to my preferences and hopefully we'll see the implementation of that.

Regardless, Zero seems to really care about the game and the community. I believe he'll do everything he can to make it fun for everyone. Those that want an easier game, will probably get it, and those that want the challenge, definitely already have it.

Bottom line is, the game is worth it. I don't want to turn anyone away from this with an overly negative review. My original review had nothing good to say about the game and that's very very wrong, the game is worth the price tag and definitely worth your time.

Previously published negative review:
There are a great many things to like about StarDrive 2 but unfortunately the incredibly unfair and difficult AI outshine anything good this game currently has to offer.

The main problem comes from the fact that the AI seem to be able to 'cheat'. They always have these impossibly massive fleets that more than out match yours regardless of how advanced your race is. Diplomacy is laughable. It's always completely one sided, the AI will make you an offer but will almost always reject your counter offer even though it's more than a fair trade. If you refuse to trade with them on account of you getting a terrible deal out of it, be prepared for them to invade you almost immediately.

The problem is two-fold because the difficulty setting does NOTHING for the AI difficulty. The only thing it does is change how hard diplomacy is. Because of this the difficulty setting might as well not even be there. Even if you are able to get a race on your good side, and you give them everything they ask for and more, they will inevitably declare war on you for seemingly no reason and they will always win that war because they're somehow able to match your forces 3 - 1 or more.

This is not even taking into account the amount of 'random' enemies that spawn very early into the game and destroy any progress you make. They never stop. You can't destroy their bases because you aren't given enough time inbetween each attack to amass a fleet large enough to destroy them. The worst is when your main fleet is blown to bits and they go after your freighters. You can't defend your freighters because an enemy engagement with them is an automatic combat failure. They're just destroyed. So your colonies starve and die out. If you create more, the AI that's camping your home world will just immediately destroy it. You can't send reinforcements because the game forces you into a combat screen with no way to send more ships to help.

This is a huge problem because your fleet could be RIGHT NEXT to your home world but the attacking fleet manages to get in just right so the only thing fighting on your side is the orbital station around your world. So you just have to let them destroy it while you sit there unable to do anything about it.

The combat 'fun factor' suffers for me because if they decide to attack my lone scout vessel two feet away from my main fleet, I have no choice but to waste a good 30 seconds entering combat and making it retreat when it would be so much better if I could just have my main fleet join the battle.

In short, the current state of this game is frustrating. The negatives I mentioned here would be completely manageable if not for the freaking AI steamrolling you 10 minutes into the game.

reviewText:
StarDrive 2 is a complete rip off of Master of Orion 2 without any of the good and all the bad.

A lot of people on here are writing reviews either praising the game or telling you it is too difficult. I doubt anyone praising it has actually beaten it or plays many 4X titles. I could write a long list about why you should avoid this game, but I will keep it short. Here is the breakdown:

1. There is no ending. A silent video is all you have to indicate you have won the match. The game will continue even once finished. You have to exit to the main menu, quit to desktop, or keep playing.

2. Conquest is your only victory condition. You cannot have allies, so there is no diplomatic option.

2. The UI is a direct copy from MoO2 in every way. Managing colonies at the late game is tedious, and will take up almost all of your time unless you ignore them.

3. The AI is terrible. If you need proof, go read any of the other 500+ reviews telling you it is terrible.

4. Diplomacy is pointless. The AI will only use diplomacy to threaten you. Once again, you cannot have allies.

5. The ground combat is terrible. It is similar to XCOM in style, but is devoid of any strategy. There is no cover, and only a few weapons / items in the entire game. You take over entire planets with small squads of marines.

6. The game is too quiet. The only sound is the music (which is very lackluster especially in combat), and basic UI / combat sound Fx. There are no voice overs except for the tutorial. It truly feels desolate and without character.

There are a multitude of other issues, but I will not burden you with them. The end all be all is that the game is not what it should be. Your play experience will not be good, and when you finally beat a match you will be extremely disappointed by the ending assuming you survived the boredom of the late game.

reviewText:
UPDATE: Don't buy this game because you won't be able to play it, everytime a patch comes out you have to perform a hotfix by editing files yourself.

So yeah, definately don't buy this unless you wan't to be spending time browsing the forums for fixes to crashes instead of playing.



I'm only going to mention the original StarDrive once because it would be unfair to base this game solely on its predecessor. I loved StarDrive and had a ton of fun with it, I practically threw my wallet at my monitor when I found out StarDrive 2 existed and had already been released.

The graphical and sound options aren’t abundant but the consistent and unchangeable graphics are part of what’s unique about this game. It has a cool look to it which is appealing. The best planets in your empire come to life as they grow, space stations can be seen orbiting them and large cities lights can be seen from space.

Real time battles look nice and it is exciting to watch your ship designs stomp the enemy. On the contrary it’s also fun to watch your ships get smashed because you never took that class on the importance of point defense. The trial and error required to design a potent military add an exciting element to the game. I have never been engaged in a large battle however, every battle I have fought has consisted of mostly between 10-30 ships.

Diplomacy doesn’t seem to do much at the moment. Each faction will contact you (probably once every 10 turns so get ready for the spam depending on how many AI you have encountered) and offer trade agreements or technology swaps (or to demand tribute if they're a more aggressive AI). The AI honor their treaties as far as I am aware (haven’t had any issues myself but others might have). By treaties I mean trade agreements or non-aggression pacts and nothing else. The game has a weird way of negotiating using some sort of tolerance system which I haven’t figured out yet.

Spies allow you to perform multiple functions. Defensively they protect you from enemy spies. Offensively they can steal technology (in the form of moles which are currently unstoppable to my knowledge), reveal enemy fleets and movements and two other functions I cannot recall. Essentially you can just spam build spies because they can be produced quickly and have no cost or maintenance. Once you have an armada of spies you can plant an infinite number of moles to steal all the technology you need (the AI will do it to you so I hope you don’t enjoy your privacy).

Technology works in (nine?) different tech trees. When you research anything in one of the tech trees that tech tree advances. You have to choose what is important for now and trade or steal (probably steal) the rest. The tech you unlock includes everything from ship parts, new space stations, upgrades or buildings for your empire.

Gameplay wise imagine that someone told you civilization five was similar to a real time strategy game. All you have to do is hold down the end turn button. The problem is that it doesn’t work. It isn’t entertaining and StarDrive 2 ends up feeling painfully slow at times. The larger your empire gets the more it needs to be micromanaged (which is to be expected but ends up being oddly complicated).

As the game slows down you’ll find yourself dealing with countless nuisances. Neutral AI entities will spawn at a constant rate to attack your undefended systems. Wormholes will open up faster than a hookers legs. I have not had a single game where a wormholes have not opened up in the heart of my empire to allow free reign to anyone who wanted to ravage my sweet virgin body.

Countering the pirate/neutral AI threat would be fairly easy except that there are unreasonable soft population caps which punish you for having a fleet capable of defending yourself. I have not figured out a way around this aside from raising taxes to obscene levels during incursions or just having a huge surplus of space cash. Couple this with the fact that finding habitable worlds is like trying to find a straight guy in a gay bar. Your empire will end up being large and spread out but still only containing 4-5 good planets (meaning your limited size fleets had better be well managed)

In conclusion StarDrive 2 is not a bad a game but at this time there are too many small annoyances that keep me from enjoying what might be a great game. It feels like I spend most of my time fighting everything but other empires. Its problems leave it average and unenjoyable. In time this game will probably become great through its mod support and continued developer input (the dev has been working non-stop to fix issues). <3 you Zero.

5/10.

Please pardon any grammatical errors, I am but a simple plebian.

reviewText:
Gotta start with this: This game is amazing.  If you like RTS/4x/Space you will like this.  Battles are RTS, rest of game is turn based.  Customization of your spaceships is the best part.  Well worth the price.

But read on cause it's not all good.  This game has bugs.  Lots of them, way too many for a release.  Save often cause it crashes.  Occasionally you may control your opponent's army in a fight.  Sometimes units will start a battle with 0HP.  Beating the game doesn't always trigger the victory screen (In fact I only got it to happen once).  The events in the game are few and get old fast, but they aren't required to play.

The UI needs work, the races need balence, the bugs need fixing and the only victory condition is poorly thought out.  But the core is great and the game is fun and addicting.  I'm done playing for now as it's getting old but if Zero ever fixes these things I'll be back building spaceships the next day.

DLC Edit:
Many of my inital complaints have been fixed.  Lots of good rebalencing.  Got me to spend another 20-30 hours on it.

reviewText:
The most addictive 4X game I've played since Master of Orion 2.  The shipbuilding is amazing, and the space battles are absolutely beautiful.  It has many different minigames, including unique missions and research, giving plenty of interesting choices along the way.

Only minor problem I have with it is that the ground combat is a bit wonky to see what you're doing and control properly, and doesn't quite live up to the rest of the game in terms of how it looks.  Also, the unique missions seem to be pretty few in number, since I tend to get the same 2-3 ones every game I start, but this will hopefully be addressed with mods/dlc in future.

Well worth the money, this game is tonnes of fun.

reviewText:
Love 4X and games like Civilization, Warlock, etc. but don't care for this game.  Tutorial is lacking- manual is lacking often have no idea why I'm doing poorly or how to fix it.  Maybe if I played the first version would be more intuitive - <shrug>.

Combat get super repetitive real fast.  Built three of the large starting ships and the AI starts attacking me right off sending their ships at my fleet. My ships just stay in the same place and launch missles at approaching ships until all other ships are dead and mine are all but undamaged.  Next fight same thing - by 7th or 8th battle I am super bored so I click auto resolve for the battle and two of my three ships die... whaaa...so much fun.   Meanwhile I am losing money with no apparent means for generating more.   So the game keeps selling off my buildings  which don't seem to do anything anyway since none of my colonies are growing even though i have surplus food and freighters.

Tech seems mostly leaning towards upgrading ships which are already winning every battle.  Nothing seems to help me generate larger colonies or more money - tech descriptions are super vague as well.

Overall seems like a lot of tedious work with poor documentation and in-game info and i am not enjoying myself enough to even put the time in to figure it out.

reviewText:
Gameplay in StarDrive 2 is too forced into a style that the developer wants instead of a style that I would like to play the game.

If after a certian number of turns you have not made contact with any other players then a wormhole spawns between your homeworld and another players homworld. This often results in an AI fleet invading my homeworld is short order. The developer has responded saying that this is a feature designed to prevent turtling. My take is that if I want to turtle I should be able to do so!

I would still like to turtle so I make contact with another player, but maintain peacefull/minimal releations with them. After a while I get a notice that my citizens are wanting to go to war with the AI player. Since Im just starting to build a navy I decide against it. A few turns later a large fleet of 'rebels' bent on going to war show up at my homworld to change the government. My fleet of now 2 ships gets steamrolled by the rebel fleet 3 times larger than my fleet.

Let me play the game how I want. If I want to turtle and play 'simspace empire' for a while I should be able to without being forced to play aggressive.

reviewText:
It is a Master of Orion remake.
Its graphics are polished up, the combat is real time, but it all boils down to the simple fact that this is Master of Orion.
If not for the hefty price tag, I would definitely recommend this game.

Other points of concern:

Combat
The space combat is entertaining in the beginning, but becomes a chore in the late game.
With large numbers of ships, the battlefield is crowded from second one, it does not scale well over time.
The load times before and after battles make the automatic battle resolution even more tempting. But Ships do not seem to get XP from automated combat...
(Also, combat pre-load and after-load times are horribly long, even with newest Hardware)

Diplomacy
The diplomacy is really broken: It is easy to keep other empires entertained or urge them to trade stuff with you no sensible human player would ever think of trading.
The diplomacy mechanic seems superfluous to the eventual military conquest, there is no diplomatic victory" of any sort
date: nor deeper mechanics known from other 4X games."

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. Unfortunately, the downsides eventually got me too frustrated to be able to continue play.

* Really odd game balancing : economy is almost always doing badly, even with the barest of minimum planet maintenance facilities. Random space pirates show up with ships more advanced than your interstellar government's and knock out your flagships. Really?
* Performance issues: The indie part of this game shows through painfully during ground forces combat. The graphics are far from anything special, but everything seems to lag anyway. There are similar issues throughout the game, like an annoying, delayed transition between space combat and the strategy map. Speech text is very slow. And there are no options for adjusting these things...

Dah. I might give it another go and try to take on a capitalist personality in an effort to have a workable economy, but gads. So far it's just worn my patience thin.

reviewText:
I feel I have played enough of this game to write a proper review.

This game is a great deal of fun. Ship customization is awesome, Space combat is great fun and if you have the tactical mind about you, you can destroy whole fleets with just a handful of ships if you do it just right. The game is extreamly difficult passed easy mode, making it high risk high reward game. Random events will happen, like a random ship will apper with bugs on it, or your planet will have sharknados. This increases replay value and keeps me wanting to come back and find all of these. The Ui is simple and nicely laid out, making moving troops and building ships a breeze.

However this game does have its issues.

Ground combat is not as in depth as Most people would like. Its just a simple move-here xenonauts like combat, except not nearly as in depth, as previously mentioned.
There seems to be only one way to win. Build a huge fleet, and steam roll the galaxy. Trading and negotiating simply puts war off. I wish there were other ways to get other peoples colonys with out bombing it from orbit. For example, Maybe spreading your culture across the galaxy will cause certian colonys to turn to earth culture" and that colony joins your faction. This way developing relations with other factions isnt pointless

Overall
recommended: and if you are new to the 4x stratagy genre

reviewText:
I think I can sum up the game in one word: tedious. StarDrive 2 is a modern remake of Masters of Orion 2. It adds some neat features, like placing modules in specific quadrants of the ship but takes away on some of the others. I'll try to break down some of the main areas.

Colony Management - It's very tedious, much like MoO2. There are some auto-builder scripts you can select from to focus on food, research, or production. But, when I pick one like production, the manager often moves some of the people off of production and over to research. If I try to correct this, the colony goes back to manual mode. Also, you may inadvertently get technology for colony buildings you don't want (some have drawbacks), and these will get rolled into the build queue by the colony AI".

reviewText:
I would definitely recommend this game. Forget the trollish reviews--a lot of people are reviewing the game not its own merits but by posts by the developer or experiences with a prior game (SD1, which is a different beast, but related).

Yes, the game is HEAVILY indebted to a classic 4x space game, Master of Orion 2. It's not quite as good as that game (but what it is, eh?), but with some polish and an expansion pack, I think this game might surpass it.

What you should ask yourself is this -- do you want a space 4x game with a turn-base strategy and a RTS tactical map? If so, SD2 is for you. Really, there are not many hybrid 4X games out there. There's the Total War games, Sword of the Stars series, and . . . ? Most game companies don't do these type of games--they either go turn-based all the way, or RTS all the way. Why? It's really hard to program two-games in one and figure out the proper way the two should mix.

SD2 manages to pull off this hybrid approach really well. On the strategy side, you colonize planets and build buildings that help improve the economy. There are many buildings that can help improve industry or science or food. you can then use trade to boost these variables.

On the tech side, the tree is deep enough but not too much to allow individual techs to feel unique and useful. There's still some balancing to do, but the nice thing is, lower tier techs, mostly the weapons, still have their place. You're also limited by your race and your choices, so nearly impossible to get the entire tech advances in one game. This offers some interesting strategic choices up front--do I choose better weapons or better buildings or research options?

Combat involves an RTS game where ships duke it out. Lots pew-pew here with cool weapon and shield effects. Some battle can get pretty crazy, especially when there are lot of ships. Sometimes, the RTS mode can be buggy, and when you ahve a lot of ships on screen, the game lags. The developer is working on this problem and has posted some potential fixes.

There's a lot more to this -- included is a scenario and campaign editor. You can also experiment with a battle-only" mode
date: where you can design ships and see them duke it out. No reviewers mention this! It's such a great idea
recommended: and i can't think of any modern game that includes this option.\n\nGive this game a chance --it's a one man developer
hoursPlayed: and you can surely get a good 50-60 hours of this game
voteText: if not more if you mess around with each race and the scenario editor. There's a ton of content to play around with--don't get sucked into the negative hype. The game is well worth your money."
