reviewText:
New Edit 22.05.2015

Happy that the devs did not listen to the fanboys. The game is now harder, many of the problems below are fixed. This game is still not one of the best 4x game but I would give it a 6/10 in it's current state.

Ground Combat is still boring as hell, feels out of place, takes a hell of a long time (and you can't save during the battle) and makes planetary invasion very tedious and boring. I really miss the old Stardrive planet battles, but even more I wish they could have gone for the MOO model instead. Stardrive 2 is basically just planetary bombardment=automatic win without any real consequences (you get some insignificant pollution). Planetary bombardment of your own planets is still just a pop up message.

At least now the game offers a challenge, although it is usually a predictable one, the only interesting factor is seeing what tech the enemy have gone for. But usually its just standard configurations.

The space battles are great, colonization is cool, empire management is okay. As stated above it is a 6/10 now.

Old Review:

Edit: Many fanboys are thumb downing my review, they have obviously never played any of the great old 4x games and I wish them well on their journey into the 4x space genre. The developer is working hard to rectify many of the detriments below so I may be changing this into recommended. Want to add like many other of the no fanboy reviews that long range cannons make the game very easy to exploit. Hope to see this change as well like the dev was hinting in the last update.

This is the best Strategy Starship customizer and battle simulator to date, sadly though I can't recommend the game as a full 4x product because of it detriments.

Here is a summation of the Detriments:

Ground Combat:
Awkward out of place RPG grid turn based board game that is slow, boring and does not belong in a 4x game ever. The customization of the soldiers is tedious, the limited amount of soldiers is stupid as it makes planetary defence which was a very cool aspect of the original Star Drive impossible. No more massing an armada on nearby planets planning your military invasion in steps in a grand strategy. Now its just 12 ground troops=automatic Win. If you need some inspiration then check out a old glory game called Imperium Galactica or it's prequel Reunion by one Hungarian team, or even better use the MASTER OF ORION II system with two armies basically just slugging it out on a battlefield referencing Empire Strikes Back battle on Hoth. Not a RPG slow grind that take ages for a simple comat which is in truth a wierd minigame within the game.

Note: The Diplomacy has been greatly improved in the last update, so this criticism is no longer valid.
Diplomacy:
Went from exploitable in Stardrive the original into plain stupid in Stardrive 2. In the original stardrive you could get any treaty if you just sprinkled it with enough techs or capital, which made it very easy to get a cease fire even when the Opteris or Rayleh had just destroyed your armada and they stand ready to commit genocide. Now even throwing everything at a normal trade treaty the AI just says wow you are giving me too much

reviewText:
First of all let me make it clear that even though I don't recommend this game I do sort of love it.

This game would be the best thing in 4x genre I have seen since Moo2 if it was not so riddled with technical problems.
Constant loading problems and stuff not working as they are supposed to make it a really unenjoyable experience.
To give an example at one point I had a situation where pirate raiders would destroy multiple freighters and thats ok.
The problem is there was like five of those fights which were just a press of a button and then my freighter would die.
And at some point during this it would bug out and not allow me to continue resulting in me having to crash the game and load and hope it would go through the next time.
It eventually did after repeating this nearly ten times.
At other points weirdly usually after losing a fight it would get stuck in the loading screen resulting in the same thing.

And these bugs are numerous let me tell you.
In no other game that I have played i've had to crash the game so much as in this.

Other issues I have had with it is that I think the research options are too narrow and simplistic.
There should also be more options to how you want to play the game, as in victory conditions.
The game events are very linear, random events are not really random as they pretty much happen always at the same time.
I would also like to see more variety on ship hull types for all the races it is quite boring to only have one hull of each size class.
Overall the game needs more content in it and get rid of the technical problems.

Now having said that I do love what the game is trying to do.
It is more like Moo2 than anything I have seen since Moo2 and that is very much a good thing so if you liked Moo2 then hope that this game gets it's technical problems in order and you will have a good time.

reviewText:
As someone who enjoyed playing StarDrive, I'd like to share my experience of playing Stardrive 2. So far (14.6h) I've been playing as Humans (with my own custom civ traits of course - they make a MAJOR difference in your gameplay experience) on Normal difficulty, huge system with 9 other civs, and I'm currently faced with enemies on both my northern and southern space borders. I'm also becoming quite chummy with some samurai space bears.

Now I've seen some complaints about Stardrive 2, and I have to admit my first few hours had a couple of complaints - mainly research and... well, I'll tell you what else when I get to it. Further into the game I found out how they downgraded the spy system, but let's get back to research. I was annoyed at how you could not research all the tech on the same tier, and then I encountered my first race. (I'd like to mention that I don't go exploring the entire galaxy, so I don't encounter multiple races before I'm ready to deal with them. That'd just be STUPID... Hmm was that too rude of me?) When I entered diplomacy with them, I was happily surprised to find out that you could trade the tech they had researched for whatever you feel like giving them. After encountering a few more civs, and by the time I met up with my favorite bear shogunate, I realized that unless you take diplomatic action towards these aliens, they're gonna wonder why they should keep the stupid foriegners around rather than kill and conquer them.

I should probably mention that being able to customize your ships relatively freely is a big plus for me. They made it a touch simpler than the original StarDrive, but while it was disappointing at first - I realized it cut down the time I spent designing my failures and designing new ships to replace the failures (since they sucked in combat) or redesigning my redundant ships (due to new tech). For example, in SD1 you could face all your weapon firing arcs forward. In SD2, the location of your weapon decides where it aims (except cannons/mass drivers - they always aim forward) The way around this though is to select the *arc extend* feature on the turrets you mount so they cover a 180* angle - aka they can fire forward.

I'll be updating this review in a few days once I'm back home and play a bit more, so I'll leave you with this: if you like customization and you find that you can understand a game's mechanics fairly quickly, then you'll enjoy this game.

reviewText:
Stardrive 2 is a fun 4X with a focus on combat, ship design and exploration. Think Total War in space: turn based strategy map with real time space battles.

Lots of good humour and references to SciFi in the game, as well as colourful characters / races / art. Lots of random events and anomalies to explore - the galaxy is a big place.

Ship designer is quite deep and uses a module based system where you drop and drag engines, weapons etc onto your ship. Everything is directional, so shields placed on the left side will only shield the left side, and weapons have firing arcs depending on where they are placed etc. For those who don't like making ships, the game comes with default designs.

This game is heavily inspired by MoO2. If you are looking for a massive complex game like Distant Worlds or Europa Universalis, you won't find it here. Ground combat is turn based tactical similar to Xcom or Advance Wars. I would say the ground combat is alright but not great.

Some of the menus need polish which I expect will come as the dev tweaks the game post-release. I have not encountered any game-breaking bugs, but the game did freeze once and the one time the UI disappeared while I was in the ship designer. There are also some game balance issues which are of course being worked on by the dev.

Even still, it's worth picking up.

reviewText:
I'm a huge 4X strategy gamer and think that, for the most part, this is what Master of Orion 3 should have been.  This game begs for comparisons against MOO2 because many of its features are straight from the game and other predecessors, which is perfectly fine by me.  I actually prefer strategy games that build on the best aspects from prior games rather than trying to reinvent the wheel.

The Major Gripes:

- No multiplayer.  Unfortunately, the AI is just not smart enough to maintain my interest, so after 50+ hours, I'm probably done with this game, which is kinda sad because its very solid

- The AI is dumb.  I play on the hardest setting and there's just never a point where I don't have the upper hand.  I'm absolutely baffled by all of the reviews on here that say the game is too hard.  If you build two of the largest size ships you can build (with the original starting tech), no enemy player can touch you for quite a while.  Now, I don't mean to say that the AI is particularly dumb in this game.  Its not.  The stupidity of the AI, unfortunately, is a problem that spans most 4x space strategy games like this (I'm looking at you SOTS 2, MOO3, Gal Civ 3, Civ 5, etc).  However, without multiplayer, that sorta ends the game.

Random Musings:

-  Designing ships is fun and just complicated enough without being too complicated and there's a lot of viable approaches to take.  Make ships super fast and give them devastating close combat weapons or slow your ships down with lots of long range artillery and kill the enemy before they get to you.

- I've never found any use for building smaller than the largest ships.  The AI hasn't seemed to figure that out though, so my fleets always completely annihilate them (even on the games hardest setting).

- Unfortunately, without multiplayer or a brilliant AI, your enemies will never adapt to any of your strategies, so you'll never need to vary them up.

- Turn based strategy map with real time combat space combat is my favorite combination in strategy games, but this is probably a personal preference.

- You can specialize worlds.  Have a very fertile planet?  Make it your bread basket.

- Its pretty.  Its not going to win any awards, but its crisp and attractive and not a throwback to the 90s like Distant Worlds.

- Ground combat is xcom style, but unfortunately its very limited to not being worth playing at this point.  The AI is particularly easy in ground combat once you figure out how to use shields properly.

- Its got solid game mechanics.  The economy is complicated enough to be fun, and simple enough to not be tedious.

reviewText:
Beta Tester review

Stardrive2 takes the best parts of Stardrive1
Extensive ship customisation
Epic real time battles
Funny and cool aliens

And merges it with the best of MoO2
Extensive research including -racial techs -random techs  -exclusivity techs, and more.
Central quest with mysteries and treasure
Huge race customization options
Challenging and aggresive enemies
Space Monsters
Tense diplomacy
A News robot

And then it adds a bit of its own magic to the mix too
Turn based ground battles and customizable troops.
Unique leaders to govern your planets, command your fleets, fight your ground battles, or even do some spying.
A powerful espionage system how you use it can mean the difference between victory and defeat.
Moral choices,- how you play will
effect other empires attitudes to you.
Many special events to keep you on your toes.
Minor races with unique abilities.

Its a game I will be playing for years, not just for the battles, not just for the cute aliens, not just because its beautiful game, but becasue it is a modern MoO2 and I need just one more turn.

reviewText:
Stardrive 2 is one of the best 4X games I've played recently, certainly the best game based in space. It has some minor issues, but none that can't be easily resolved with some time post-release.

Pros:
Great empire management
Great ship design (One of my favorite parts of the game)
Tech tree that forces strategic decisions (Unlike Civ tech tree where you always end up with everything)
Difficult to win (I really am sick of strategy games where victory is assured on all difficulties except the very highest)
Enjoyable ship combat
Good graphics

Cons:
Various bugs, though not terribly common
Huge battles very CPU heavy (Playing on a Phenom II x4 840t, so not a great processor)
Some weapon balance problems
No multiplayer (This isn't a huge problem for me personally, but I know people who won't play games if it doesn't have multiplayer)

Overall, the game has a great set of mechanics that will only get better as the dev polishes up the remaining content.
9/11, would certainly recommend it to anyone who likes strategy, or sci-fi epics.

reviewText: You want to know what makes a great 4X game great?  When I can research the ever-living crap out of a tech tree and have weapons and sub-systems capable of putting an enemy in a vice grip they can't get out of when they think they stand a legitimate chance at beating me.  It just seems that for every legitimate effort I make to race my ♥♥♥ up the tech tree into even being capable of standing toe-to-toe with my enemies, while making decent headway into designing my ships properly, I just keep finding myself generally outclassed unless I spam an enormous amount of starships into a battle.\n\nThis isn't part of my review necessarily, it's just a remark I'd like to make:  I have also heard that this game's predecessor actually had some decent concepts but that it had been abandoned so the developer could focus on this.  That's a really tough claim to make, considering this game looks worse than what I saw in the trailers for the first.

reviewText:
Just like with the first Stardrive, it took me a while to get the hang of this game. The way the AI worked, the combat system, the whole game really. I hated it. Just like I hated the first Stardrive. You know what I did though? I kept at it, until finally, I got the hang of it. I loved Stardrive after that and I was expecting something different from the sequel. I was a little disappointed, but you can't always get exactly the things you want. No, this game isnt exactly Stardrive. It's Stardrive 2. It's great in it's own way, JUST like Stardrive was.

Just because it isn't exactly what some people were expecting doesn't mean it's a bad game. It took me almost two whole days to actually start enjoying this game. Now that I figured it out, I love it. If you liked Stardrive, then try this one out. It's a different experience but it's great all the same. If it's not for you, then it just isn't. No need to leave a bad review on OPENING DAY because it has problems or doesn't meet your expectations. This guy, Zero, put out two patches almost right on top of each other after listening to peoples complaints and bug reports. Where else do you get  service like that for your games? You don't, or at least not anywhere else in my experience. Be happy about that at least.

Anyway, in conclusion I suppose, this game isn't exactly Stardrive, if you want that play Stardrive by all means it's a great game. So is this game, it just takes some time to adjust. The customer service" from these developers is insanely good. Don't like something or think its broken? Bring it up
date: they'll probably fix it. Buy this game if you like Stardrive
hoursPlayed: or 4Xs. You'll enjoy it if you do.\n\n"

reviewText:
I was a beta tester and so i have had the game for a long long while.
but... most of that play was just pointing out issues and commenting on things.
And working on blackbox for sd1. A lot of time working on blackbox....

I didnt really play the game as a game until it was released because i wanted to wait to play the real thing.
I was not thrilled about the game being TBS. I know people like that but I really dig 4x RTS. being tbs was a big turn off to me.

But... It works here. i can take my time. put it down to do something else. I still am much more attracted to RTS 4x but something about this game i find very engaging. I think its the ship design and how it fits in with the game.

I find there is a connection between ship design and strategic use of the ships. research labs on a ship provide research points and provide ship combat function.
sensors are useful.
i find myself making my own command ships. ships with larger bridges and long range weapons and sensors and what not designed to give the rest of the more combat ships a better strategic use.


I find myself making diverse fleets of ships with specific roles and not just mobs of super combat ships.
I like that a lot. Thats not a feeling i get in a lot of these games where the ship design feels part of overall game.

There are also all these mini quests and adventures. like what sd1 what trying to do with the revoran and such but did not make it and some of these quests are just killer in concept.

but... There are launch bugs. Ill update this review in week or so and see where its at. There are not a lot of game breaking bugs. the one i hit was in the ground combat with deployable shields where i put the shields down in such a way that blocked my progress and it stuck me. no way forward no way out.
those kinds of things will make me put a game down pretty quick but that is the only one i found like that and its avoidable.

there are other bugs that muck up the gameplay too but i havent hit them.

Final word... I enjoy this game. i dont say that lightly. I find it engaging and entertaining. Making my ship designs and feeling like they are mine and they make a difference and have a unique kind of role makes me feel part of the game.

People say the AI is hard. i have not found that but i say thats good. I want a good AI. I dont want it to cheat. I want it to smartly kick my ♥♥♥.

edit.
the AI is not really all that good. it has an initial good economic model that will cause people looking to take it easy a hard time but once the player learns the game they will stomp the ai currently.

dev is still working on that.

game is still pretty fun though.

reviewText:
The game is very Masters of Orion-esc.  I have played stardrive and many many other 4x games.  Probably my favorite Genre.  Honestly i was on the fence about this one.  I didn't know if i wanted to spend the money and jump in, but after watching some lets plays, I had to try it.

The Good:
Stardrive ship customization. Probably the biggest thing here.  You can literally make any ship you want and make it work, Its based on these little squars blocks outlining your ships interior and its 4 quadrents.  Each quadrent having a different gun facing and its own hps.

The 4x-ness- spying, diplomacy, trading, combat. Multiply paths to victory.  Side missions and quest.  Which i might add can be harder than some of the AI players.

The fact that there is ground combat. So, This is also a negative but still the fact they they at least have something representing ground combat is good from the point of future development.

They game iteslf is Turnbased, but the combat is real time in an instanced battlefield.  I really like this!  One thing I didnt like about Stardrive 1 was that a battle would be really messy and meander all over the place. Some might like that, but for me having an actually formal engagement really made this fun for me. It also opens up battle arena that is also in the game.  So less persistant RTS and more Gratuitous space battles.

The look and asthetic is well done. Hard to believe they have such a small team working on it.



The bad:

Some things are half done or not fully fleshed out.  Ground combat needs a lot more love, but it is still enjoyable for me.

There are some bugs here and there that need fixing

Many racial weapons/tech/ship layouts are unbalanced or non existant.  I.e Kulrathi have their own melee weapon and defensive skill for ground combat, and they have tech that furthers this in the ???? tree for research. Pollops and Squids have it also, but races like human Vulfar chukk are kind of out in the cold.  Not to mention an optri cruiser has almost 2x the space to put modules on it than the vulfar.  I know that this is being looked at but for now its in the negative column as it directly effects the game in a big way.

The game to me seems more like a beta, but I am a purist that believe games are not launched until they are ready and polished.



Conclusion: ok so I would not have recommended this game when it launched, but in just a few days the developer released so many big changes in under a week that I had to take the plunge.  Sure, is it not finished and buggy. Yes, but I would rather have a game where the developer is constantly updating it to make it better than a ok game that gets and update every 6 months to a year.

reviewText:
StarDrive 2 is a refreshing game to the old 4X genre and I really would like to recommend and here are the reasons why.

The main reason, for not recommending it, is that I feel it is incomplete. Both in features and bugs. It is a shame though because the game is surprisingly well done. The UI is fluid and pleasant to look at (contrary to Galactic Civilizations 3). It has both tactical space and ground combat. It has beautifully rendered planets and the map is organised and does not become cluttered when you zoom out (again unlike Galactic Civilizations 3). But where it fails is in two areas.

The game is incomplete. The ground combat is woefully underdeveloped, diplomacy is not very well done, building starbases is almost useless (except getting command points) and it takes way too quick to max out research techs which makes the game almost feel like a rush-type 4X game. The tactical combat, although refreshingly good for a 4X game, is not balanced and the different weapons and defence system can range from really good to practically useless.

Then you have the lack of variety of ships where every race has only one ship model per tier.

And then ofcourse you have the bugs. The worse is probably when you invade a planet and sometimes you are in control of your enemies(!) units instead of yours. It is nothing that can't be fixed but still reduce the gameplay quite a lot.

That being said there are a lot of good things with the game. I already mentioned the good UI and tactical combat and how you fit your ships is really nice with a lot of cool weapons and utility modules. Sadly though that the rest of the game has so many problems because this is truly amazing game if you take into account the fact that it was developed by only one person.

That being said, I found it well worth the money because you can replay it quite a lot. So despite the lack of bugs and incomplete areas, it will still give you some fun for your money.

reviewText:
So here's my review (from someone that has put at least 100 hours into this game).

This is a good game... a very good game however be under no illusion of what you are getting. This is a game made on a shoe string budget by what seems to be a single guy. He releases regular patches to fix the things he has broken in previous patches. The graphics are not going to win any awards and the gameplay at the end gets a bit repetitive. With all those negatives, this is actually a really really good game. I would put this in a similar league to tetris when it first came out. It's one of those games that will eat away at your life as you play again and again. The sight of your intergalactic empire sending out fleets of ships to defend against an attacking race is exciting. Will my fleet make it to the planet before I lose it to an invasion, will my state of the art research win the technological arms race and allow me to turn the tide of battle? This game feels how i imagine it must feel to actually control an intergalactic empire.

Buy this game but be aware it is not without its faults.

reviewText:
Fair disclosure, I'm a alpha/beta tester of this game. Sunk a good 200 hours of time into this game throughout it's development cycle.

This game styles itself as a kind of spiritual successor to MoO2. It's a mix of turn based strategy with real time tactical combat. Because the game instances the fights, similar to Total War (But in space), the game is able to support hundreds of fleets, and thousands of ships in the same galaxy.

The main feature of this game is that, like in SD1, you design the ships you take into combat. There's a few pictures on the store page that depict it. You can design your ships to do whatever you want them to do in combat. You can load them down with fighter bays and kill your enemies with bug bites, artillery ships that stay far back and lob Gauss cannon rounds and torpedoes, short range anti-fighter ships with beam and flak weaponry, or ships that combine multiple features. By far, this is one of my favorite features of the game. There's nothing like designing your own fleets to send against your enemies.

The replayability is also great because of the customization options for your species, and because each species gets their own unique technologies. Both ground combat and space combat can be autoresolved based upon the relative strength of your forces VS the enemy's forces. This is helpful in the late game, when there are a lot of small skirmishes (Which I usually autoresolve) and a few huge battles (Which I command myself).

All in all, I think this is a wonderful 4x game. I'd suggest it to anyone who enjoys strategy/4x games, and for sure anyone who played and enjoyed MoO2.

reviewText:
StarDrive 2 review: comparison to Master of Orion 2.
The short of it:
This feels like an overhaul to Master of Orion 2. Slightly buggy, but I found it more fun than MOO2 (!!!).

The long of it:
Compared to the initial StarDrive, this game removes a lot of mechanics (real-time play, space battles integrated in the strategic/galaxy view, ability to research the whole tech-tree), making it less of a successor to SD1 and more of a spiritual successor to Master of Orion 2.
It plays almost the same way, with some added complexity (real-time space battles, ground battles, empire resupply range), while updating the UI to make the game play faster (sortable planet list, fewer clicks required to do most actions etc.).

I played MOO2 and SD2 side-by-side, and I had more fun with SD2, especially due to MOO2's ponderous interface. Also, SD2 has a bit more *oomph* during battles, better spy mechanics and more race options. So, I'll say that SD2 does almost everything the same as MOO2, some things better, and I'll just list the (potential) drawbacks:

- [edit: mostly fixed:] still slightly buggy, still slightly unbalanced, but stable and patched often.
- tactical space battles replaced with real-time batles. Faster games, more ships, but less control.
- ground combat is quite simple. Tactics, research, quests and individual equipment decisions make a huge difference, and this reactivity makes it fun.
- [edit: Fixed! Game is much less micro-intensive now:] no auto-build/governor. The game slows down in the later stages because of this big issue.
- no ship capture / scrap to get techs mechanic.
- some racial traits, technologies, ship modifications and mechanics missing"

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game? Yes, and no.

There are nine awesome races that all have an unique feel. But all these nine are not very well balanced. A race of robot bugs are the most op with a cruiser class ship with as much room as a battleship from other races while the wulfar has very limited space to work with.
I would prefer that you could choose a layout you wanted and a look you wanted. You can choose to play the wolves with the same traits as the Robot-bugs, but not the same ship. A bit weird.

The map generation is good, you can choose how many opponents, who these opponents will be and if you want random pirates attack. The size of the map can range all the way up to 100 stars, and each star can have up to four planets soo get ready for some exploration.

The early game runs really well and with a tech-tree where you only get to choose one of two or three really good upgrades you will feel that your decisions do matter. You'll get a few colonies up and running (more likely than not on barren ultra-poor high G planets but still) and you'll tech up some new fancy moduel like mass drivers for you ships. Now comes the fun part. Building the ships!

This is the reason i feel like you should buy this game, The shipbuilding is awesome. You need to carefully think if you really NEED that last cannon or if you should add an other layer of armour. You'll need to think how long this ship will be in battle, is 226 sec enough for a whole battle? Will you need more ammo?
I could spend hours in this part of the game.

The mid game starts when you have found the other races, some of them will want to trade with you, others will just want to take your hard earned stuff. Here the game falls flat. There is no point of being friendly to the others. There is no such thing as allies in StarDrive 2.
Even if the flower-plant-alien loves you to 100% you still have you still have to kill them to win.  If you are combat oriented however you'll do just fine.

Late game is weird. If you get here it's too late. One of the other races have half the galaxy and the number of ships in each battle are above 30 capital ships on each side. All with their own massive effects. The number of small ships can be over 60 + fighters(4/module and a ship could have 3-10 of these). It just gets too laggy to play and you'll find that you just want to peace out.

How ever, I do recommend this game. There are rumors on the forums that there soon will be a fix to diplomacy. And even just as it is now I cant help but too love it. Seeing your ships destroy 5 times as many as you have is rewarding. Ground combat is fun even if it's a little bare bones. Tending colonies are not the most fun but not the worst either. As for difficulty, the game is kinda easy when you get the hang of it.

Shipbuilding doe! There is no other game that does this as awesome as StarDrive. just oh my god. If you into customization give this game a try! (My english is not the best, thanks for the read anyway! )

reviewText:
It's good. It's very good. In my opinion it doesn't (yet) surpass the incredible MOO2 but it might be the best space 4X to come out since then. That said it is still something of a rough diamond and there is definitely room for improvement, fortunately the developer is generally responding to constructive criticism and I am hopeful that he will continue to refine the game.


The good -

The whole game oozes personality, ships look amazing, races are well designed and battles are really impressive.

There are some really nice innovations. Designing ships is great fun. Interactions with events and minor races are on the whole well implemented and the way these elements play out is both interesting and rewarding.

The diplomacy system - it's innovative and I really like it in principle. Although this is countered somewhat by the limited number of diplomatic interactions.

The basic game mechanics are a lot like MOO2 and that, for me at least, is a very good thing.

The space battles are a great spectacle and a lot of work has clearly gone into them. There are some weapon balance issues but these are already being looked at and patched.

It's generally stable, I have experienced no crashes so far and have encountered only one bug, which has already been fixed. As far as I can tell it's in a much better state than SD1 was on release.


The bad -

There's only one victory condition and it's via the total elimination of all opponents. I have some concerns that the need for complete eliminations will make the late game a boring grind, this is one of the biggest issues with 4X games in general and I am disappointed that SD2 has not addressed it, at least not yet.

There's no benchmarking mechanism to see how you compare to your opponents, there's not even a basic score counter. I realise this is personal taste, to an extent, but for me it is a significant issue and I hope to see it addressed soon.

The lack of fleet formations, you fleets turn up for battles in any old shape. This means you can either manually arrange every single ship before any battle or just don't bother, I found my approach quickly became the latter option, and that is irritating and immersion breaking.



On the whole the bad bits haven't (so far) detracted from my overall enjoyment of what is a fun game with huge potential. I would unquestionably recommend Stardrive 2 even as it is at present and if improvements continue to be made it could just be the true MOO2 successor that many people have been waiting nearly 20 years for.

reviewText:
Yes the game is buggy, those negative reports calling it out are not lying, some might be exagerating but from what I can see a developer is making progress fixing those up... wish it would be happening faster...

Having said that, the game is heavily inspired by the all time best 4x classic Master of Orion 2 and borrows a good amount of great ideas from the game while adding some reasonable improvements to the mix (not so much as to spoil and oversaturate a good design with garbage gameplay elements I should say).

My absolute favorite is free form fleet movement and removal of space lanes... always hated those and I am glad that I can send my fleet to any position in space, move around my fleet and approach a star system from another side of the star while avoiding that pesky npc fleet that does not let me get to it from the front.

As I said before everything else including the tech tree would be imediately familiar to anyone who played MoO2, and I like that. I want a decent remake of MoO2, and so far even the official reboot of the game did not make me feel so close to that old days one then this ameturish, low budget, tiny dev team project.

If you are not easily put of by the fact that the game needs alot more bug fixing and polish you might find this game a good throw back to MoO days.

reviewText:
First off I never played Stardrive 1. But I would rate this an above average 4x game.

Like Endless space planetary management with realtime space battles. Only con is the ground battles, which are noticable neglected.

Planet layout, and tech tree are simmilar to endless space. Space view has high detail, easy to manage. You can manage the individual buildings on a colony simmilar to Masters of Orion.

You can only reasearch one tech in three. This forces you to trade via diplomacy or steal with spies. A good game mechanic. Diplomacy is transparent and fair. Tooltips tell you all the bonuses, makes it easy to navigate alian diplomacy.

Real time space battles are very good. You send in your custom designed starships, and let em duke it out. Not much in the way of stratigy. Just who has bigger guns and more armor. Wide variety of webs makes it interesting. I'm alwase testing new ship designs.

Only con I have is that ground battles suck. The graphics are very poor in this section. Your troops are put on a chess board, and attack a few times per turn. Really boring. If it wasn't so crusial to defending my planets.  I would never use it.

Overall 8/10. Probbably the best 4x game out right now. But that isn't saying much. The genere has been neglected for a long time. And with no major titles we are left with this. Good could be bettere. (Improve ground battles or remove them.!!)

reviewText:
The long and short of it is that this is the Space 4x we've been waiting for for 20 years. Were you disappointed in games like Endless Space, Horizon or Galactic Civilizations, games that ALMOST delivered what they promised but fell short in key areas? This game is for you. Taking cues from Master of Orion, and building on the first installment, this game feels like it hit a nearly perfect storm.

The planet management is deep, but not overly complex, the tech trees are interesting, exploration system is finely tuned, and the combat is a blast. Space combat is visceral and fun. Ground combat is a little bare bones, but deeper than it appears on the surface, and very difficult and satisfying.

There are many approaches to situations, and the dynamics between you and the rest of the galaxy is interesting and fun.

It isn't the perfect Space 4X, but that game hasn't been made yet. This is the best one made in modern times. Pick it up if you are a fan of the genre or have been sitting around since Master of Orion 2 wondering why someone couldn't do better in 20 damned years. Is it better than MOO2? I don't know, but it's a damned fine game.

Highly recommended, this game is a blast and a half.

reviewText:
(edit) After more play, I have changed my review to thumbs down. We are to version 1.0h, and none of the bugs mentioned below have been addressed. Meanwhile the developer has plans to release a named patch with new features while balance issues still exist. This misplaced sense of priorities makes me think the game will never be balanced, or patched, correctly.

The good: It's an addictive 4X game that steals a lot from MOO 2. Many of the tech are taken directly from MOO 2 and choosing one topic locks you out of other choices, just like MOO 2, forcing you to use diplomacy to acquire them. It's a pretty game overall. The switch to turn based play for the galaxy map is a good one. The real time ship battles look great. It has that one more turn feeling. This is Moo 2 brought up to date. That should be good, right?

The bad: Here are just some examples to give you an idea of what I'm complaining about.

Ship design: it's a fiddly process. The game doesn't remember your previous choices in terms of size and quality of your components, forcing extra clicks as you fine tune your design. Also I have had the game simply refuse to save designs I've spent 10 minutes making, losing my work. Speaking of losing my work, the game will erase your work if you click a new hull. There is no 'mirror mode' that would allow you to quickly apply armor to 2 sides of a ship.

The game's soundscape is poor. Some sounds are simply not mixed correctly. The game released with serious balance issues in terms of the different difficulty levels. This has been addressed somewhat in a patch, but still needs work. When being attacked, you can't see the components the enemy ships have. Listening posts and refueling stations have the same icon on the galaxy map, making it impossible to tell which is which at a glance. At the moment, listening posts are bugged and acting like refueling stations. When one of your planets lacks something to build, the on screen notification of that is ridiculously tiny and tucked in the bottom right, making it easy to miss.

I hope this gives you an idea of the general state of the game. There are bugs, and there are things that are either just plain wrong, or clunky, when managing your empire. As I said above, the deveoper seems to be more interested in 'building buzz' by releasing a 'superpatch' than polishing his game.

reviewText:
Steam absolutely needs a middle ground between yes and no reccomendations. Everything is here to make a great game, but it just isn't implemented correctly.
Rather than say what I do like, I'm going to tell you what will turn you off from playing once the new game smell has dissappated. The AI just rolls in and mucks about creating all sorts of annoyances.  These aren't annoying because they are challenging, it is because it feels cheap.
I absolutely do not enjoy the systems in place for taking over planets.
More systems need to be put in place to respect the players time.  My biggest annoyances with any 4x are always late game empire management.  The game does not notify you when a planet isn't working on anything.  There are many very simple yet highly needed UI elements that just sap the enjoyment from the game.
So I would say that if you are interested in this game, wait for updates.

reviewText:
I propose to not buying this game, because there are so many annoying bugs.
It never crashes, but very often (at least after *each* fight) you have to wait 1-2 Minutes until you can continue playing. At the moment, I own about 10% of the Universe, but after an usual fight I have to wait 68 seconds until the (mandatory) fight statistics are displayed. After confirming those annoying statistics (they are interesting only the 1st 5 times), the game requires again about 30 seconds to load.

Its really annoying that after 1/10 of the game play time it's almost imposible to play the game if you do not just want to ... wait. wait. wait. ... wait.

It's really annoying: there is a cool, big tech tree - but no precise descriptions, so that one has to start reverse engineering and try to find the differences.

Additionally, one can not research items on the same level.
This way I'm playing long time and suddendly I see that I made a wrong researching decision and so I have to hope I can get the missing item on another way. Or once more to realod an old game.

It's really annoying that the tech tree does not list numbers and facts
and that my engineers forget how to research another item on ab already researched level .

reviewText:
Finally a successor to MOO2! Plays very much like MOO2, same planet management etc and fixes the flaws of SD1 (i.e it's turn-based now). The combat is actually better than the turn-based combat of MOO2, though I was skeptical at first. It's fast enough to be enjoyable, but slow enough that you can give orders to your ships, or just watch how your new designs perform.

Research screen is a bit boring but the advances are nice. Some are identical to MOO advances.

I like the alien races, though the music doesn't match the MOO diplomacy music. But what does?

Ship design screen is simple enough to be intuitive, but complex enough that you can design ships to your requirements.

10/10.

reviewText:
I see a lot of negitive reviews on here because the game is hard.

This is not a hard game. The AI also DOES NOT CHEAT. It will unsettle most of your 4x game habits. You will not get 50-100 turns of peace to quietly build resources & infastructure and expand to your hearts content. You have to prepare for an attack immediately. It may not come, but it most likely will.

It is different than most 4x in that your in danger from turn one. I start every turn with the question, can i fend off an enemy fleet this turn if a wormhole opens up on my homeworld. If i answer no, then build ships. This game heavily rewards players garrisoning units (half command points and no maintanance).

The AI is AMAZING! Any game you have ever played where the AI decision making could be exploited and you thought to yourself, I shouldn't be able to do this. The AI is actually very cunning. It will wait for you to launch attacks outside of your teritory, so your ships are low on fuel and have trouble returning to defend. It will steal from you, it will backstab you.

There is no science victory, there is no diplomatic victory. You have one goal, domination. You can turtle, but only to counter attack. Yeah, expect the AI to have garrisons.

I highly recommend this game. You will have to practice at it to get better. The in game tutorial is excellent. The tooltips are excellent. Do not give up on the game if you start losing. Start another game and instead of building that nice to have thing that gives +1 to whatever, build a ship. =)

reviewText:
What a fantastic game StarDrive 2 is.

It's a nice twist on the 4X genre, with the addition of a Shipyard, allowing the player to fully customise the ships in their fleet.

Combined with Turn Based Combat Lite as I call it for both ground combat and ship boarding, this is a fully featured 4X strategy game, and the discount for owning the original game (-33%) is a welcome touch also.

For £15.40 or £22.99 if you don't own StarDrive 1, this game is well worth your time and money. :)

reviewText:
Played a few months ago and did not keep up with changelogs, so some impressions may be outdated.

At first i was excited to find a game similar to Master of Orion that makes use of more recent technology and delivers real time ship battle. Until midgame, StarDrive 2 is allright.

In later stages, ship battle turns to fleet battle and performed terribly for me on i5 @3.6GHz which i really didnt expect.

Generally the idea is really great, and i do acknowledge that this game is written by a singular dev iirc.
After having played for a few hours and having explored the tech and AI behaviour,  unfortunately i would say this title lacks the brilliance and entertainment i expected, as opponents feel hollow and monotoneous.

- Ground Combat control feels unrefined and gets boring rather fast.
- Interface is faulty and sometimes not clickable
- FPS drops to slideshow in real time fleet battle and skipping to result with diverging outcomes ruined the motivation to keep a positive attitude towards a great idea of this game.


Alltogether i appreciate this attempt at rebooting great titles like moo2 and galciv, but i can not shake a strong feeling of scepticism about the intentions behind the design and quality of product and thus would advice to wait for further completion or developement before buying it.

reviewText: I would love to recommend this game. It has a lot of promise, but it is simply too unpolished to be considered great or even good. Every game basically starts the same, Same unoriginal encounters, same spawn problems. Even choosing the largest possible map (100 systems) the game always seems to spawn all the races right on top of each other. Meaning that normal 4x expansion and exploration is severely limited as you are effectively boxed in from the start. Ground combat is a joke. It is nearly impossible to defeat the bear race on the ground, they will walk over any garrison you build no matter what tech you have. Other races will often make unreasonable demands, even if you are friendly or allied with them. The Opteris, for example, demanded several of my worlds in order to not declare war on me, even though we were allies at the time. I've also had races declare war on me only a few turns after meeting me. It doesn't seem that the faction relations (good, bad, hostile, whatever) have any bearing on how that race reacts to you. The game does have a decent shipyard though, allowing you to customize any ship with upgrades and new tech to your hearts desire. With time and work put in, the game could be great, but at this time, even after patches, it is still lacking.\n

reviewText:
20 hours in I think i've finally seen enough of this massive game to write an informed review!

I'm not going to address the unfinished state of SD1, plenty has been said about that and all I WILL say is that if you purchased SD1 I believe the discounted $20 asking price for this follow-up is a very good deal for what you get; It's up to you whether or not that redeems Zero for your perceived loss on the first game.

StarDrive 2 is Space 4X that has a lot in common with the Masters of Orion franchise but many, many more layers of complexity and an irreverant tone with a lot of references to other science fiction; It's not very serious and I appreciate that given how complicated everything gets.

If you have any interest in the 4x genre I don't think you can go wrong here with the caveat that it can seem poorly designed and weighted towards the AI in some areas UNTIL you really understand how to play, at which all will be forgiven and you'll be hooked; It has a vicious learning curve in spite of a pretty well done tutorial and you've given an enormous amount of freedom to shoot yourself in the foot right from word go.

To break it out into the different game layers at work:

You design the physical layout of all your ships using whatever parts you've researched. In combat if a round hits your left flank and that's where you decided to cram a bunch of unshielded nuke reactors you can kiss your butt goodbye. Try a bit more armor next time. To supplement the AI's ability in this area they will occasionally use templates you made for their race when you play against them so beware. This sytem is slightly simpler than in SD1 but I think that's all to the good, having to lay wiring was kind of dumb in my opinion.

You move these ships between star systems and engage in RTS fleet combat that often looks a lot like Gratuitous Space Battles." It's great
date: it runs better than in SD1
recommended: and there's a lot of strategy involved as before. My only complaint on this front is that click and drag selection is a little fiddly and you can't always tell a group of the same ships to use their ability simultaneously. You may think that your ships are being unresponsive but it's probably that someone scrapped your engine with a well placed shot or took out your power supply!\n\nPlanets have a mapped out surface where you place buildings and any planetary invasion or boarding action turns into turn-based infantry combat that looks like a less developed X-COM. Sadly
hoursPlayed: this is the weakest element of the game at the moment because planetary invasions play out on a flat open grid with no obstacles and you have vision of everyone the whole time. In my opinion that sort of takes all the charm out of the X-COM model and I hope we get more varied maps and fog of war in the future. It's servicable though
voteText:
and if you want you can avoid it by bombarding planets from orbit or auto-resolving the battles.

Diplomacy is pretty cool and a big improvement from the first game. Any item that can be traded or negotiated for has a numerical "trade value." You can attempt to trade anything for anything (colonies for techs for trade rights for an exchange of citizens) but there is a "tolerance" stat that puts a hard cap on how much you or the AI is willing to give up. It's dictated by racial stats like whether your trade partner is a repulsive insect monster and also by past dealings.

Spying is simplified from the first game and works a lot like Civ V or BE spying -- you can have defensive spies or deploy spies to enemy sectors. Not a lot to say about it really
helpfulPercent: functional but uninteresting.\n\nThe tech tree is VERY Masters of Orion (two thumbs up!) You get to pick one of three techs on each tier of a discipline
votesHelpful: leaving the others behind. The only way to acquire those extra two techs is to trade for them
votesTotal: steal them with spies
votesFunny: or assimilate them when you conquer another race. It means races develop very differently and I prefer it to the "eventually learn everything" approach of Civilization.\n\nCitizens are juggled between farming
commentsCount: industrial production
column16: and research on each planet and you can ferry them around to populate your new colonies; This is accomplished with freighters
column17: which are also your trade ships. Like trade caravans in Civilization V or BE they're vulnerable and their routes need to be protected.\n\nLastly there's a mission system at play here. Some missions are to do with the "Hero characters" you can pick up who have different traits and can be used in combat or to govern your colonies. They vary wildly from each other which is pretty cool
column18:
the whole thing is well done. These hero characters are not invincible and you have to be very careful ferrying them around or running them into combat. Other missions will be random occurences or show up as anomalies on the strategic map that you go check out. Sometimes non-faction NPCs will spawn to harass you and there are also space creatures lying in wait to ruin your day.

If any of this sounds interesting pull the trigger and be prepared to die a couple of times learning the ropes! There are quite a few more mechanics I didn't get to but this turned into a wall of text already so i'll spare you any more. If none of the above grabbed you I really don't think this is your genre because this is a fine example and very impressive for such a small studio.

PS: Fuel demand driving you crazy? BUILD TANKER SHIPS FOR YOUR FLEET! Fuel is shared between all the ships in your fleet so there's no need to cram it into every vessel. Just make sure that you warp those tankers out of harm's way when a battle kicks off or you're gonna have a bad time."

reviewText:
I currently have logged over 24 hours in game time and felt the need to express my opinion about Stardrive 2. My time with Stardrive 2 has been very up and very down.

Let's start with the up's. First the price of the game is competitive with other indi games. Second the races are fairly balanced. Third the tech tree that forces you to skip a particular tech but later aquire it through trade is a fantastic idea, forcing you to expand your playstyle into areas you might not have chosen with diplomacy mattering. Fourth is designing ships. Seeing a ship that you custom built wreck the universe is one of the best parts of the game. Last is having the ship battles being free moving and not on a grid. Gridded ship battles would have been so much easier to create but free moving ships that can dodge with a proper timed burst of speed or be swarmed with smaller ships is the best.

Now the worst. Bad starting systems can spell doom on turn one. Having a hero buff three even four planets can be such a huge boost to playability that getting stuck with only one hurts bad. Next is wormholes. Wormholes often give a direct perment route to your home solar system which spells doom for the player as the AI seems to cheat with ship building production. Also on the topic of wormholes a mysterious race will nonstop attack you with much more advanced ships when you least can afford to be attacked from special random wormholes. Most of my playtime was spent turtling due to wormholes. Kind of kills the explore part of 4X. Special research is avaliable but has to be turned on and off with a slider by the user and isn't explained very well. Hell sliders don't work well at all due to zero percise control of the numaric imput. Ships need a testing ground because important battles have been lost because a ship did not function as I believed it would. DO NOT USE MISSLES. Take my word for it. Last is the stability/loading issues. I did have a few nothing a autosave load didn't fix but after patch 1 I cannot load a campaign more than 33% rendering that mode useless. Deleted the game and redownloaded but same issue. I guess I will wait for patch 2.

At the moment I feel very torn about the game. It is very much a 4x game but with amazing RTS portions that make it very fun to play but the speed you make contact with hostile AI combined with often lack luster starts can force rerolls untill a viable start can be had. That paired with the INABILITY TO PLAY THE GAME makes it where I cannot recommend the game to anyone who is reading this. Maybe in a month when it has been properly patched but that is another review.

reviewText: I'm old... almost 40 ;) and I have seen the birth of Master of Orion I and all succeeding 4X games. Many of them were playable, some were even good, but in 1996, Master of Orion II came out and set the standard for a very long time ... until now! In my opinion, Zero made an update and enhancemend to Master of Orion II! Many tried to, no one succeeded. But Stardrive II will be the historical landmark after 18 years to be the No. 1 in 4X strategies! Yes, the game is not easy. I've never played such a challenging 4X game in 25 years, which was in a playable condition at the same time. They've brought out a finished product at release. That is unfortunately not common since developers can easily patch via Internet. The game needs some tweaks and a bit further development to reflect the issues raised in the feedbacks, like more victory conditions. But the new patch looks very promision and I am convinced, it will soon have reached the polished status, which makes Stardrives the all time No.1 in the 4X genre. They've already reached 95% of the way! In my opinion, they've already written 4X game history!

reviewText:
I've put over 100 hours into this game, and will continue to do so.

In a nutshell - this is a delightful, modern take on the classic Master of Orion series (1 and 2). If you enjoyed MoO, then you will enjoy this.

The Good:

-Fun, silly nerd humor with excellent art
-An involved, intuitive, and complex ship building process as complicated as you want (use the defaults or plan every square)
-Defined tech trees and economy
-Customization of everything, from races to game modes
-Fast and fluid gameplay

The Bad:

-Some bugs here and there. The Developer (one guy named Zero) will fix the issues if you clearly identify what the problem is.
-Diplomacy and Spying could use a rework

The Ugly:

-For some reason, Zero (and Stardrive) has attracted some less than positive" community members. I don't really understand it...SD 1 and 2 are very fun
date:
very modestly priced games.

...

Conclusion - I highly recommend this game for all 4X fans."

reviewText:
First: I own Stardrive. But this is about Stardrive 2. This game is very good. Period. As an old 4x gamer I can say this for sure. Haters gonna hate.
Now the review:
I've tried almost every 4x game published during the time between MOO2 and Stardrive2. I've been waiting for too many years for this. Almost every game I tried had some things attractive and were lacking in other areas. Never found one 4x space game that fullfilled my expectatives. There was always something.
I admit, for me the canon is MOO2 and I must say Stardrive 2 is the closest game to it that I found during years. You can notice in everything around the game. The races, the research, the design, freighters... etc etc. One special mention for the ability to move the colonists around. I was showing the game to a friend and he almost cried when he saw it ;)
But Stardrive 2 has its own potentialities: RTS Ship Combat, complex ship design, TBS Land combat, the humour, surprises... you have to play it to feel. And of course and not less important a polished and beautiful UI and solid and very good graphics.
If you like 4x space genre, you must own this game. Its the best by far in years.
When I think that this game its basically the work of one man, as a coder myself I only can think wow! Thanks Zero.

reviewText:
Excellent addition to any 4 x library.

This game came out of the gates deciding not to reinvent the wheel but instead enhance a lot of typical 4 x gameplay options.

It feels like the developer has taken many of the best attributes of many 4 x games, added them all together and  then streamlined the process. There are so many interesting aspects of this game. Galactic empire building. Space combat. Diplomacy. And an xcom style ground combat.

The custom ship builder is the best in any 4 x space game I've played and the AI offers a true challenge without being given an unfair bonus.
This is a challenging game so expect to lose and have to adapt your strategy.

That being said, SD2 isn't a perfect game. Having only one victory condition (military  victory) means that you will be going to war early and often. Being beside an aggressive neighbor can be difficult and require you to figure out ways to avoid an early war.

Random events in the game are a lot of fun and interesting. But if your unlucky, can cripple a great starting in this game. A wormhole next to your home system that leads to an aggressive race , when your not ready, can make for a quick defeat.

Small frustrations aside , this is a great game.
Don't let any negative reviews or outspoken forum members sway you from taking a serious look at SD2.

One plus SD2 has over any other space 4 x game is it's sly humour. There are many fun and interesting references to nearly every sci fi movie, show and book riddled in the game. It doesn't take itself to seriously and just pokes fun at every stereotype the genre has to offer.
This isn't a selling point for some people but it's a great addition that breaks up the raw , tense gameplay from time to time.

Watch some lets plays, read some reviews and base your decision on that.
It's an excellent addition to any 4 x fans library.
voteText: 23 of 42 people (55%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I've enjoyed this game a lot and recomend it to any 4X fans. You will get your money out of it. Compared to other 4X titles currently out, this game's strength is space battles and its connectivity to ship design.

My thoughts on the different aspects of the game and how it compares to other titles:
Space Battles: Graphics are good and you don't just watch.
Ship Design:  Not overly complicated, but not simplified to much. Focuses on ship components/weapons and not the apperance of your ship. Weapons have a facing and it matters which arc you place them in.
Ground Combat: Not on par with the quality of the rest of the game. Only enjoyed playing it 2-3 times, but auto resolve is absurd (Based only on total HP), so you have to keep playing it. The upcoming DLC should have a solution to this.
Troop Design: You get to choose what your troops are equiped with.
Colony Managment: Empire management screen is easy to use
Colony Development: Not as enjoyable/detailed as GalCiv3, but more detailed than Endless Space or Distant Worlds.
Exploration/Colonization Phase: Smaller galaxy size than most of the recent 4X. Less to explore, but smooth and quick turns. You can mod this, but I didn't find a larger galaxy more fun to play for this game (unlike GalCiv3 and Distant Worlds!).
Research System: Different. Forces you to choose 1 of 3 options and you don't get the other 2 techs unless you steal or trade for them.
Diplomacy: There are no long term allies. If you work hard you can make friends for a few turns. Most relations will be neutral. Eventually, you will fight everyone.
Victory conditions: Domination by eliminating everyone else. No diplomacy or tech victory. This is fine with me as the best part of this game is the battles.

Pros:
-Ability to conrtol your ships in combat.
-Empire management screen is easy to use
-Designing ships is great.
Cons
-There are bugs, but they are not as bad as other reviews make them out to be. I've only encountered game breaking bugs twice (In my experiance I've encountered more game breaking bugs in Star Wars Battle Front, CoD: Black Ops III, and Galactic Civilizations 3).
-Ground combat as addressed above

reviewText: StarDrive 2 is not by any means, a bad game. That being said, it is incredibly small for a 4x game. After one short play through you will have experienced all the random events and found all the strange anomalys. It's ship designers is a direct downgrade from StarDrive 1, which is a real shame considering that was one of it's best features. The AI isn't horrible, but it also does not act naturally or organically by any means. It will provide a challenge, never researching the wrong tech or mishandling it's economy. The ground combat is a direct improvement over the first game's, with chess-like turn-based battles that are satisfying but easy to win once you know what gear to use and have one of the few heroes who mop the floor with ground based units. The game doesn't take itself seriously enough, with the dialogue of your enemies simply being silly and somewhat childish, which is a unique twist when it comes to the genre but in my opinion not a good choice. Rather than introducing a universe and advanced species with a lot of lore and depth, we get plant like creatures who act cute and cuddly, space bears who act like japanese samurai, and space lycans who act like dumb evil dogs who miracuously managed to get into space. The space battles, although in theory would be fun, are unplayable without a CPU with the minimum power of 3.5 GHz quad-core (even then you will lag with the largest battles) once the AI creates fleets which numbers are in the hundreds, all firing 20 projectiles a second. Late game, this issue renders the game unplayable for a lot of those who have purchased the game, including myself. This is the game breaking issue for me, because although the base game is somewhat underwheling in comparison to other 4x games, if I were able to play into the late game without lagging to death I could add some pretty great mods to turn this into a game I put a bunch of hours into, as well as continue my support for the developer. So overall, the game isn't terrible, but I would not recommend paying more than $15 for it, and that is only if you are really itching for a new 4x game.

reviewText: This game is basically what happens if Master of Orion II and Galactic Civilizations had a baby. If you felt that GalCiv was boring or you want a more modern MOOII, then this is the game for you. So this is the work on one guy, whichis super impressive given the size and scope of the game. Not even the new Master of Orion is as ambitious. Sadly this leads to a major problem. Unfortunately even with the latest patches and DLC, it's still buggy.  It's very playable, but there are still bad bugs like if you destroy a civilization before destroying all of their starbases, then you can't destroy them afterward since It requires you to declare war" on the non-existent civ. Teams have a hard enough time getting stuff shipped and working
date: I can only imagine what it's like for a single programmer who outsources the graphical work. Testing must be a nightmare given the games's complexity. Still if you can look past bugs that appear once every 8 or so hours

reviewText:
I happen to think, now that the Sector Zero DLC is out, that StarDrive 2 is the best space 4X since Master of Orion 2... and it takes A LOT of design cues from that all-time classic.  The tile-based ship design is particularly interesting and I actually like the research system that many people seem to be complaining about.  Rather than being able to research everything in the game you have to choose between one tech for each level of a particular scentific discipline.  It helps differentiate individual empires during a game and gives the player some decisions that can radically alter each playthrough by picking a different technology in the early game.  Perhaps you would rather have each farmer produce an extra 2 food on farmable planets rather than being able to place an airponics(air-grown plants) facility on any planet, including those planets who can't normally be farmed which produces a flat 5 food per turn.  The improved farming technique would add up quite fast, but airponics would make colonizing more hostile planet-types easier...  without airponics they cannot produce food at all which means any potential colonists must import food via freighters.

What can I say, I am an absolute sucker for games that force you to make substantial decisions rather than just providing the illusion of making serious decisions.  If you can unlock everything via research then every game will look almost the same, and there is a reason I never could get into games like StarCraft 2 where there seem to be single optimal strategies and deviation or slow fingers means certain doom.
:SidMeiersAcePatrolMissionLeader:
voteText: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is exactly what I was looking for, it hits all the right elements for a deep strategy turn based 4X game.  I am extremely pleased with it's depth (the tech tree is HUGE!), the various races and flavor text are engaging and often a bit humourous, and I have no doubt it will have a ton of replayability as a result.  It's possible this game was once a bit buggy based on older reviews, but I can happily report that as of yet I have encountered no bugs at all, zero!  This is the game that Endless Space should have been (but was too buggy to ever work right).  The only thing lacking at the moment is more modding in the workshop.  This game could potentially have a very long life with additional DLCs and more modding options, but even in it's current state it offers incridible depth and is extremely satisfying to play once you understand it's nuances.  If you are at all fruustrated starting out, just go watch a Let's Play video or two on YouTube and it will quickly allow you to understand the game dynamics so you can dive in and have a blast.  This game is worth it at full price and an absolute must purchase if you can ever see it on sale!

reviewText: After watching a couple of gameplay videos that came out after the Sector Zero DLC was released I finally decided to give this game a try when both items were on sale (pretty much the same as when I go watch a movie I already know I won't enjoy so much, but don't mind the price of the ticket thinking I'd rather be busy for the duration than the alternative). Just like Stardrive 1, I saw the potential of some of the features of this 2nd game, although in the same fashion I was almost always disappointed by their implementation, feeling like the developper sometimes did not even realize how good his own ideas could have been if just a bit more passion had been put into polishing those specific features.\n\nThere is - or there was? - a potentially very good game again in SD2 (as it could have been in SD1) but once more the fact the game is crippled by a sheer amount of bugs, a clunky UI lacking ergonomy, and that overall many of the features lack that little something" that would have made them awesome. Also
date: while there are difficulty levels and several options to activate or not it is pretty clear there is a balancing issue (try playing brutal x4 without deactivating the attack events and you'll most likely get crushed by a master remnant fleet around turn 100 or something (6 shielded mid size ships using disabling EMP attacks and having very decent firepower)
recommended: and if you miraculously manage to beat that fleet
hoursPlayed: good luck with catching up with the AI empires after focusing on building your military till that point in game).\n\nWhile tons of references to "geek culture" in sci-fi/fantasy fields can be found in the flavor text

reviewText:
At first this game seems like a realy good 4x game; Diplomacy is ok, Fleet Combat looks nice, General UI seems to be ok but:Ground Warfare is bad realy bad, if you want to gather a Reasonable Ground Army you have a realy Boring gaming session coming right to you: You have to Equip every single Unit manually and you need a lot of them, You have to play through Ground Combat manually cause automatic Attack gives realy bad results. This wouldn`t be as bad if the Ground Combat itself would be fun. the Ground Combat is Round based and you have 2-5 Actions per Unit (or a long move) per Turn and you have to issue every action manually...
This takes Ages and is a huge backstep to the Real time Fleet Battles.
There are other options though: You can Nuke a planet back to Stoneage or not Waging ground wars. You have the choice of bad results for your Empire or A realy boring game.

The Annoying Thing is imho that everything else is quite good... but when you are at the Point of the Game where you have to expand via Ground wars the Game gets awful.

reviewText: Not sure if I'm the only person with this problem, but I thought I'd ease myself into the game by starting on easy with one enemy and was completely overwhelmed by the amount of ships they seem to be able to create. At first I thought I had simply misclicked on the difficulty as the first enemy fleet I was attacked by almost completely took up the screen. As I watched absolutely ridicilously large fleets with troop transports destroy my empire one by one the only thing i could think was ( dang, this is easy? Hate to see the other difficulties.) I'm not sure if it's some kind of A.I. bug or just how the game plays. I can't seem to ever amass even half the fleet that my enemy does ( in a very short while I might add). I'm just going to chalk it up to the learning curve being extremely difficult. Ooh well, for those incredibely hardcore RTS fans, this is your golden ticket, as for me I'll just stick to playing the first one.

reviewText:
Got quite some time with this game down now. I still miss some parts which I thought were great in SD1, like Station design. But all in all it is a good and fun game, one of the most enjoyable 4X games.
Sadly the DLC brought quite a few bugs with it, some even hangup the game.... which means lost turns, revert to last save etc.
Though Zero is hard working on fixing them, already got the second patch... or was it the third? :D

Personally I find the pricing of the DLC totally okay, I mean with GalCiv3 they charge 5€ for a Planet pack...
Some more new modules would have been nice, but the groundbattles got a overhaul, we got a sector system with deep space stations, new related techs.

Dont forget he´s one guy working on this. So it takes more time working on stuff.
If you want to buy the DLC only if it is bugfree, wait for a few days or weeks.

All in all it is one of the top 3 4X games on my personal list.

reviewText:
I brought the DLC and it's an vast improvement for StarDrive 2. I'm very happy with the way he has set it up. I actually like the hexagon style gameplay and the game has been more streamlined. For example:

1. Ship Design - it is a ton easier to design a warship and not have to worry about the secondary systems or having to line up everything perfectly. Hours could be spent in here but thanks to the streamlined process, I can design the parts I want to mess around with and let the behind-the-scene" nerdy people figure out how to power it and etc. Excellent improvement.

2. Freighter - this entire process has been automated and I'm vastly relieved as this was too much micro-managing. The AI now does it for you
date: provided you build enough feighter ships to transport the necessary items to the colonies.\n\n3. AI - the AI has been vastly imporved and I LOVE LOVE LOVE having to deal with pirates
hoursPlayed: and etc. This keeps me on my toe and I can't just send all of my fleets of warships to the border but actually have to watch within the terroritory and intercept any troublesome pirates/space monsters and so fourth. Just a fantastic addition to my gameplay\n\n4. Colony Management - this has been streamlined by a huge margin. I do not have to try to micromanage each colony but I can still set a theme of what I woud like the "AI Governor" to follow in building up the colony

reviewText:
If you have not played StarDrive 1 this is a good 4x to pick up. It's fairly easy to start as the creator has a fully voiced tutorial and the game is a little less complex than it's predecessor (be warned if you jump around menu to menu while in a tutorial the tutorial will end and leave you helpless). If you have played the last StarDrive and really wanted this to be a good game, I have bad news and good news. Good news the game isn't broken like the last one and playing for several hours (as I normally do) caused no framedrop or resources hoging. Bad news the game is now a turn based strategy instead of one big realtime. This may not be a bad thing for all of you but it's something to consider, because it is a turn based strategy fleet battles now occur on a different screen. This once again is not really bad but the strategies you can use are limited since you always start on opposing sides and pretty much just clash in the middle every time. The ground combat is dull and managing your foot soldiers is a pain. This combat pops up often and it is rather dull with very little strategy besides shoot the things and not get shot by the things. Certain ground enemies are also really hard to kill for arbitrary reasons and will often cost you a well equiped group of soldiers. Talking about equiping soldiers it's impossible. Soldiers spawn with random gear and more likely than not the worst gear you have. There doesn't seem to be a way to say how many of each soldier you want or to even to limit their selection of items to make sure they spawn with more than a combat knife.

All this said I have had a lot of fun with the game. Ship building is what I spend most of my time on but I just wish a few more QOL things were in the ship builder like the health and shields of the ship. Managing your empire is simplified with one screen that shows you ever planet you have, what they are building, worker allocation, and so on and so forth. Tech is kept interesting with multiple routes that you can take. If you take one tech you lose the others and are sort of herded toward using diplomacy to gain the ones you missed or the spying system. Subterfuge is rather simple but does the job with multiple missions that your agents can be sent on.

I give this game a thumbs up and I think anyone who enjoys the one more turn mindset of Civ 5 will have a blast wtih this game.
voteText: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: After playing StarDrive 1, I looked forward to getting this sequel as soon as it was announced. SD2 is turn-based on the strategic level while combat is controlled in real-time. SD2 retained much of the character and customizability that enthralled me in the first game. I purchased GalCiv 3 and stopped playing it soon after buying it - not because it was a terrible game but because SD2 was better in all the ways that mattered me. This game contains a good number of quests, special galactic and world events, randomly forming wormholes (short-cuts into unexplored and enemy territories) and more that work to keep the game interesting. After putting over 100 hours into it, I can say I don't regret my decision. My biggest gripe: ground combat. I auto-fight those battles. Apart from that, I recommend this game for anyone who is interested in 4x games.

reviewText: I really wanted to hate this game. I'm a die-hard fan of StarDrive 1, even though it had its quirks and flaws.. I dumped more time than I care to admit into that game. I waited a day or two after release to see how the game fared, because I was a bit apprehensive of all the new changes. Mostly, I thought the transition to turn-based and instanced combat was neat and a cool way to go, but I felt the ship design was severely lacking in comparison to the first game.\n\nIt is certainly a little less complex than in StarDrive 1, but I couldn't bring myself to dislike it. The ship combat just works out to be so much more fun. The small simplification in ship design has actually served to enhance the whole experience, and makes designing ships take a little more nuanced approach. Ship combat now feels a lot more massive (slow motion" is awesome and feels more like "cinematic speed"
