reviewText:
Lots of people saying this game is too hard, hasn't been my experience (on normal)  and most of the reviews with that tagline seem to have missed the patch which made easy easier.

Pros: Beautiful and fun space battles, and smooth and quick strategic turns, simply no other 4x I've ever played has transitioned from turn to turn so well - its a joy to hit the end turn button. Good atmoshpere, and a nice mix of aliens and plenty of customision to make your own distinct faction out of them, and a solid tech-tree that manages to create replayability without forcing random chance (often hard luck - looking at you SOTS).
Cons: Land combat is a little meh, and on some planets its hard to see where you can move/attack, but honestly this is an extra...

Good game. Do buy.

reviewText:
I was charmed at first but after a few hours the flaws become really annoying.

1. Diplomacy means nothing. Its more of a hunger-games type of AI, it will leave you alone if theres somebody else to kill but as soon as one war is finished it will declare war on you even if you just had multiple good trades and a solid history of friendship with a race.
2. AI is ridiculously overpowered. I need to play on easy with a galaxy rich in everything to make up for it, otherwise at some point you get zerged by the AI with its infinite fleet.
3. Your population feels more like chess pawns more than anything. Whatever your approval rating is, i have yet to see a revolt. They dont really seem to have expectations, aspirations, your victories or defeat dont seem to affect them at all.
4. Ground battles needs work. They arent really fun.
5. The only way to know who owns what seems to be with colors. Can we have a little text saying the planet is owned by x race?
6. You can have a large empire but only 4 leaders. When you play on large galaxy its not a alot. A system where each star system automatically have a governor with bonus/malus would be a nice addidtion, and replacing the governor could have some kind of impact.


Overall its not a bad game, but it needs work to win my recommendation.
voteText: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Awesome game for the most part.  Galaxies could be a bit bigger, then again Im a fan of HUGE galaxies and prolonged games.  The only thing lacking is the multiplayer aspect of the game.  Have quite a few friends that have been looking for an alternative to the aging Sword of the Stars (SoTS II was awful) and something that was a bit more fast paced since we are the generation thats having new families now and time to play with eachother is almost an uncommon luxury.
I would give this game 3.5/5 stars based upon a broken down review:


+2 Star for Graphics:  Excelled table top down graphics, a classic if your looking for the pew pew in the battle of pew pew.   And doesnt require an overkill computer for that.
+1.5 Star for Gameplay:  Its a 4X, need I say more?
+1 Star for Just sheer worthy of a buy that has yet to sit rotting in my steam library.
+.5 For Game implementation, I mean this in the way that most 4X games Ive played, you had a HUGE galaxy to run around in.  I feel as if this game is limited to an extent but Im sure a mod will come along sooner or later.

Cons:
-1.5 Stars for not being multiplayer and there is ZERO evidence in becoming an MP game at a later date.

reviewText: Very little to distinguish this from the crowd, it's a dressed up MOO2 clone with an OK ship design system. Nothing to really grab you in terms of mechanics, and seems to rely on cheap shots in the form of space threats like Red Crystals or whatever they are. Stick with Star Ruler and Endless Space if you want decent 4X.

reviewText:
When evaluating this game, one must bear in mind that it has been made by one person. With this in mind, I have found this game to be very, very impressive. It feels like any 4X made by larger studios, and in some ways surpasses them. It only launched recently so there are still some bugfixing and balancing to do, but it's perfectly playable and the hours will fly by while you play this game

You will like this game if you prefer 4X games with more of a focus on combat and ship-design. It's ship designing feature will have you endlessly tinkering with your designs, and the combat is very satisfying with explosion sounds and gfx providing you a suitable reward for your aforementioned tinkering. If you mainly want a diplomacy/empire-building 4X, this game still is perfectly fine but you might get more satisfaction from other games.

Finally, beware that the game can be a bit challenging. Balancing of things is still on-going and I'm sure countless mods will spawn to help out with that, but the game will have you sweat a good bit and the AI can be quite aggressive if it notices vulnerability. The space combat AI seems, in comparison what other games of the genre have done so far, actually fairly good. The Diplomacy AI needs a bit of fine-tuning still, but it's already decent in it's 1.0 state.

I recommend this game.

reviewText: If there was a mixed review I'd rate it that but right now I'm rating this a NO since its getting mutiple patches a day and seriously needs a lot more work on (AI cheats like hell) . I'm still mostly on the fence on this second game.  If your new to Stardrive and enjoy turn base games like Civ V then you should like this one. On the other hand if you played the first stardrive and enjoyed the free flowing real time feel of being able to build fleets and move them around easily to patrol your empire, set up governors to manage the bulk of a large empire then your in for very very slow and fusterating game. (the first stardrive had its memory bug issues as soon as 700 ships were deployed in game you were on borrowed time any moment the game was going to freeze and crash)   I do like the side quests but the staging needs work especially when you can't zoom out and control your units and they are hidden behind a pop up and you wind up basically stuck since the enemy units refuse to advance. Oneside mission I completely gave up on after I couldn't manuver my units because I couldn't select them because the info boxes were in the way. That seriously needs to be addressed. AI is extremely onesided reminds me very much of the early days of CIV where all empires are super aggressive and would declare war at a drop of a hat especially if you colonize a world after they are introduced to you. Bug they need to fix is the AI spams a huge fleet more than I'd feel is possible with a hand full of worlds.  Or they are so far up the tech tree its ridiclious cheap, one thing I don't like is the AI having the abvility to use my own ship designs. Personally that breaks the game for me why spend an hour building a kickass titian ship that can wipe the floor with every emipre out there and ten minutes late the AI has it and spams 10 of them in five turns while you might be luckly to get 2. For now I'm going to give this one a rest least till most of the bugs are fixed.

reviewText:
This game directly appeals to Master of Orion and other space 4X games fans.  There are a lot of interesting aspects of this game, but unfortunately there are also too many fatal flaws.  The infantry combat is so bad that many players avoid it altogether.  It's basically a crappy isometric turn-based combat minigame that would have been sold on a Wal-Mart multipack floppy disk ten years ago (I'm serious, it makes the original final fantasy tactics look amazing).  The other fatal flaw is the sheer amount of interface glitches.  I can ignore and work around a lot, but they are everywhere.  The third fatal flaw is that you cannot give verbose commands to your ships in combat.  The ship combat is very interesting, but it's incredibly limited.  There is no formation move.  You cannot queue commands.  The battlefields are always the same boring grid, etc.

The dev has patched it many times, but it's still a broken game, and he is already moving onto his next project.  He hard coded many parts of the game so it is very hard to fix/mod, so this game will NEVER be fixed.
Do not buy this game, and be careful about supporting pre-releases!

With great sadness I remove this once promising game from my library list.

reviewText: Man am i dumb.  I didn't like stardrive 1, but because i really wanted this franchise to be good so i gave it a rather naive second chance and that was quite a mistake.  There is a fine line between homage and ripping off other games and this game is a blatant rip off of Master of Orion II, but it lacks the soul MoOII had.  Besides the ship building there is nothing unique about this game, and to top it off the ship building is massively unbalanced, some factions have ship layouts that are way smaller than the other races, others have such weird shapes that you can't possible do anything useful with them.  And then tiny little things like not putting things in alphabetical order in sorts, or not being able to filter menus really make this game just plain mediocre. Also bad ai, but hey no game developer in the history of 4x games has ever made a good ai...

reviewText:
I really like this game, I really do. However, It does have it's flaws.

Pros.

-Variety of races, different playstyles, ect.

-lots of interesting tech.

-Ship Weapon customization.

-Ability to commit genocide on friendly plant people.


Cons.

-Beginning battles are unbalanced (Enemies are apparently able to mass produce ships at the speed of light, and are not confined to command points.)

-Not being able to ask your allies for help in a war.

-being confined to a command point limit. (limiting big ship production)(Enemies have an unlimited budget, and are not confined, once again, to the command point limit) Leaving wars to be mainly one sided, and you Sh**ting yourself on the corner of the map waiting to be obliterated.


Anyway, please make the AI not so OP. It is broken and extremely hard to beat, yes, even on normal difficulty.



All in all, I give this game 7/10

reviewText: Got a bunch of hours in, and finally got a mod to work so I figured it deserved a review.  I've played worse games.  Its a pity how the dev abandoned the first iteration of the game and then put out a DLC without actually finishing the second.   There's a nice mod to make the tech a bit more bearable.  I love the achievements, lots of scifi fiction hooks.   Game could use more custom maps, more options and more hulls.  There's exactly one hull design for each size ship for each race.\n\nGame's got lots of issues, lots of annoyances.  But its fun.

reviewText: StarDrive 2 is a game with a certain amount of charming potential but is plagued by jagged edges. As of January 2016 there are still game breaking bugs & a noticeable number of generally design flaws / minor bugs. The general attitude among players that have been paying attention to the development of the title (and previous title(s) from Zero Sum Games, the developer) is that the problems will never be fixed.\n\nStardrive 2 is bargain bin fodder; befitting of whatever reduced price the end user can stomache with the knowledge that its a rough product.

reviewText: Slow boring game with uninspired content, horribly misinformed tutorials. If you love spending more time figuring out the mechanics of a game, how things work, what real impact they have than actually playing through a game, then this game is for you. The ground combat is worthlessly boring and monotonous. Space combat is psuedo complex hidden beneath sparkly lights but is also flat. Overall I'd say its like they took a good long look at MOO II and said 'hey guys lets make a game not quite as good as this, only cheesy'.

reviewText: The initial impressions of SD2 are positive. It is exceptionally similar to MOO2. I know it is common to say that when discussing any space 4X game but it is really true in this instance. The pace of the game, the way research is conducted, the complexity and scope of the game is almost exactly like Masters of Orion 2. There were a couple of good ideas from Stardrive 1 that carried over including the factions and the ship builder. I love the graphical style too.\n\nIf that impression held throughout I would give StarDrive 2 a firm good" rating. I've never played any 4x that evoked so much from MOO2 which is generally a good thing. The feel of the game is very similar to that classic game
date: down to the research options. The art style is wonderful
recommended: the ship builder is exceptional and the AI is more than competent (in fact
hoursPlayed:
it's brutal). There's a lot to like in the game.

But it falls down in a few areas and could use quite a bit of work.

The middle to end game is not very good. Every game will devolve into the same pattern - at some point you'll expand too much
voteText: your neighbors will get upset and it's just all-out war at that stage. There are no really cool random events to upset the balance of power and no distractions to occupy the player's attention elsewhere. It's a drudgery of cycling through building on planets
helpfulPercent: pushing units around
votesHelpful:
auto-resolving battles and repeat. This is a common problem in 4x games but it's magnified here because there is only one victory condition - extermination. Thus the entire endgame falls apart and the whole game breaks down.

Which brings me to the next problem...

...the Victory Conditions. The player has no choice and it becomes very tedious. Instead of building a consensus or achieving enlightenment or fighting some external foe
votesTotal: I'm forced into a policy of being a ruthless warmonger. That's not a lot of fun IMO.\n\nThe random events are exceptionally limited. Usually it's me getting .5 fewer food per farmer. Big deal. Where are meteor showers or a comet to explore? Where's a powerful earthquake that changes the orbit of a planet

reviewText:
It's extremely close to Masters of Orion 2 and I believe it's far superior in many aspects. I've played MoO2 quite a lot and I've played tons of other 4X games and none were this close in design and yet still feel modern and well thought out.

the game's not perfect but it's definitely one of the best 4X games out there. with a bit more extra development, some DLC adding some more depth and some cool mods by the community and it probably will be the best out there.

best parts:
-ship design (lots of choice and flexibility without some of the hassle from SD1)
-combat (AI is pretty clever, including that of your own ships)
-research (MoO2 style, wish it was copied more)
-no unneeded micro-management (like freighters. thank god)
-easy to understand, hard to master economic system overal
-solid diplomacy system. (takes some getting used to but when you get it it works fine)
-bit of genre savvy humor on the sides, lest we take the game too seriously. (best to leave that to the expert, i.e. distant worlds)
-free range battle ground is an excellent way to test your designs. just wish there was a way to adjust the tech level of your modules. the various missions are way too difficult for my tastes, though >.>

haven't done any ground battles yet. can't comment on how good or bad those are, but I hear good things.

worst parts:
-I feel I have to scroll and drag the map around a -lot- to get a good view on what my planets are doing. I feel many other 4X games do this a little better. especially endless space. yes, this is a minor issue but gets more annoying the longer you play and you have a bigger empire to manage. it'd help if you don't have to zoom in as far to get planet details. I don't really feel the empire management screen is a proper replacement of an easy to use galaxy map, though it does what it should well.
-no multiplayer! no real dealbreaker as truthfully I hardly ever play online with or against other people, but considering this game's outstanding ship design feature it really would suit it particularly well.
-the game secretely hates your guts and will let you know about it any chance it gets. 20 turns in and get your first ♥♥♥♥♥♥ corvette out the door? congrats, let's celebrate with a remant fleet at your doorstep you wouldn't have a chance of defeating 200 turns in. do not overestimate your 4X skills and just start your first game on easy like a noob should!

reviewText:
For those of you who love Masters of Orion, this is the same type of game, but perfected. Imagine if you could custom design the layout of your ships in Masters of Orion, with better graphics to boot.

Ignore the internet trolls who don't understand what the heck they are talking about. This is an indie game made with far greater love and admiration for the genre than big budget studios with millions of dollars to spend. The result is a game with much better design and implementation.

Best turn based strategy game on Steam, hands down.

reviewText: If you enjoyed playing StarDrive, then continue playing it. StarDrive 2 is a gutted version of the first game with a few improvements. What I mean by a gutted version is that if you enjoyed the control over the fleets and dynamics of the space battles you will not get that with this game. StarDrive 2 is more of a point your fleet in the direct of the enemy and the computer will work out the rest. The game does have a better planetary battle concept; but, that is what it is a concept. Sometimes you take control of the enemy, sometimes the enemy doesn't do anything at all. I really loved the first game. When I watched the videos on the second game, I thought that is would be an extension of the first with better graphics, ship construction, and planetary battles. Changing the controls for the ship battles lost my support for this game.

reviewText: I wanted to like this game, and I almost did, but ultimately the tone-deaf developer and the balance of this game put me off it entirely.  I like to play 4x games with a minimal focus on combat, and its just not possible to do that in StarDrive 2.  No matter what you try to do in terms of economics, research, diplomacy, the AI is just a giant war machine that will attack you and force you to play your entire game around pumping out an endless supply of ships to survive.  I understand that the developer wants this to be a more confrontational game, but when you limit the player's options so severly, they may as well have none.\n\nDone with this game done with this developer.  Good riddance.

reviewText:
Well here it is, the sequel to the game everyone wanted right? Right?

I'm gonna' start with the positives;
- The game has a nice UI when you're playing on the strategy map, it's relatively easy to use and tells you every thing     you need to know at this perspective.
- The games empire management screen is useful, it allows you to manage a large empire quite effectively from one screen.
I find that I quickly run out of positives, the reason I've played it for as long as I have is because there are star wars and star trek model mods for it, most people don't know because the games steam workshop is broken.

The negatives, unfortunately this may take a while;
- The game severely lacks originality, it doesn't innovate the genre at all and uses most of its aspects from the master of Orion game series. All of the races apart from the Chukk affiliation are ripoffs from MoO, and all of those races assets are reused from the old game, infact most of the assets of the game are reused from the first game, the buildings and the ship designs, the game has even less ship designs then the original which doesn't help.
- The game has six options if that, including the ability to disable the gnn broadcasts, which can get annoying, you can turn v sync on/off and fullscreen on/off, change the quality with 4 different options from fastest to best, you can change your anti-aliasing settings and change the resolutions. It's extremely lacking in option customability.
- The planetary production is boring, you can change the workers from science to production to food, again like MoO.
- The ship design has changed to become much less customizable, the firing acrs aren't customizable and it's less balanced.
-  There is only one win condition total dominance of the galaxy or you can just quit when you kill the masters.
- The AI doesn't favour diplomacy and they will all declare war because they can't do anything else, they don't really value allies or friends, performing diplomatic acts just pospones the envitable. They can't design new ships just the default ones which are terrible so if you have a decent few ships you can completely destroy their fleer, which brings me to the envitablility of ground combat. Unless you have nukes on your ships to exterminate the enemy soldiers and sweep in with some soldiers to capture the planet, you will have the unfortunate displeasure of meeting the ground combat. Its performance is terrible, it's ridiculasly unbalanced, dull and auto resolve is unreliable so you are force to do this monotonous task if you want to win.

It's an unoriginal easy sequel that is buggy with a bad developer. Don't buy the game, if you want a game that's like this but more polished and by a reliable company, I'd either buy stellaris, GalCiv or the new master of orion.

reviewText:
Personally I have really enjoyed this game much more than I have enjoyed other games in the 4X genre. The developer has already made a patch to make easy mode easier, so the difficulty is a lot less of an issue now.

Pros:
Game lets you feel like Darth Sidius before he turned the republic into his Empire.
Pretty sweet space combat
The alien races (AI) do a wonderful job of staying true to character, allowing for a fun roleplaying experience
Decent bit of side content to do in game
Each game will play out differently

Cons:
Non automated combat can feel a bit clumsy
This game can be QUITE difficult at higher difficulties
Lack of a story
Not overly friendly to players new to the 4X genre
Interface can get buggy/cluttered towards the end game (nothing game breaking) due to the sheer size of the map and how much is going on in it

With all of that being said, I have written a very detailed review for this game which can be found at this link:
http://www.wtfgamersonly.com/stardrive-2-full-review-conquering-universe-one-move-time/

The link above will do a much better job of explaining the different pros and cons of the game, as well as addressing concerns many gamers might have before making their purchase. If you are on the fence about this game, I highly recommend going and reading that review.

If you're already thinking about getting the game, DO IT!!!! I promise you that you will not regret your purchase.

reviewText:
A MUST HAVE! This game is phenomenal! Absolutely, mind-blowingly outstanding! I have done so much in just one night... Conquered planets, went to war twice, enjoyed the awesome diplomacy and unique races, love the leaders that come along too... I ended up have an Elephant man with a futuristic staff governing my people on a desert planet where they happened to harvest spice... Hell YES!
What can I say: 1) Stellar, action packed beautiful Space Combat 2) Awesome turn based ground combat with troops (very functional, fun and unique) 3) In depth and easy ship, weapon and troop customization. 4) Huge (nearly endless) talent trees with special projects that come your way time to time 5) Seriously among the best diplomacy systems of any game 6) Unique races, planets, ship designs, buildings, backgrounds and all sorts of beautiful illustrations accompanying the awesome texts. 7) Outstanding music with a wide variety and appropriate mood changes with events.

If you want a game that would be something like total war in space, then this is your ticket. In fact I would say this is even better than if total war made a space game. There is nothing that I dislike in this game, I honestly feel that it is perfect. I know that I will be back for hundreds of more hours to come! Thank you for making this extraordinary game! It has blown my mind, I truly love it! If you are questioning whether or not you should buy this game, THINK NO MORE! It is aboslutely worth every cent and more. BUY IT! It is one of the BEST GAMES that I have ever played. Can't wait to wake up tomorrow and hop back on!

reviewText:
The second I heard he was switching to a turn based system I started getting weary, but my love of the first one made me hope for the best, sadly my hopes where in vein.  This game is just plain boring.  Everything that made the last game cool and unique has been stripped away.  I loved the real time battles and micro turns of the first one, they made the game challenging and fun, but now it's a space bar holding simulator.  Not enough happens in one turn to justify making this game turn based.  This how it works, you pick a research and then you hold down the space bar for 2 mins, and then the research bar is done and you pick a new one.

The research UI is horrific.  I still haven’t figured out the tree.  In fact there doesn’t' seem to be one.  Or maybe the UI is just so terrible I can't tell.

Making the battles a separate screen takes you out of the action a great deal, it's not fun at all.  Even designing ships isn't even fun anymore, because you start with like half the modules unlocked.  What’s up with that?

This game is just boring as it is, and to fix it, it would require a complete overhaul of the game, so I doubt it's going to be better.  I don't recommend this game if you liked the first one.

reviewText:
I have played a lot of 4x games(Master of Orion, Master of Orion 2, Ascendency, Master of Magic, Fantasy Empires, The Civilization Games, Heroes of Might and Magic 1-5, Galactic Civilizations, Imperium Galactica II, and probably a bunch more that I don't remember right now), and the reviews for this one seem a bit more enthusiastic rather than accurate.

It borrows heavily from other games but to the point where it feels derivative of them rather than being a synthesis of them. Moreover it is so blatant about it that it feels like it is flirting with the breaking the fourth wall not something I am a huge fan of.

The game has a lot of potential in the ship design and strategic aspect of space and ground combat and the level of depth that it allows you to manipulate your empire.

I will say that it was better than MOO III in general fun and striking a balance between allowing depth and getting carried away with it.

My big gripes about the game are as follows.

Technological advance doesn't yield significant upgrades until you get very very far along in the trees. I almost always had better luck researching a few basic (tier one or two technologies), the pumping everything into producion ships and troops and conquering the galaxy without ever doing more than cursory reasearch.

The AI literally cheats on basic settings, I have tested rich homeworlds on small maps with optimized industrial output and the AI will invariably massively outcolonize me and outproduce me (in terms of fleet and fleet size) very quickly in the early game. You can still win by being clever or cheesy in your builds, but the fact that it literally plays by a different set of rules on default settings really really bothers me.

The technologies are poorly balanced to create a stable empire. The game forces you specialize each of your planets because of prohibitive maintanence costs (making one planet that has all upgrades and buildings your empire is capable of will put a big dent in your wallet). Basically I find myself skipping almost all of my unlocked buildings on most colonies just because of what it costs to maintain them. The way various technolgies interact and overlap with each other just makes a lot of them feel useless or redundant or only of use on a very small proportion of your colonies.

I do think the game has a whole lot of potential and with some patches or balance changes could be more fun. Essentially my complaint it that it forces you to play in one of a few very specific ways if you want to avoid getting wiping out quickly on default difficulty. It felt more like how well can I implement this strategy which I know will be the only viable one for this map/race selection rather than what type of empire would I like to build this time. It feels like the game has mechanics for amazing strategies and fun but makes it impossible for you to implement them before you have already taken control of the map.

Bottom Line I just didn't have fun playing it.

reviewText:
StarDrive 2 is a true successor to Master of Orion 2, my all-time favorite space strategy game. They are similar, especially the tech tree, which is brilliant and, as I hoped, never ending throughout the game, however long. But SD2 has much more to offer, peppered with more than 100 potential random events. And it’s much improved over SD1.

I see negative reviews that have only played for 3-8 hours. I’m on my first Normal setting game (probably should have gone Easy setting first) and I’ve played for 2 days against 5 AI, 161 turns, without the end in sight on a 70 star game (out of 100 at the moment). Granted, I’m carefully reading every well-written description of tech upgrades to plan strategy and learn the game. Nearly every item has a mouse-over tooltip to help. Love that. Developer has already stated on forums that he’ll make the Easy setting a bit easier for those who found it too hard and he says the AI doesn’t cheat or spawn ships as needed, it just plays more efficiently.

Tutorial is nicely done, getting you off to a good start. The artwork is beautiful, from splash screens to the solar systems, ships, icons and elegant UI. One reviewer thought the UI was clunky but perhaps he didn’t know that you can back out of windows with a mouse right-click, so boink, boink, you’re back to the strategic or planet view in a second. You can zoom in to the battle scenes and see the hits and scorch marks on ships. Sound effects are very cool for each variety of weapon. One reviewer claimed he could only zoom completely in or out on the strategy map. Must be a scroll wheel problem. I had no problem smoothly zooming to any size view on the strategy map or battle view. One click on a planet and the planet view opens to plan your next building or ship. Right or left arrow can take you to each of your planets from that window. You can also build from the Empire Management screen or pick out your next planet to colonize from a list of explored planets with several filters. Planets may have a special resource or condition that can be beneficial or harmful in some way. If beneficial, it may affect your entire empire. If harmful, there is an opportunity to reverse that affect through special research. I’m just getting into the spy system and it strikes me as very cool.

You can start a tiny colony on rich asteroids that fuel production with no pollution or build a refueling station on a gas giant, so eventually every planet in game has a use. Better explore early game to find those few Terran planets. Swamp, ocean and tundra planets can help produce food until you develop Aeroponic Farms, Subterranean Farms, etc. Build some freighters that will automatically deliver extra food to colonies that need it. Freighters are also used to move colonists between planets and for ground troop transport. You can also research an Experimental (read mystery) tech and get something unexpected. Last one I got was Unsavory Cantina, boosting morale, that wasn’t on any tech tree. Later in the game, you can research a Colony Ship that deploys a free Rover Bay (+production) and Aeroponic Farm (+food) to speed colonizing late game. Brilliant. The Terraformer, deep in the Bio-Chemistry tech tree improves the class of a planet every 25 turns until reaching Gaia. Looking forward to that! Stop at an unprotected enemy planet and pick up a few slaves for your Slave Pits, if you have that tech and mind set.

SD2 has a lot to offer the space strategy gamer and I highly recommend it. I’ll be playing it for years as the developer refines the game and adds DLC. Just loaded my saved game for today (2nd day after release) and it’s already version 1.0c. I’m guessing the Easy setting has been changed already.

reviewText: I genuinely think this game is worth the asking price. It is a solid experience and has nice variety for those who look for it. That said though it is a little lacking in some areas. A few complaints are in areas like diplomacy. The lack of a Federation system as was present in the first game is noticable to me and combined with the demanding AIs always pressing your tolerance limits is an annoyance. The ground combat is weak in my opinion though permissable as it isn't the focus of the game but allows some break up in space battles. Most interestingly is that this game feels designed with multiplayer in mind. The tolerance limits would play well into players not over coorperating, the leader system means that no empire can have all the cards and players would have to consider sharing techs to get what they want. This would also help explain the lack of Federation since it merges two empires into one. This leads into my final point where, other than seemingly bottomless ability to throw ships and troops at you AI is a little lightweight. They don't use great unit cohesion in ground combat and I found them to use numbers rather than design to win space fights. A player would pose a much more interesting threat and I might actually have to bust out the Hazmat suits. Again a good game but it has a way to go to become great.\n\nAddendum: Thought of it as I was writing the above. I know that they simplified space to ease the burden on computers and such but I miss: being able to build battlestations in deep space, being able to jump ships in and out of danger, or the possibility of ships getting stranded in space after their engines are shot out, FTL and combat thrusters, ability to redesign transport ships (could be converted to combat use), designing stations, exporting production and assigning governers to build and manage things on planets. Regardless though I think this game is an improvement on small scale galaxies but needs some upgrades to help managment on large maps. Happy space battles and remember: It may not be much to look at... but Its RAINING DIAMONDS!

reviewText:
Great fun from 1st step.

First I encountered a little bug, but Zero has corrected it asap. This is customer service as we want it.

Game shows up like a very detailed 4X title with a mix of usual turn-base play and real-time battles. Additional you get some X-com like ground fights. You have full authority over your ship builds and could even more decide detailed parts, which you could micro-switch probably larger distance for less hitpoints or else to your conveniance. Even your ground troops could be equipped from a pool of very different weapons, armors, health bars or whatever you may research.

The game is mixed with a lot of surprising events...like stumbling over a wrecked ship with your scout...but you need some ground troops for further investigation. Once you start the mission you'll find yourself surrounded by a load of 'bugs' which pretty much like your taste. ^^

Played now for 4 hours on release day and can't wait to go on the other day...

***

Ok, found a minute to give another response after nearly 100 hours of play.

This game is great, it gives you total into depth ship design, research planings or just colonization road to think about. Anyhow it is released and we currently are on version 1.01 there are still some rough edges. But Zero with his one-man-dev-show is working hard behind the scenes to bring new features every patch and recognizing every single bug response to make this game fun for every customer.

Only thing I do miss is multiplayer, but currently I'm more into playing a StarTrek inspirated conversation mod with plenty of new ships and other stuff to get into the story.

Anyhow it is same genre, I do not like to compare SD2 with GC3 as both games do aim completely different and have only turnbased and sci-fi in common. But besides that, SD2 is much more dynamic and brings more fun to me at the moment.

Cheers!

reviewText:
While I enjoyed StarDrive 1, it was never finished. This game looked, at first glance, to be an attempt to create the game SD 1 was supposed to be. A lot of the changes are good (turn based but still quick gameplay), tech tree in which every choice feels like it makes a difference (but also extremely remniscient of MoO2) and hints of a story you might learn if you spend enough time with the game.

Ship building is basically similar to the first game, but streamlined, which I highly approve of.

The bad (and/or not yet done features) are too many to give this game a pass. If anything, this most certainly belongs in early access. If the designer disagrees, he ought to stop making games.

A few specifics:
-The tech tree is basically a mash-up of SD 1 and MoO2. But with sparsely any game effects visible (except for buildings, which are all well detailed, which makes the difference all the more obvious). The description certainly doesn't convey how utterly useless researching Plasma cannons was (in every way a worse choice than the weapons you start with, since they just almost never seem to hit) nor that researching and equipping rail guns to my troops would be a worse choice than sticking to the laser rifles you start with.

-Ground combat. Wow. Are you serious? You release a game with this feature"?
Graphics are acceptable

reviewText:
I have changed my mind on Stardrive 2.  I am sticking to the prior posting that I don't really care about the Stardrive 1 complaints.  That said I am getting rather upset with the game balance.  After a number of hours I keep hitting a brick wall against the game's AI.  I am not a master of RTS or TBS games but I can usually hold my own against AI.  That said even on easy I am getting my butt stomped regardles of what I do.  I have read up what I can but it seems like I am not the only person running into what almost appears to be a cheating AI.  At first I thought I was expanding too quick eating up resources because of that and the AI was able to build a huge fleet to come at me, regardless of me owning 90% of the map.  So then I started playing it slow, building up a pretty good fleet or two with just a couple star systems under my control.  Nope still get stomped.   I have went back and trying countless different tactics and regardless of what I do I can't get anywhere near the fleets that the AI is putting out.    The game isn't bad but the AI is either cheating or there is something else going on.  Like I said I don't claim to be a strategy expert but even at easy I am getting stopped.  I don't mind hard games, but I don't like games that AI has balance problems.   Zero put out a patch that was supposed to make things better on that front, but if anything they have gotten worse.    Stay away for the moment if you want a game that has an AI that plays fair and isn't going to trash you over and over again even on the easy setting.  I can't imagine what the harder settings must be like.   I know I am going to get some L2P comments.   Maybe I am missing something major but after hours of play I continue to get slaughtered by the AI regardless of what my tactics are.


Review at the 90 minute mark - outdated
I had the first Stardrive. I didn't have a big bone against it like some people.  I didn't play for Multiplayer anyway so it not getting included in didn't bother me.  I can see how some people were upset though.  I am not going to say that Zero didn't hurt himself when he dropped support of the first and started working on the sequel, however I understand why he did.  Personally with the 90 or so minutes I have spent in the game I can say that the sequel is worth the money.  I would have liked to see a bit of a better discount for prior users but still for $20 it wasn't that bad and if you don't already own the first I feel like the game is stable and more than fun enough to say that it is worth $30.  Do I understand why some Stardrive players feel slighted, yes.  Do I think it is unforgiveable?  No I don't.  As long as Zero continues to support 2 and doesn't run off starting 3 before everyone feels any major bugs have been addressed I personally think everything is fine.  I have a ton of space 4x games and 4x games in general, and I can say that SD2 does a lot of unique things, and well enough that it sets itself out from the crowd.

reviewText:
Great game, with potential to be amazing.

Captures much of what made MOO2 amazing, while adding a great deal of charm into the world (the dialogue from the leaders and such). Combat is real time, cinematic like BOTF but with more strategy.

Main thing holding it back from truly replacing MOO2 as the king of 4x space is the remaining bugs. This is also the source of a great many of the negative reviews here--many people feel that a DLC expansion should not have gone through until bugs were fixed.

But hey, the creator seems really active fixing the bugs that are being found. If he continues in this for the next couple of months, and really gets things as close to bug free as possible before moving on to new content, then he will have achieved true greatness with this game.

And he will have built a stable platform on which I will look forward to purchasing many future expansions. There is the potential here for years of worthwhile content, Crusader Kings 2 style, as long as the bugs are squashed thoroughly first.

I personally decided to buy it now with a sense of optimism and hope (which I think the developer is currently proving he is worthy of). Either way, I am very much looking forward to seeing the future of this wonderful game.

reviewText:
The DLC made this game.

It was an also-ran til then.

I've played half a dozen games with the DLC and each one has been completely different, even though I've stuck as the same race throughout. Different challenges, each set up has guided different choices and the random heroes and questes ensures it stays interesting.

The tech tree always offers you as range of offers to complete 1/3 of the puzzle in a particular area, with the other two thirds only gained by espionage or diplomacy. eg within research lvl 1 you can unlock a reaseach centre (+3 per scientist), universities (+5 and then +1 per scientist) or a ship module that increases reseach. Once you get one, the other two are locked down and you are into another related 1 in 3 choice in this area for lvl 2.

You can also design your own ships and it doesn't require a degree in mathmatics!!!!

Yes 4X, yes  deep space strategy mindf##k and yes sometimes just as you think you have dillusions of Ming the merciless you get totally creamed by a mysterious space pirate, lobsters or angry hippy crystal... but that's what makes it great (and you then to restart).

If still unsure, stick it on your shortlist and pick it up in the inevitable sale.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic. I was shocked to see it had mixed reviews and realized I didn't post one.

I keep coming back to it over and over again because it's easy to fire up and play and there are so many races and types of ships to build it makes each game a new experience. Originally I thought of it as a modernized clone of MOO2 (till I learned it a little better) but... I hate to say it.. I mean I really do because I'm a big long time fan of MOO2 but I'm starting to think this game is actually superior to Master of Orion 2. It's just got more of everything that is great about MOO2 in a slicker and friendlier UI. I can't believe it was made by one guy. I guess sometimes one persons vision is better than an entire team of developers with conflicting ideas. I was looking to get the the new Moo early access remake and... ya know I think I'll just keep playing Stardrive 2. Expensive voice actors don't really make a great game, it's gameplay that make them great. Great gameplay is what makes us play various games for over 10 years like MOO2. It's not the fluff of cut scenes or voice acting. It seems Zero understands that.

I think this game gets some negative reviews or is called incomplete" by some people is that they expect the game to have some kind of splashy story and a easy "story mode" setting.. and that is not really what this is. This game is about terrific 4x gameplay in the vein of old style gaming (like moo itself). You will not win every game and that is a good thing because it puts the pressure on an makes you take risks. As far as bugs go
date: I haven't really noticed any serious ones but I play it on Linux so maybe it's more stable. In all the games I've played maybe it's crashed a couple of times.. big deal. (I've seen major titles that are waaay worse
recommended:
)


Pros:
* Great ship design.
* Tactical ship combat is really good.
* The UI is friendly and well thought out.
* Planet management is fairly easy. (compared to Moo2)
* It has a lot of cool races each with their own unique ships that is more than how they look they actually affect what weapons you can research and equip so various things work better on various races.
* Customizable galaxy with random things to discover in it.
* Sidequests that open various new technology and can impact your builds.
* It's very challenging. (I play on hard or brutal mode usually)
* Plays great on Linux.
* High replay value.

Some things it could improve on:
* No DLC! - Seriously zero take my money.
* Occasionally (on my hardware) the game slows down on 100-200 ships shooting it out. (w/ thousands of missiles or fighters especially)
* Ground combats pretty basic. (tho better than MOO2)
* Spying could be abit improved.
* No Stat system or charts to see how your doing. Sometimes you feel a little blind.
* No peaceful solution. You have to kill everyone. (tho diplomatic win is kinda meh..)
* No real ending. You just win. (I wasn't expecting much but nice victory screen or stats would be nice)
* Some of the larger ships are not symmetrical and have more space on one side or the other. It's an oddity..


Haters be dammed.. this game rocks. If you like 4X
hoursPlayed: it's a must buy."

reviewText:
Have only played for a few hours thus far.  Really like the design and concept, but the UI is clunky, there's no key mapping, and cant save Ship Designs, which is a BIG part of this game.  Shipyard itself is generally buggy, the UI keeps shifting and sections keep overlapping other sections, plus it's really slow to respond.  Will continue playing to see if issues resolve for now, but disappointed in interactive execution.

Edit - reload did solve the Shipyard problem (for now).  However, when running into alien races framerate drops dramatically.  The animation seems to really slow down the game.  Ground battles can experience the same issues - when selecting units the game freezes for a few seconds.

Oh yeah, and what's with the 0 Food production on just about EVERY planet.  Out of over a dozen habitable planets, I've found a whole whopping TWO that allow any kind of food production (and both of those were minimal at only .5/farmer).  This wouldn't be so bad if your colony ships allowed more than 1 population on them, but NO customization for Frieghters and Colony ships means they aren't capable of increased capacity or armament.  Hell, you can't even control Freighters, so if you have a distant planet you want to settle, you can't accompany your Colony ship with a Foof Freighter so your people dont starve before you get some food there in the only way possible allowed by the poorly designed game mechanics.

Based on this HIGH dependancy on food transport between colonies, there are some obvious racial benefit choices when starting a new game.

reviewText:
Tl;Dr - Just get Master of Orion 2, or the latest one.

I really enjoyed the first StarDrive because of the real-time 4X. Despite the bugs in the first game, it was amazing seeing your empire come to life in real time. Ship customisation was a really cool thing, being able to build your ship from scratch from a general hull type is really cool.

Basically the only cool thing that was transferred to SD2 was the ship building mechanic, and it received next to no improvements anyway. It went from real-time to turn based, and in doing so basically became a MoO clone. It tried to differentiate with an XCOM/HoM&M style ground combat mini-game where you could control your units. However it was such a half-baked and often buggy experience that it detracted far more than it could ever give.

SD3 if there is going to be one, needs to return to its real-time roots, which was its biggest USP, as far as I'm concerned. The series has a chance to really make a mark in the space 4X genre, and it's unfortunate the second entry in the series has been so let down with lazy copy-cat design.

reviewText: StarDrive 2 impresses me in a lot of ways.  Firstly, the music and graphics are outstanding.  Secondly, the ship editor is both in-depth and intuitive...though I'm still trying to figure out optimal designs as the default ones don't seem to last very long in combat.  The races themselves have unique personalities and I appreciate their quirks and dialogue.  The tech tree is different in the sense that you have to pick between 2-3 techs every tier, meaning you'll pass on the others and may never get them.  This made me really think about what kind of empire I wanted.  Combat was also very fun and satisfying...I liked watching my creations attempt to work with what I gave them (shields and beam weapons, mostly).\n\nAs far as what I don't like: the game doesn't tell you when a planet is not producing anything (it does tell you when new research is available) and the AI is still too difficult, even on Easy".  I am not ashamed to say that I could be playing better and designing my ships more efficiently
date: but I'd also like to see "Easy" made even easier...that is
recommended: I'd like to build up my empire in relative peace and then attack when I'm ready. It would be great if there was a way to turn off the AI's ability to attack altogether and instead have it play a defensive game. Either that
hoursPlayed: or limit their CP in some way.  Of course
voteText: there are those that think "Brutal" is too easy and don't want the developer to change anything. That's why there are multiple difficulty levels...I'm sure it's possible to change one difficulty setting without touching the others
helpfulPercent: making the "don't nerf the AI for the casuals" complaints irrelevant. Some of us don't want a challenge
votesHelpful: just a way to unwind after working 10 hour shifts. I'm just the type that prefers a "light" challenge...*shrug*
votesTotal: everyone's mileage will differ.  If some feel that "Easy" is just right
votesFunny: then perhaps an "Easier" difficulty setting could be added.\n\nLong story short
commentsCount: casual 4X players may get frustrated (like I have) at times when the AI decides to come at you with a vengence despite your attempts to be passive.  Difficulty aside I'm really enjoying this one and I can easily recommend it to 4X fans.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YxB-vpqlQUk"

reviewText:
I've been playing StarDrive2 for a long while now and I've neglected to add a review until now after seeing its Mixed rating which I feel is undeserved. I would like to list off the games major stengths and weaknesses.

Strengths:
- Extremely customizable galaxy (How many stars, liklihood of life in each system, several different patterns to place them in that have significant gameplay consequences for each one)
- Excellent execution of the 4X concept (Explore fast to get a few treasure systems with plenty of buffer systems between them for protection )
- 9 species with customizable racial traits (Personally I was happy with their presets and never changed them)
- Beautiful digital graphics and fine character art
- Stradegy in unexpected places (Most battles are decided by how well you built your ships and each race has a favored stadegy that requires a tweak to your fleet to come out on top)
- Great replayability (I'd swear I would be sick to death with this game and after a two-week break I play as a new species and conquer the galaxy all over again!)
- Crazy ideas (I've made talking elephant citizens, T-Rex shocktroops, and dropped zombie virus nukes on planets!)
- The developer is good about fixing bugs or performance issues that get brought up (Crashes have been rare for me)

Weaknesses:
- Not much story in the campaign ( I've never played a 4X game brimming with plot )
- The space battles dont require a lot of stradegy (Its mainly decided by the quality and size of your fleet)
- The game really slows down in the epic 100+ ship battles (Patches have since made it tolerable)
- The ground battles are stiff and slow in contrast to the fast and fluid space battles ( The troop limits on special missions keep it challenging though )
-  The only way to win is wiping everyone else out ( Develepor claims there will be more victory conditions later )


My personal score - 9/10

The AI, is just down right stupid and interacting with them is totally pointless. Even after all the patches to it has only elevated high functioning mentally disabled. reviewText: A hard AI based game With realistic Solar Systems (Very Few Planets like Earth) where you have to rely on your Technology to not be over run by your foe. I have played multiple games all ending and starting out differently, Rebels can take over your capital, A unforgiveing foe attacks you, or maybe some radom wormhole opens and a unknown race ends up killing you, these are just some of the examples of how this game is diverse and every game will be different. I would recommend this game if you want to try a new fun 4x Strategy game that is Random in its events and difficulty.

reviewText:
The game is a good buy and enjoyable, overall worth the money. However, it is not yet a great game and will require patches and expansion packs to make it so. Detailed comments below.

+ Throughout the game there is the feeling of an arms race, constantly needing new technology and designs to stay ahead.

+ The diplomacy is quite good, albeit lacking alliances and a diplomatic victory. You also do get a few funny requests (such as one of my opponents declaring war on me for not giving them my homeworld).

+ Graphics are good (from my experience for the 4X genre).

+ AI and the game seems balanced but it does take c. 10 hours of trial and error as it is quite tough.

+ Race customisation options are good.

- The game does have a number of bugs e.g. for c. 25% of my first full game I would end up playing ground combat as the enemy. This is not game breaking as I could guarantee myself a win by therefore intentionally losing as the enemy but it is odd for such an obvious bug to be present at release.

- The UI is at times awkward, e.g. for some races Titan ships (the largest vessels) are too large on the strategic map and prevent the ability to select any other planets or fleets in the system. This again is not game breaking but is quite frustrating.

- As far as I can tell, elimination of all races is the only victory condition. This makes it very sad to have to turn on your closest friends to win the game.

- Ground combat is relatively poorly designed; a system such as MOO2 would have been fine or a later expansion pack.
voteText: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
After logging around 5 hours, i have found that the game is quite enjoyable. There are instances where you just want to turn it off because some space monster starts rushing you and blockades your planets or your fleet is harrased by them, but the whole idea is to get yourself into a stable position to be able to defend that.

The game is nice in looks and nice in gameplay. The new landing battlefield is amazing and lots of fun, i find myself getting lost within the boarding fights or the attempts to wipe out an aggressive alien spieces that has control over an anomaly.

I like the fact you have to decide which research you choose and then diplomacy is one of the other ways to attain the ones you havent researched, it means you actually need to interact with other races and build some kind of relationship with them in order to get what you need, and the fact that citizens have some kind of influence on which races you can trade with makes the game that little bit more challenging.

There are some negatives like the fact that you will get rushed even if you dont have a fleet, by the hostile forces that reside in the galaxy, you will find other races rather quickly and in some cases have to go to war before you intended. There is also  the fact that it can be relatively fast paced due to small sized maps, and continual turn passing.. i think that every turn should matter and there should be things to do every turn rather then turn passing while waiting for research or so on... then again this could be me playing the game wrong :S

All in all i think that this game is worth it considering is low price tag, It's not for everyone but if you enjoy turn based stratergy and enjoy space colonization simulations, I suggest you buy this game.

reviewText:
Star Drive 2 is a worthy successor to Master or Orion 2!

So let me compare it to the classic:

+ Better economic/expansion AI than (vanilla, not modded) MoO2
+ Better graphics than MoO2
+ Better ship design (via module placement that matters)
+ Special Resources for empire wide boni
+ Special Research Projects
+ More diverse planets (types are about the same #, but SD2 has more modifiers)
+ Mini-quests/events (some location/discovery based, some from heroes)
+ Real time with pause space ship combat (-> you can keep formations, useful for specialized ships like canopy shield carriers or PD-Platforms)

+/- Aggressive/opportunistic AI: If you are really weak, they will attack (even if they trade with you and like you, so no real friendship")
+/- strong focus on military/conquest aspect of the game
+/- not (yet) as many mods as MoO2 (but is does have strong modding support)
+/- planetary invasion mini-game (some like it
recommended:
but you can still bombard from orbit)

- less modules in ship design
- lesser focus on diplomacy
- slowdowns with very large battles (more than 100 ships for me)
- missing some useful features MoO2 had (in-game encyclopedia
hoursPlayed:
statistics)

I can wholeheartedly recommend this game!

If you get it

reviewText: Some of the best shipbuilding in any 4x space strategy game ever. Ground combat is meh, and it currently has a few issues with oversized fleets and auto resolve, but I really like shipbuilding. It also has one of the best start game customization I ahve ever seen. The options menu is lackluster though. It also really innovates with the diplomacy screen, even though the diplomacy itself is a bit lacking, by letting you see the exact value of different trades and why the other race hates or loves you. The research is also really interesting because you must choose between different techs, only getting rhe other ones through diplomacy or espionage, spying being pretty lame. Buy it on sale.

reviewText:
The reasons I choose to give StarDrive2 a negitive review;

1. The game is buggy and has serious balance issues
2. A DLC pack has been released, which should have been a update.
3. Very little bugfixing going on
4. Developer has dropped out on previous game, leaving it in unfinished state, and seems to want extra money to provide expansions when the game is still as unbalanced as day one.




I liked the idea of this game, I thought it would be a successor to the Masters of Orion games, and in some ways it is. Its not a bad game, but it feels unbalanced and unfinished. I bought the Original StarDrive too.

The Developer abandoned that project stating it was in a playable state, which to some sense it was, but it was not what was promised, unfinished tech trees, an intresting storyline with the mysterious remnant race, which just ended half way with no explanasion, despite it being clear there was more to the story.

reviewText:
As of 1.0g I can safely say that this needed a longer period of beta testing.

The balance is off, by quite a bit, in some places. This is most obvious in terms of the weapon systems where early-game tech is typically the best option throughout the game.

Some of the available options don't work, like special research projects to remove some planet maluses. Sometimes these fancier systems work poorly like subspace projectors which are difficult to place, impossible to deconstruct, and do not provide a consistent bonus in their area of effect.

The AI would sooner spite the player than actually attempt to survive in the game. I reduced a 10+ planet AI empire to 1 planet, and it consistently refused to surrender anything but one early game technology for peace. This wasn't a tolerance limit, but rather that it simply didn't see enough 'profit' in the deal.

The worst of it though is the FPS drop on the tactical map. Depending on the weapons you and the AI have this can occur even on moderately sized battles (about 20 ships a side, most of which are corvettes). I have a beast of a machine, (i7-5820k, GTX 980, 16gigs of ram and SD2 is running on a SDD), and the FPS can drop to nothing. What's irritating about this is that SD1 had bigger battles, with bigger ships, and worked much better at these numbers than SD2 is doing with an only moderate difference in graphics.

You couldn't justify it at $29.99. If you owned SD1 and can pick it up for a third off then it's a solid purchase. Otherwise though, you're better waiting for either a reduction or a fix to some of the above.

That said, it is worth picking up eventually. This is probably the closest we've come in modern times to a 4X classic like MOO2.

Manual ship and ground battles is a huge selling point. This is one of the very few 4X titles that has these mechanics, and it does both pretty well. The AI is a bit weak but that's hardly unusual. There are plenty of customization options for your ship, and while the balance is a bit off at the moment and you'll get to the point where you're mass-producing things very quickly so customization can be more tedious than enjoyable (like naming ships), they are very nice things to have.

Something else that struck me is that the galaxy is very much alive. You will be bombarded with things happening in your empire - ski resorts being set up, restarting the gravitational spin of a planet, wormhole studies, pirate attacks, and just this great collection of events. There's not a 4X title out there that offers the same level of activity. There's also quite a bit of passive universe-building like ion storms and the 'grimdark traverse' with more than a few, not really terribly well concealed, easter eggs about other sci-fi titles. The AI, while not terribly smart or understandable, has great character. As a veteran of SD1 I had hoped to see a few more races but the existing ones are still very enjoyable.

Empire management is also quite cool. You can have different races within your empire, and each provides their racial bonuses (so an Opteris citizen will get its smart bonus even if you don't have that trait). I spent quite some time setting up a few foreign exchanges and giving each race its own planet. I would have liked the ground combat units to reflect the racial make-up of the planet, but that's a small thing.

If you own SD1 then picking up SD2 for 20 bucks before the discount disappears is a smart move. If you don't then waiting a bit to see how much patching Zero will do and how effective it is more prudent at $30. When it drops though, even if Zero hasn't managed to iron everything out, it's still a very good purchase. It's not flawless, but aside from the optimiziation issue in battles there's nothing in it that can't be relatively easily fixed.

Ultimately the flaws with the game are mostly down to balance. That's something that would not have been an issue had it had a longer, or more exposed (but probably not on Steam Early Access), beta period.



Edit: I forgot to mention the tolerance addition to diplomacy! In some ways it's a purely contrived mechanic, but how it ends up working is a really nice in-game restriction to prevent you from gaming the AI. Unfortunately diplomacy has some trouble at the moment (see above), but it's one of the innovations in SD2 that actually forces a different approach to the genre norm when it comes to interacting with the AI.

reviewText:
I'm really not sure why this game has 'Mixed' reviews. This is truely one of the better 4X games out there and definitely one of the best produced in recent history. I can only assume that at least part of that is due to the fact that StarDrive II is totally different than StarDrive I. I didn't like StarDrive I personally so I would say thats a goood thing. If you liked SD I then you may feel differently. StarDrive II is a true classic 4X space opera title.

Ship customization is a real standout with this title. You can pick all the systems from weapons, shields, hanger bays to powerplants, C&C systems, and medbays and place them on a wide variety of ship sizes and shapes. Which adds another minigame type aspect that is well done and adds to the enjoyment and variety of the game. Each playthrough you can tweak and scheme to build ships that are a little better.

The real-time space battles are great with a well done variety of weapon effects (lasers, projectiles, missles, point-defense, etc), the ability to launch fighters for defense or offense, give standing orders, manually direct ships if desired, deploy mines, engage planetary stations, zoom in or out, whats not to love here?

The atmosphere is engaging and quite complete with a solid and well thought out lore. The races have real 'personality' and quirkiness that actually makes them standout and be remembered long after you play the game. This for me anyway pushes this game towards 'classic' quality. The custom race generator is quite excellent and balanced and allows you to make well balanced custom races that cater to your own playstyle.

The AI is above average for the genre. Clearly if you, like many of us that enjoy the 4X genre, have been playing these games for 20+ years the AI will rarely 'beat' you but it will give you a reasonable challenge. I have not seen the AI doing truely stupid thing like sending fleets to attack fleets twice their size or leaving planets undefended as I have with other 'bigger name' titles.

The diplomacy system is well done with many options to trade; money, treaties, trade, technology, planets, etc. The diplomacy screen gives you immediate feedback of the 'value' of both sides trades so you can clearly and easily see the likelyhood of making a successful offer. The races traits even affects what types of goods/technology they value more than others. Well done.

The graphics are quite varied and interesting. Not ground breaking but well above average. Different races ships look quite different. The universe scale map is quite nice with attractive atmospherics. The UI is well done and presents all the information needed to make decisions in an attractive and functional way without menu surfing.

Planet development is standard faire for the genre with a wide variety of planet sizes, types, and environments. The varied environments interact with various racial abilities. Planets can be mono or multi-racial with associated ups and downs depending on your technologies. A wide variety of buildings can be placed to upgrade your basic production values of industry, food, reseach. Your tech tree selections provide more than enough options for specializing your planets and giving them different roles within your empire.

The tech tree is perhaps not as deep as some would like but it is more than amply long for all but the longest of games in huge universes. The mechanic to pick one of three techs at each technology upgrade is innovative and ensures that on each playthrough the tech is varied and plays out differently from game to game. The tech tree can be easily modded if you really desire more.

Some people complain about the ground combat but I actually find it quite a fun 'mini-game'; sure it's not C&C ground combat quality but its a great way to break up the monotony of moving fleets and setting build orders. It's 'fun' not 'deep and complex'. Many of the ground combat scenarios are interactive story missions giving the game at times an RPGesque aspect which is nice and fairly innovative for this genre.

The game is fairly moddable so I love being able to easily tweak and mod minor annoyances in ways I prefer. Compared to the many other recent 4X games this is the one I would recommend over many of them.

In my 80+ hours I have seen few (if any) bugs and the game runs extremely stable which seems to be a rarity in todays world of 'early access' drivel.

Overall, I strongly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the classic 4X space opera genre.

reviewText:
Having played Star drive 1 and loved it, I enjoyed the RTS style of that game but this one goes into turn based 4X strategy which is alot slower paced but more enjoyable i feel because i can sit back and think, and chill. I see alot of negative reviews about this game saying its too hard... Why would you play go into a 4X/Grand Strategy game wanting to roll over everything? Thats just not fun and pointless.

Pros
-Turn based strategy is a way better than the first game because i can relax and think.
-Hours of enjoyment simply designing ships to suit my enemies at the time
-Improved diplomatic options and tolerance system
-Improved Gfx and sound
-That moment of when you completly destroy your enemies. XD
-Huge gameplay improvements
-Way more technology and Research is now very interesting allowing for huge replayability
-Customizable Races also allows for huge replayability

Cons/Improvements I would like to see
-More Hotkeys/Customizable Hotkeys
-UI and Lack of control in the RTS battle mode. I would like to see the ability to right click drag to tell my ships how to face. Also things like hotkeys and control groups and the ability to lock your ships into a formation.
-There is a lack of new music and art assets ( but i understand its a very small team)
-Sometimes it is difficult to select and click on things on the map.

But all these cons i think can be improved and there had ALREADY been 2 patches in 2 days =D Overall i think this game is going to take over my life for the forseeable future xD

reviewText:
This game is nothing short of amazing, it is made by a small indie team (or is it just zero? i'm not sure) but it is just as good as other triple a 4x games.

The short answer:
my tactical sense is that of a large rock
war owls
machine gun dinosaurs
uplifting elephants

10/10

The long answer:

The Good: there are 9 races with unique traits and you can make your own custom race traits. The empire management is simple and easy to learn. The ship combat is a simple order you ships to attack this target or move here, BUT each ship takes damage to a certain part, front back left or right and once all the modules are destroyed, they can attack the core. Destroying the core destroys the ship. So you can maneuver your ships so that they last longer. The ship desgining is easily the most fun part of the game, you drag modules onto a layout of a hull and the positioning can change the part of the ship the shield will protect, the firing arc and more. There are also cool events that can happen, such as an infested ship or finding a planet of dragon people.

The Bad: the only victory is to exterminate all the other empires, and the AI acts like they know this. Diplomacy is tough, as the AI tends to ask you for your stuff and threaten war otherwise. Some of the races hull designs are certainly better than others, as the Kulrathi and Opteris Hive seem to have larger ships than the other races. Ground combat is kind of clunky and slow, and I find myself autoing the invasion, even if it makes me lose troops. The Mac version also crashes quite a bit, but it is getting less and less common.

BUY this game!

reviewText:
Having played Star drive 1 and loved it, I enjoyed the RTS style of that game but this one goes into turn based 4X strategy which is alot slower paced but more enjoyable i feel because i can sit back and think, and chill. I see alot of negative reviews about this game saying its too hard... Why would you play go into a 4X/Grand Strategy game wanting to roll over everything? Thats just not fun and pointless.

Pros
-Turn based strategy is a way better than the first game because i can relax and think.
-Hours of enjoyment simply designing ships to suit my enemies at the time
-Improved diplomatic options and tolerance system
-Improved Gfx and sound
-That moment of when you completly destroy your enemies. XD
-Huge gameplay improvements
-Way more technology and Research is now very interesting allowing for huge replayability
-Customizable Races also allows for huge replayability

Cons/Improvements I would like to see
-More Hotkeys/Customizable Hotkeys
-UI and Lack of control in the RTS battle mode. I would like to see the ability to right click drag to tell my ships how to face. Also things like hotkeys and control groups and the ability to lock your ships into a formation.
-There is a lack of new music and art assets ( but i understand its a very small team)
-Sometimes it is difficult to select and click on things on the map.

But all these cons i think can be improved and there had ALREADY been 2 patches in 2 days =D Overall i think this game is going to take over my life for the forseeable future xD
