reviewText:
Pretty good game overall. Somewhere in the middle between GalCiv (strategic, planet management), Sword of the Stars (combat depth with some physics) and MoO (ship design and management on MoO2 level). All in all, I'd say - It is very fun. Has a lot of small, nice events that add up to the general gameplay too. Tactical combat is interesting enough with ship design being amazingly fun.

That said, it has a little bit more bugs than you'd expect, and of a sort you'd not expect. Most notably:
- Fast fleets tend to overshoot their destinations - and then try to get back and overshoot again. This circus can for last a few turns if you're unlucky.
- You can't enter the purple wormhole right after researching it. Need to wait for a new one to spawn. And then to not overshoot it ;-)
- Very rarely, but sometimes you control the wrong ground force during ground combat.
- Very rarely, (happened to me only in corvette-only fights) forces refuse to engage and you do not seem to have control over any of the ships.
- Leaders appear so rarely that it's entirely possible to have a complete playthrough without ever encountering one
- A lot of the weapons are not really much of an improvement over their predecessors - effective dps seems similar.
- Auto resolving battles kills ships that would have not a single chance in hell of dying had the battle actually taken place.

I would also be happy with a bit more documentation on weapons while placing them in the shipyard. It's not trivial to remember at first which weapon is 'beam', which a 'particle beam' etc, and if installing, say, a particle capacitor makes sense for one.

The game's also a bit too easy. I have not lost a single game ever - even the new brutal modes seem to only give the AI more resources, but don't really make it any scarier. I think you can safely ignore any difficulty below 'hard' even on your first playthrough.

All that aside - I would recommend to friends. Which I am hereby doing. Cheers!
voteText: 15 of 29 people (52%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I regret spending opening price to purchase this game. It has so many bugs that I wonder of the devlopers acually played the game before releasing it. I have fleets disappering, invisible enemies, freezing and crshing on minimal settnigs, and that's just the tip.

The game itself introduces nothing new. it is essentially a reskin of its predecessor, but actally feels more limiting rather than less. Planetary governors have been removed, forcing you to micromanage every planet. Heroes were added, but barely rate a footnote. Espionage no longer has individual agents with their own names and rankings, Ground combat is clunky and frustrating, fleets will hover around, miss, or otherwise loose targets which you had ordered them to find, board, or engage, Diplomacy is socompletely unbalanced that it would require a separate review.

And then there are simple things, like persistant scenario memory, that further frustrate me. You spend time setting up the ideal scenario for your game and then for whatever reason choose to restart and have to do it all over again. There is no apparatus to save  races or campaign settings.

All and all, I was too frustrated to have fun.
voteText: 17 of 33 people (52%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Stardrive 2 is the game for you if:

1.You like a 'fast' turn based feel, don't expect to wait for minutes while ai's take their turns!

2.A true Master of Orion 2 successor, which you notice very well as you play the game. Lots of ideas taken from there, so you can adapt very quickly to the game. So if you like MOO2 you will like this game.

3. A nice ship combat system, really nice to watch, and you can actually apply tactics--especially if you design your fleets well. You won't just sit there and watch the battle happen. Unless you have a titan packed with mass drivers, defense guns,and a tough armor or shield.


4. Focus on planets has improved drastically, especially how population and building special buildings has a huge impact. Colonists can either be taking care of the food business, the production business, or be Einstein-tier researchers.

5. Customize ships. Shipyard is back, and while it isn't as free as Stardrive 1 the limitations are there because it makes the ship combat more realistic. Far more choice too with every component, want it to be armored-its going to be heavier,cost more, and take longer to build. Lots of different weapon options as well.


6. Lore, lots and lots of it. Also add to that the funny jokes and items you come across taken from many different sci-fi series

7. Enjoy mods, because this game is build to support plenty and plenty of mods. Star Trek mods are already on their way. Also, with the current game engine choice it's bound to look  good.

-----------------------------------

Stardrive 2 has innovated upon

1. Concept of freighter fleets is high in this game, don't remember if MOO2 has it though. So protecting freighter fleets is very important unless you want your empire to stagnate and crumble.

2. Simultaneous turns system,it's turn based with a realtime feel.I might be the only one that really likes this system though. Turns happen instantly,not many(or any) 4x games have such a quick turn system.Also, every empire makes the turn at the 'same' time more or less.


3. 3D ground combat, you rarely if never see that in a 4x game, while it is at the moment simple it has great potential.

----------------------------------------

Then again, the game could use quite a few improvements, but these are

1. More detailed ship battles, they are amazing as they are now, but nothing is ever perfect!

2. Better ground combat. Perhaps in a future expansion?

3. Better user interface in certain sections, speed timers in the battle interface?

4. Larger galaxies, 100 systems is huge but the universe is the limit!

---

Overall, great game-shines over its predecessor. A great single player 4x game, quite refreshing to see.

Added bonus, it's the first turn based 4x game to come out on gnu/linux!(as far as I know).

reviewText:
Pretty awesome to hear this starship and empire building game was created solely or mainly by one person. The quality is AAA all the way from the excellent animated cut scenes and incredible still art to the intensely helpful professionally voiced tutorial to the gameplay mechanics everything radiates superb polish.

Ship building is very exciting as one tries to see what is the best design for the job you intend to do. It is a major high creating a ship and seeing its purpose fulfilled exceptionally whether its for combat or colonizing or to transport workers and troops to another planet. There are also supply lines one has to keep open by avoiding enemy blockades as you will need supply lines to keep your ships fueled for the long trek into enemy territory to destroy their main empire planet.

Combat is tense and alot of fun as i was maneuvering my ships to avoid enemy fire while getting in the best position to do the most damage while being able to pause at any time to revaluate the situation. Winning commendations after a battle also gave a added sense of satisfaction after a victory over raiders or another empire.

Races are varied and interesting from the honorable shogun like bear race to the violent pyschotic wolf race. There are also space pirates to contend with which will harass your territories until you deal with them.

There is a vast research tree which allows for the discovery of many new advances from ships to making life easier for your planetary populations such as increased population breeding and stronger lighter metals for ships along with better handling power plants to keep energy weapons going along with many other discoveries just waiting to be researched.

Music and sound effects  have a excellent science fiction vibe creating moments of peaceful stellar harmony as you view the vastness of the space map or watch the humorous galactic news feeds. Many a focused moment i have found myself suddenly in a relaxed mental state taking in all the audio goodness with hypnotic futuristic music by the legendary likes of Isao Tomita. This combined with the soothing visuals made me feel i was back playing MASTER OF ORION 2 but with modern enhancement making for a smooth user interface experiance with excellent tool tips popping up revealing information on every single big and little thing happening on the screen. I definitely appreciate this and it has made my enjoyment of StarDrive 2 a much more richer experiance.

StarDrive 2 a spectacular over the top intricate yet easy to get into masterpiece thanks to its incredible interface of star ship combat and empire conquest where galactic catastrophies will leave you smiling in awe as empires rise and fall.

reviewText:
StarDrive 2 is just the kind of strategy that will keep you coming back for more. Every time you play you get an almost completely new experience. The research, galaxy generation, and the AI's make the game feel like there's is still so much more to the game. Not to mention the AI with the collaboration of GNN give the game charactor and purpose. It's always best in my opinion when you feel you are in the game and running a real empire.

The combat for space battles in StarDrive 2 is amazing. I don't understand why some people find that this type of combat is like Total War or some other strategy game, it's completely different, and in my opinion much better. When you want to take a break from Campaign, there is always the Battle Arena which places you in the combat immediately controlling an entire fleet. Ground battles honestly could use some work. When I went into ground combat, I felt suddenly seperated from the real game and I ended up feeling bored and the gameplay felt tedious. Ground combat is still an important function of the game so I hope Zero Sum games can change things up a bit in the future.

The strategy of the game overall is fantastic. I was placed in situations where I had to make difficult decisions for the good of my empire and these types of challenges are definitely what I look for in a 4X strategy game. For the sake of not revealing too much information, I will conclude by saying that Star Drive 2 was probably the best purchase I have ever made. The graphics are great, the strategy is amazing, and space combat adds an amazing twist to the experience. I recommend this game to anyone who not only enjoys strategy, but enjoy a replayable game that will provide you with with plenty of challenges. Enjoy

Worth Buying? Of course!
10/10 - Strongly Recommend

reviewText:
It's the best space strategy since Endless Space.

Nicely customizable ships with vastly different abilities and even some interesting tactical ground combat.

Game reliability has increased significantly since Stardrive 1 (I haven't even crashed once yet) and the semi-turn-based system does wonders for both late-game performance and an easier overview of your empire.

There are still a couple of balancing issues where certain weaponry is more powerful than it should be and the different hull sizes give certain races an advantage, but I do believe those things can be balanced given time.

All things considered, if you liked Stardrive 1 and it's potential - you'll love stardrive 2.

reviewText:
This is a game i really strongly recommend. Think of master of orion 2, and add all the new jazz modern pc games have to offer. What you get is this game, and if you liked the original moo2, you're gonna love this.

Now i've read the reviews before buying this game, and in most of the negative ones people cried about the game being too hard, about the ai cheating, about them dying the instant they meet anyone. I played the original master of orion a lot, and i must say that i had no problems holding my own. Yes, the pc is overagressive if he has a larger fleet. But as others have said in ther reviews, it is usually just a load of junk. Having a few decent ships, it was no issue to shoot that junk down and have enemy sue for peace.

There is one slightly irritating issue, although it's hardly keeping me from enjoying the game. The GNN and ground missions have text written letter by letter. I assume it's because my pc isn't top-notch anymore, but it takes ages for the text to appear, much slower than my reading speed anyway. And after a click it's gone. Now what i've seen in other games that used this letter-by-letter style is to use the first click to complete the text, and second click to move on. This avoids frustration in fast readers / slow pc owners.

In any case, if you liked the master of orion series and the original star drive, this is the perfect blend. Highly recommended.

EDIT:
After playing all the way through a game twice, I find it really worth the money. However there *is* one issue with planet management I see in late game - there are just too many structures I want to *build on each new planet*. Right now I avoid colonizing additional planets just because it would bring low benefit for much clicking - which is a wrong choice strategically.

A very nice solution I've seen in one of the fan-made old civ games is - *templates*. Imagine there are cca 4-5 templates defined (template 1, template 2, T3, T4, T5) and *the player choses what this template will build*. After that a planet can be assigned to 'build' template 1" and will start filling it's queue with stuff that is in template 1's queue.

Now the obvious advantage of this approach over ministers is that player has complete control over what his planets are building
date: while *saving tons of clicking*. Plus when a new building is unlocked
recommended: there's nothing easier to add it to template 1 and have all planets using it build it.\n\nExample of this template approach can be found in an old fan civ game "C-Evo"->menu->macro management->city types."

reviewText:
Maps should be bigger, encountered a bug where I started a battle as the enemy, some ship modules look exactly the same as others and/or the image was stretched to be blurry, ground battles need more work, AI are a bit too aggressive (why do they always demand tribute?).
I found myself wishing I could:
- Get a notification when a colony is building nothing.
- View what strategic resources do while negotiating with AI.
- View the base food and production I can reap from a planet that already has farmers / workers.
- Heal ground units when they're on a planet I own, you shouldn't need to research hospitals....
- Control ships in battle easier. You can only use special abilities with 1 ship selected.

Also the ammo used per second if all weapons fired at once" can be misleading. You could have a module that uses 100 ammo but only fires once every 10 seconds. It will show 10 ammo per second
date: but will never actually fire if you don't have at least 100 ammo capacity. You'll have to keep this in mind when building ships.\nDespite all these things I found the game to be fun. Maybe it's not compared to other 4x games in it's genre but this is the only one I've played. Considering it was made by such a small team (only one person?) I can look past things. It can be hard and confusing at first
recommended: but once you understand it then it's easier. Building ships is one of my favorite parts. I look forward to this game being further updated (there was already one). At least it isn't a triple A game asking for 60-70 bucks while hardly being a game.\n\nI would recommend to wait until it's on sale or improved upon."

reviewText:
9/10 would recommend.

I only say 9/10 rather than 10/10 because as of right now the numbers arent balanced very well. Higher tier weapons are actually a detriment and higher tier ships are a little too cheap to bring to the table. Both are purely numbers, though, and can be fixed very easily/quickly so that is the only reason i say its not perfect.

The new turn-base system allows much more relaxed play even in the late game. SD1 had a bad reputation for becoming a micromanaging nightmare late game due to the RTS nature it had. The people that say otherwise should go play Starcraft if they want a fast-paced RTS, not StarDrive.

Personally i love the new shipyard mechanics. Many complain about it because it removed a lot of customization with firing arcs and the ships are smaller, but i welcome it. I could spend upwards of an hour in SD1 designing a Titan ship because of all the firing arcs and power management it required. In SD2, probably 10min max. Much prefer the vastly faster customization vs the amount of customization.

Difficulty meters cater to a wide array of players. The Normal" can be rather unforgiving until you learn a few tricks of the trade
date: but theres a lot of ways to make it easier while you learn the game."

reviewText:
This is a great game, and stands well on its own, and I plunked 9 hours into it without even blinking.  That being said, this is what Master of Orion 3 should have been.  It seems to be extremely influenced by Master of Orion 2, and even the space combat, while real time, is vaugely reminiscent.

The original Master of Orion was my first foray into 4x gaming(Star Fleet and Star Fleet 2: Krellen commander being my first Scifi gaming love) and as such newcomers to the genre, or those who have not grown up with the unforgiving older 4x titles may find this game difficult on the normal difficulty settings.

This title brings back memories of gaming long since forgotten about, and does not incorporate a lot of the hand-holding of newer generation games.  Which I find refreshing.  I recommend this game whole-heartedly.

reviewText:
Still searching for the perfect 4X in space? Ya me too. There's lots to like about this game but the game still has a few warts.

Pro's:

1. Ship design and ship combat. Personally from a Realtime perspective I don't think there is a current game that does this better. If you like TBS combat look elsewhere but I think this game makes a valid case for the transition to realtime combat in space 4x.

2. Race diversity. I think the species that are in this game add a fair bit of flavour. I know the moo races will always have a special place in my heart but these are pretty good.

3. UI in general is clean and bugfree.

4. Planet management is decent and not overly tedious.

Cons:

1. Ground combat.....ugh.....its hex based ground combat. Why or why after making the wise decision to go realtime for space would the developer go with hex based combat? It's so tedious and not fun. Fortunately its not a major part of the game.

2. Diplomacy is rather weak in general. This is a flaw in many 4x games except for a few. This game is strictly centered around winning through attrition. One path to success. The game feels a bit linear in the approach in this sense.


Overall. I'd recommend the game but it leaves me wanting. Combat is great but Diplomacy/victory conditions are just as important and the ground combat is the bitter pill to swallow in between.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I strongly caution anyone from buying this game. I really wanted to like this game, and was pleased to see a Linux port on a space 4x-er. After 111 hours in I am going to be deleting this game from my library. I spent those hours trying to find the promise that drew me to the game, but was delivered in frustrating little bursts of mediocrity: diplomacy, ship design, UI, land combat, and ship combat are all poorly executed. If the developer had put in the consistent work and updated the game maybe this game would have reached its initial promise. Instead, the game feels like an orphan, and a developer with a past who seems to spend more time defending himself in forums then making a good game. Again.\n\nFor a contrast, check out Hearthlands (a totally different game) for a game that popped at the same general time as Star Drive 2. Look at how many updates and changes this game has gone through, and how much better a game it was then a year ago. And all those updates have been free. I am just pointing out the work by the developer, not the quality or genre of the game.Too bad for Star Drive 2.  And when Stellaris is released this game will be a memory. I will probably never buy a game developed by Daniel DiCicco again. Burn me once, burn me twice...

reviewText:
Star Drive 2. Turn based strategy, real time combat. All of the original races are back along with a new race. Very good game.  There Can Be Only One! No alliances here, but you can butter up your neighbors. If they cask to trade for a really good tech, give them something lower and avoid diplomacy penalties by getting a diplomacy bonus! Trade and Non-Agression treaties can buy you time.

This is a game where you need to build colony ships for each colony you want to colonize and there are three population tasks - Food, Industry and Research. You can even move population around.

Food is available across the Empire - provided you have freighters (easy to build). Everything is handled by the game for your freighters. Poor planets give the same amount of money as any other, however, production suffers. Research is great! The larger your Empire the more expensive research is. There are research fields, and you only get one item from the list of three. You can trade or maybe capture the other items.

Races are neat. Each is different with different traits. Racial traits for the playable race can be adjusted. This is Way Nice!

Combat is pretty neat. This game does not have as many ships as Star Ruler 2, both games are very good. There is also ground combat, so bring troops!

The only negative I have is that in the late game things slow down. However, the developer has stated he is working on improvement in this area. That will be good.

Star Drive 2 is a really good game, it is very similar to Master of Orion 2, and I think even better. Do not listen to the negative reviews, Star Drive 2 is a very good space 4x game.
voteText: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An awesome game in the same lineage as Master of Orion 2!

The game looks fantastic, both the 3D and 2D assets. It's fun to just sit back and look at the pretty map, or watch the space battles.
Except if you just sit back you may well lose. How you approach combat matters, as does ship design. If you like to get hands-on with your ships, expect to spend a fair amount of time designing them.
Sound design and music are very satisfying. Everything sounds right, which goes a long way towards selling the game.
Interface is informative, understated, and polished. It avoids the overly minimalist interface of Endless Legend, but doesn't distract you either.
Empire management is understandable, but hasn't been dumbed down. It's very similar to MOO2.
There are some bugs, but the game continues to receive updates after its release, and nothing I've run into has made me regret buying the game. I'm very excited about the new DLC, and I intend to purchase it soon. Do bear in mind that the developer is basically a single person; this isn't the product of some big studio. One advantage to that is that the developer has responded to player requests; larger galaxies were asked for, and were delivered, first in a free patch, and then even bigger ones in the DLC.

reviewText:
Update 6:
The real review: the game is, as of patch 1.0d everything that has been promised.

The new research-system and exclusive tree is pretty amazing, makes you think what is best for your empire, but not just now, as well as in the future. Trade and negotiation becomes essential to acquire tech, especially espionnage =3 (all you diplomacy-enthusiasts)

Planet management is extremely nice, smooth and intuitive. It is some kind of known system, but it fits well in the game.

Troop management and equipment adds an individual aspect that I have never experienced in a 4x game before (I played most, beginning with Space Empires IV).

The turn system is pretty much the manual version, in my point of view, of the predecessors 5 sec turn instance system. With 8 AI enemies 5 turns, as for my machine, are 5 sec in sum. When needed, this system provides you with planning-possibilities you might and/or will need.

To criticise, in my experience, is the 8 ships only build list. You can edit it, ok, but I do not like to manually swap the updated designs for the older ones. Stardrive 1 had the better system with actual and obsolete designs, autoupdates and (for me) never ending design list to choose from.

Update: After long hours of intense gameplay, i came to a different understanding. Unique ships are worthy units. You bild them once, they remain in service till they are destroyed or dismissed. Mainline battleships are build often, destroyed often, and updated regularly. Even a humble frigate becomes the cornerstone of a fleet, advances through the system of achievements, collects experience and becomes even more valuable; even a carrier can have experienced fightersquads that are much more survivable and do a better job than freshly produced ones. This feature requires some micromanagement, but time is not a matter.

Now for the games key feature: Ship design

Everything matters now, not just the sum of components. You can armor them, outfit special characteristics.... Range, angles, everything matters now. Weight and other subsystem-characteristics are detailed and explained within the editor, so no more one-shot ships that need constant supply because their reactors are woefully underrated (engine rating should at least equal power consumption rate). Unfortunately, as of this build, the powergrid system (a rector only supplies power within a limited range) is lost.

Damage is applied to different sectors of the ship, is one gone the ship or station is as well.

I am continuing to play, have not encountered any bug within 8 hours of gaming.

Till the next update!

(Playing United Federation)

reviewText:
First game, lasted only 30 minutes due to starvation and pirate fleet attacking my underwhelming fleet.
Second game, Did better as the Vulfur (wolf guys) and started to capture planets and systems but met the humans, was promply eradicated.
Third game, made a tiny map to think it would be easier to expand....I was wrong.
Forth game, made a medium sized galexy and set it to 4 races, they gang banged me into a corner but I proudly held them off. Was killed later by crystals.
Fifth game, started to learn the basics of the game at that point and got into the groove of it. Managed to control half the map till pirates started to attack my homeworld from the edge of the map, couldn't get there in time and soon whole race died.

Eventually I'll be able to win one game but even still, I'm having a blast playing it. Sure, it may be a dumbed down version of it's first title but thats good for someone like me. I feel this game appeals to both hardcore 4X gamers and those just starting out. For me, its a must buy and sure, there may be other 4x titles out there but that doesn't mean this isn't a great game either.

P.S. I know I don't have a lot of time in the game. It's due to my college work but I will be spending a lot more hours in StarDrive 2.

Contrary to what you may read from the many trolls and haters griefing about StarDrive 1 this one-man-developer obviously deeply cares about the games he creates. This is a man who has the education and CV to earn significantly more money in his original job and gave that up to follow the dream of making his own game(s). I kinda envy him for that courage. StarDrive 1 could not be further developed because Microsoft ended support for the still flawed engine it was based on. StarDrive 2 is different with the departure from realtime but IMO more true to the original vision and a great advance on Stardrive 1.

This game was released as  a fully functional version more mature than too many AAA titles and the developer has been quick with updates containing bugfixes

I enjoy this game. I really do.

However, there needs to be a big disclaimer here...

As of May 18, 2015, I would NOT categorize this as a release worthy game. It still feels VERY much like an Early Access game, complete with all the bugs and unfinished features you would expect from such a title.

If dealing with Early Access issues is not your thing, DO NOT BUY. At least, not until it can more properly be considered a release title. If you are good with Early Access issues, then go for it.

reviewText:
Hi there,

there was a point where I had given up on the game, yet hoping it will be improved. While lurking the forums I saw Zero takle some of the community requests and decided to give the game another chance and purchased the DLC.

The reason I still can not give this game a positive review is, because it's a buggy mess. My major issue was, that some major mechanics problems and bugs haven't been fixed in the Vanilla game before throwing out the DLC.

The DLC has changed the mechanics and added some new content but it's still a buggy mess. Recently I have encountered bugs that make the game unplayable and that after such a long time.

Instead of making a pay for DLC for 6 months, Zero should have been fixing the game implementing player requests and ppromised things such as Workshop and Mod support.  Then release a DLC, but no, a DLC +old bugs and now even new bugs.

I regret my purchase of sector Zero and can not recommend the game untill all these issues are fixed and the game actually reaches the end of it's BETA stage it is in.

reviewText:
Star Drive 2. Turn based strategy, real time combat. All of the original races are back along with a new race. Very good game.  There Can Be Only One! No alliances here, but you can butter up your neighbors. If they cask to trade for a really good tech, give them something lower and avoid diplomacy penalties by getting a diplomacy bonus! Trade and Non-Agression treaties can buy you time.

This is a game where you need to build colony ships for each colony you want to colonize and there are three population tasks - Food, Industry and Research. You can even move population around.

Food is available across the Empire - provided you have freighters (easy to build). Everything is handled by the game for your freighters. Poor planets give the same amount of money as any other, however, production suffers. Research is great! The larger your Empire the more expensive research is. There are research fields, and you only get one item from the list of three. You can trade or maybe capture the other items.

Races are neat. Each is different with different traits. Racial traits for the playable race can be adjusted. This is Way Nice!

Combat is pretty neat. This game does not have as many ships as Star Ruler 2, both games are very good. There is also ground combat, so bring troops!

The only negative I have is that in the late game things slow down. However, the developer has stated he is working on improvement in this area. That will be good.

Star Drive 2 is a really good game, it is very similar to Master of Orion 2, and I think even better. Do not listen to the negative reviews, Star Drive 2 is a very good space 4x game.

reviewText: This is a very good game, I must admit I only have about 6-7 hours in it, but everything I have seen so far tells me it is an excellent 4X. And that is my final point, I think Zero is comitted to this title so I think the long term support will be there.\nGreat game, well worth the price and Sector Zero enchances the game greatly.

reviewText:
An awesome game in the same lineage as Master of Orion 2!

The game looks fantastic, both the 3D and 2D assets. It's fun to just sit back and look at the pretty map, or watch the space battles.
Except if you just sit back you may well lose. How you approach combat matters, as does ship design. If you like to get hands-on with your ships, expect to spend a fair amount of time designing them.
Sound design and music are very satisfying. Everything sounds right, which goes a long way towards selling the game.
Interface is informative, understated, and polished. It avoids the overly minimalist interface of Endless Legend, but doesn't distract you either.
Empire management is understandable, but hasn't been dumbed down. It's very similar to MOO2.
There are some bugs, but the game continues to receive updates after its release, and nothing I've run into has made me regret buying the game. I'm very excited about the new DLC, and I intend to purchase it soon. Do bear in mind that the developer is basically a single person; this isn't the product of some big studio. One advantage to that is that the developer has responded to player requests; larger galaxies were asked for, and were delivered, first in a free patch, and then even bigger ones in the DLC.

reviewText:
Pros:
- MOO2 Rip-off: This is better MOO2 than the original MOO2 ever was. Basically all of the orig game mechanics are there, but all of them are slightly enhanced (in the way that you think this is what is should have been in the original). Some of the mechanics seem to be new (ground/troop combat), but overall, very good design and approach for those players, who strive for a new and deep MOO-type-of-4X-game.
- Very good overall graphics/sound design: Light, but effective, pleasing one's eyes. Some menus are very well organized so e.g. the empire management is thus very effective, even with lots of colonies.
- Very good ship designing: Create multi-purpose or very specialized ship designs; mix fleets in a way that fits your gaming style. In general, there is a great variance of ship's weapon and module types.
- Good ship2ship combat/battles: Ship design plays a big role in combat, but certain tactics are necessary and are a definitive advantage. Still, tactics are not the core of battles, it is mainly techlogies and ship design. Ships get various medals/bonuses for certain combat achievements and retain these for life; these are also upgradeable. Battles are also very well graphically designed to please one's eyes. Thus, some battles can be quite epic.
- Well designed diplomacy: You know exactly what they think about you and why and what you did good to help the relations, what you did bad to harm them. You know exactly where your current diplomatic limits with each of the races are. Spying is yet another game concept which reminds of good old MOO2, but is nicely extended, so that a player has a better control of offensive actions.
- Additional in-game candy: You can build Space/refueling stations whereever you need them on the map. Exploration of space anomalies - some trigger combat, some additional research; all provide various in-game bonuses and content. Various planetary enhancements, generated randomly ad-hoc as a result of certain long-term situations (sport resorts, merchant guilds, private shipyards, ...). Space-creatures. And a dark story, affecting the whole galaxy...

Cons:
- Diplomacy: Despite diplomacy being very well designed and informative, it seems its purpose is not to seak diplomatic victory in this game (e.g. a concept of permanent alliances is missing). Diplomacy does not need an ovehaul, but an extension to have even more possibilities.
- No SpaceStation designing: This is a minor" issue; but not possible to create customized space station designs. Neverteheless
date: space stations use the best tech the player has available.\n- Groud/troop combat: Although developer put quite an effort into modelling of this concept
recommended: it is a bit dull. It has a great potential
hoursPlayed: but it feels like it does not work as originally intended. This is overhauled in DLC.\n- MOO2 Rip-off: This might not be ideal for players ho seek new
voteText: unorthodox approaches to 4X gaming.\n- Some bugs: From time to time
helpfulPercent: there are small bugs/glitches in the game
votesHelpful: usually not gamebreaking
votesTotal: but sometimes quite annoying. The number of bugs went down quite a lot just before the DLC release
votesFunny: on the other hand
commentsCount: DLC release might have introduced new ones. Anyway
column16:
the (only) developer is working to fix those too.

Verdict: 8/10
Very good content
column17: sometimes spoiled a bit by occasional bug. This is an excellent 4X MOO2-like space strategy game
column18:
probably the best one out there.

===========
Get the DLC!
- More exploration / remote mining of more resources.
- Nebulae
- Bigger universe

reviewText:
I want to love Stardrive 2.....

It has personality in spades and it is really immersive, more so than many/any other 4x game that I have.

However it frustrates the hell out of me to play it.  The AI is super agressive from the get go so its usually a struggle for survival from the outset so there is not a lot of time for development (the 4x part), you end up having to follow one quite specific path to get through the beginning and its a military approach, many of the quests and missions are interesting but there are a limited number, you usually need to do them to survive the early game and this detracts from replayability.

Lastly, ground combat is not great but many others have covered this. It could be an interesting enough little mini game on a mobile phone, but compared to the ship customization and the superb realtime 3d ship battles, it does not really fit the grand scale of the game.

However obvious limitations aside, there are glimpses of brilliance in Stardrive.

I really hope the new DLC's adress the problems because if they do this may well be my favourite modern 4x space game.
voteText: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After having seen the troubles surrounding Stardrive I & II, I was still curious and picked up Stardrive II on sale.

Long story short: don't let a lot of acid and bile on the forums stop you from trying this. The series has a troubled history, but denying yourself is only punishing you. I don't know what really happened, but people get REALLY pi**ed off on internet forums - we know this - you'd think they spent their life-savings, their left hand and a firstborn child on it or something, rather than a handfull of quid (I picked it up for a little under seven).

Its not perfect, but it has all the solid staples of a good 4X, is very pretty in parts and has some unique selling points of its own - the ship designing is fun and effective for example, and the turn system is different.

It *is* a bit too obvious what television programmes the developer likes to watch though... Gold-pressed Latinum? MalFillion? Breaks the fourth wall a little.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Really like it, it has some issues when it comes to the AI and diplomacy in my view, the fact that a race tries to get as many techs out of you as possible and then declare war on you just because you took 2 planets in your own influence zone is weird, there is no point in dealing with diplomacy.

The AI is way to aggresive, and there is no other options then waging war on eachother, hoped for more diplomacy options like alliance would be nice. If you are in the middle and gets sorrounded by enemies then you are more or less screwed.

The good point is the combat, really fun. When a faction delcares war on you, there is this arms race that is a load of fun, atleast for me. Gets destroyed by rockets one battle, and then refit your new fleet with anti-missile defences, and wreck them. Small things like that really makes the game really fun. But I get the feeling that the AI don't change much, after refitting my fleet with anti missile defences, they still used them, which is kinda weird, especially after like 8 big battles.

And the customization of the races is fun, but it feels lacking at some parts.

I would recommend this if you are a really big fan of Sci-fi strategy games, but at the same time, I would not recommend this over games like Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion though.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a fan of StarDrive 1 and someone who's played a fair share of 4X games I can't recommend this game to most people.  I think there are a select few 4X players who won't be turned off by the overbearing management required to win in a campaign.  I am not one.

StarDrive 2 is very tedious.  There is a lot of variety in what you can do, what strategies you use or ships you build.  This game does a lot of good things, but nothing extremely well.  The RPG aspect, planet management, tech trees, diplomacy, and ship building are a positive.  Ground combat was definitely improved with the DLC.  Space combat however is its major weakness.  Both the actual battles and preparation for them, are lopsided.  It's the most frustrating aspect of the game.

If you are a 4X fan, and see something in this game that makes you want give it a try, by all means do.  However, I don't think most gamers in general would enjoy StarDrive 2.

By the time my fleet arrived they had taken my planet and a awesome real time battle ensued. i wiped out their fleet in a spectacular battle. i then recolonised my previously own planets, they sent another fleet. i wiped the floor with them again. it was awesome then the deplomacy window popped up they were begging for peace and friendship, as we were good friends before i forgave them, but next time they betray me i will wipe them out.

Space bears

cons

over all pretty awesome game as good as any AAA game if not better, it's like total war in space. I'm a huge total war fan although Rome 2 was a bit Naff. If your tired of creative assemblys ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bugged releases and fancy a change in setting give this one a go. It's ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.

reviewText:
This game is pretty fantastic.  I am a fan of space civ / tactical combat games.  This addresses both of those categories extremely well.  The space combat is VERY fun.  The variety of races, abilities, ship weapons and modules, and technology is IMPRESSIVE.  I have spent a lot of time on this game in the last 10 days.

The only complaint I have... is the end game goals are not clearly defined. I beat the massive Master ship, and was encouraged to retire... but saw no in-game way to conclude the game.  Seeing empire stats, and numbers comparing my empire to my competitors would be a really nice thing to have.  I felt underwhelmed, and somewhat unsatisfied with just quitting.

Will I play again?  Yes.  Do I love this game? Yes.  Could it be even better? Yes.

reviewText:
After my negative review of Stardrive 1 I thought I'd review this to set the records straight, this game improves on SD1 in every way, every little problem I have with the first one is resolved and more:

+ It's stable! Not a single crash, laggy moment or instability.
+ The research system is vastly improved and adds a few features I've not seen in a 4x game, including a system that makes diplomacy and espionage very important.
+ The ship varieties are nice, the game is very pleasant to look at.
+ There's even a little X-com like tactical game for your ground troops
+ Random events and regions of space can trigger special research projects that can help your empire
+ Freighters and cargo transport has been hugely streamlined, this used to be very frustrating in SD1 having to micromanage all of your freighters.
+ Good variety of planet features that give extra depth to the colonisation system including some nods to classic sci-fi.

All that being said, there are some things that could have been done a little better:

- The sound design suuuucks! from random 'sci-fi beeps' on the tactical map and cheesy 'pew-pew' noises in battles, the sound design could have been so much better, honestly can't remember what the music is like other than I turned it off pretty quickly.
- there is a max 100 system limit. the galaxy doesn't feel particularly big, gets crowded quickly with more than 3 opponents.
- A couple of balancing issues could use looking at

All in all though, this is a solid 4X game that improves greatly on it's predecessor, pleased to have bought it.

reviewText:
closest game to master of orion 2 i have seen so far. Since this game is like a remake of the all time classic I will compare the two games

Originally written at release, edited on release of the DLC

Pro:
-It does have a great economic system that is heavily inspired by MoO2 and even improves the former ones.
-The Space fights are Top, also the Ship desgin system
-Nice Graphics
-Really good strategic space map and boarder simulation (Note: got even better with recent DLC)
-random events with some story

Neutral:
-early random pirates can really hurt and bascilly trough the game, so u HAVE to prepare before expanding
-the diplomacy has the potential to shine, but it needs some more tradeobject. like force someone to declair war to someone etc.
-the UI is not as compact as MoO2, and could need some more links and detail tooltips


Negative:
-Like MoO2 it still has some bugs BUT the dev is stil actively working on the game (as of 2016 still active, just released an DLC)
-german langunage is partly bad translated, better play in english
-you feel like with some final relatively small adjustment this could be the best 4x game ever. (with the recent DLC this is even more true)
-I dont like the ground battles. (its like a streamlined XCOM). I feel sorry for the dev since u can see he invested quite some time to develop this. It just doesnt works out that good in a game focused on space (THIS IS FIXED WITH THE DLC's new ground combat system!!)

Total:
I enjoy the game, and I am looking forward to every patch from the dev. If you liked Master of Orion than buy this. Some points Stardrive2 does better others MoO2.

As of 2016 with the recent DLC, this is the true succesor of MoO2 and the very best 4X available at the moment.

reviewText:
So, I'm a very old gamer, but I've never written a Steam Review before.  This game needs more good reviews, so I'll make it my first.  As a veteran of every major 4x and strategy game since I played the first Civilization as a teenager, Stardrive 2 stands out as a real gem.  Major pluses:

+Depth and complexity in race and game setup without endless sliders and checkboxes.  You have several meaningful choices, which can be combined in complex ways to make for a very different play experiences, but customization isn't a total swamp of minor adjustments.

+The planet characteristics (Size, Type, Gravity, Mineral Abundance, Strategic Resources, Special Features) can be combined in an absolutely cool and endless number of ways to create a very unpredictable variety of planets.  This makes for great choices to make on the strategic map.

+The graphics are effective and evocative, and the game text and lore have a sense of humor matching the gamestyle.  This is an unusual and really beneficial thing - too many games have beautiful art that's not so evocative, or err on the side of grim-and-serious when that is not a needed aesthetic for their other choices.

+Ship design is fun, deep, and offers many ways to optimize your ships together or individually, while refit system encourages you to redesign when needed without a major gameplay penallty.

+Battles are pretty, quick, and offer an appropriate level of micromanagement.  They break the turn cycle with a real-time experience, tracking individual ships with medals and such for accomplishments is also a nice touch.

+Tooltips abound, meaning the complex mechanics can be explored and understood easily.

+Ongoing patching seems to indicate developer involvement and dedication.

+Diplomacy system uses trade, different weights for different groups and players, and a tolerance" mechanic in an effective and interesting way - but see below for critiques of diplomacy.

No game is perfect
date: though:\n\n- UI could use improvement and efficiency
recommended:
with better keyboard commands and such.  This includes things like idle planet notifications.

- More and more interesting random events are needed to keep the universe outside of the AI players more alive.

- Some races feel less balanced than others
hoursPlayed: in the area of advantages and ship designs.  Same with weapon designs.\n\n- Total randomness of setup can create very unfun initial game conditions
voteText: or conditions where you don't realize how much better other player's starting areas were until you're already a ways into the game.\n\n- More diplomatic options and win conditions could make this feel more like a "complete" 4x game.  The AI's tendency to want to kill you at first sight could also be watered down a wee bit
helpfulPercent: at least for the 'not genocidal' races.\n\nThis is not a complete review
votesHelpful: just a few isolated thoughts."
votesFunny: true

reviewText: this game build on predecessors like Sins of a Solar Empire or Imperium Galactica II to create an amazing 4X strategy game that stands out all on it's own.  there are plenty of different races (9 I believe), all with pretty unique traits.  only one race doesn't seem that great.  the diplomacy is top notch, something most games is this genre struggle with.  this game also has ground combat (think old school x-com), something most of the games in this genre do not have.  Some of the random events that occur in campaigns require you to do things like attack a pirate base with mariens to stop their raids, or clear a derelict of hostile aliens to acquire alien technology.  these random events, combined wiht the fact that each races AI behaves differently depending om their racial traits make for a very replayable and divergent game.  which alien you first contact can totally change the way your game unfolds.  Last but far from least, the ship combat in this game is pretty darn good and strategic, and it hinges rather heavily on designing your own ships.  you have different ship hulls ( you start with 3 and can research more) and can outfit different variations for each hull to serve different roles.  what is really cool about this is that it creates incentive to actually buld carrier battle groups with escorts and the whole 9 yards, very cool.\nIf you love strategy, or space, get this game!

reviewText:
As an avid fan of Stardrive 1, I had high standards coming into Stardrive 2. I was surprised to find that the game had changed from a real time strategy to a turn based format, although space combat still happens in real time. The turn based format does not hamper the game flow however, and Stardrive 2 is just as fun as it's predecessor in terms of a space 4X Game.

Pros:
-Diplomacy system is greatly improved from SD1
-Space combat is simple, but effective. Your ships will have multiple weapons and can engage multiple targets at the same time.
-Ground combat is now a turn-based system, unlike SD1's Land troops on a planet and cross your fingers" system.
-Ship Building has been simplified but still very easy to grasp.
-Unique missions and events featuring neautral factions keep the game interesting.
-Interesting and diverse factions with different personalities. Factions with similar personality traits get bonuses in diplomacy.

Cons:
-The game can be very hard for players not familiar with the genre.
-The game does not tell you if a planet is sitting idle and not constructing anything. This results in lost production so it's important you keep your build queues full.
-Less ability for automation compared to SD1. For example
date: you cannot tell your scouts to Auto-Explore
recommended: or your ships to defend an area."

reviewText:
OK, Bought it and have played about 30 games. In a good game, my empire doesn't get squashed 20 turns in from making first contact and it reminds me of all the good parts of Masters of Orion.

But the really sucky thing, is that there is a game stopping BUG (and I do't mean an alien bug) when your fleet destroys a large enemy fleet of small ship. A list of the destroyed small ship names appears on screen and doesn't go away. Effectively Game Over! This especially sucks because it happens when your empire is kicking ♥♥♥, a rare event.

So, overall, excluding the BUG which must be fixed, I give it 3.5 stars out of 5. And, with practice, you can learn which weapon and armor techs work best and actually kick ♥♥♥. Plus NEVER sell the good war techs your enemy doesn't have, but that is just  common sense, not a problem with the game.

As far as game management is concerned, their MUST be a central ground troops load out screen for the entire empire. I can't tell you how many planets I have lost because I forgot to upgrade the troops.

With some more TLC and the BUG fix, this could be close to a 5 star 4X game that runs on mAC!

reviewText:
There are a lot of negative reviews of this game that based solely on the fact that it's 'rock solid' and 'unforgiving'.

IT'S A 4X. WHAT DID YOU EXPECT?!

Seriously though, this game is wicked. It's a vast improvement over its predocessor.

What I love the most about this game is that the developers have taken StarDrive (1) and gone back to the drawing board with it; keeping in the awesome and cutting out the naff.

My number one hope was that they would keep in the awesome races, MoO ship customisation and the battle screen. Done.

What I hoped they'd take out was the Gal Civ-esque 'real-time turn-based' time progression - which was both infuriating and rubbish. Done.

The new focus on diplomacy and the ad-hoc intergalactic economy that it creates is really cool. I love that making friends with the AI is not just a pointless sideshow. If you don't play nice with them, you can't trade for those sweet sweet techs that you didn't pick in the new research tree (which is great as well) and your holla dolla generation just tanks if you stay isolationist.

That being said, the AI can 'play nice', but it's my experience that it comes down to what race you're trying to suck up to. If the race is hellbent on galactic domination and keep on asking you for tribute and gifts... OF COURSE THEY'RE GOING TO END UP INVADING YOU.

I have had a couple of freezes on the loading screen, but honestly - it was twice in 15h of playtime, which is a damn-sight better than some games on release.

I love that this game isn't an 'early access' title too. It's something that really put me off of StarDrive (1) which ended up with me only putting a few hours because of how buggy it was.

I wholeheartedly look forward to where the devs take this game. I'll happily pay for any expansion they come out with.

reviewText:
Stardrive 2 is a very deep, turn space managing game. The battles are very well done as the ship fitting system. The experience levelling of ships is also very interesting, made by levels and medals that give you bonus in battle. The game is more about managing the fleet, create good fittings, managing planets and expanding. Diplomacy is quite fine and the gameplay can be very deep. The ground battle could be improved, maybe doing it a bit quicker, or make the troups auto-fighting. The core and best aspect is to me the fleet battle where you can pause the fight and study a good strategy, according to your fleet composition / fittings. Technology tree could be a bit more clear, but is still working fine. Defenetly if you liked Galactic Civilization 2, you must play Stardrive 2. I feel is a naturale improve of GC2.

Pro - Deep ship fittings system
- Nice battles to watch and manage
- Good longevity, replayable
- Very nice system of levelling of ships, with medals according to kills/assists and Xp
- Good map generator

Con - Not 100% customizable faction
-  Battles on ground are not so enjoable as space battles
- Still not enough mods

reviewText: Review is current per ver 1.1a\nWith the latest patch fixing many gameplay and bug issues this is NOW a awesome game with a ton of potential down the line with easy moddability.  SD2 Combines the best parts of Moo, Moo2, Gal Civ and other 4x games. The crown jewel of Stardrive has always been the real time space combat and SD2 does not disappoint. The combat is now faster, yet with more control, more streamlined and less frustrating YET more complex with more tactical choices in battle.  Choosing the most optimal Strategic counter response to threatening enemy fleets can win or lose the game. In a recent game I designed a slow, heavily armored and shielded fleet to demolish a Vulfar massed frigate/CRV  swam only to have a another race tear my primary fleet to shreds from all the way across the battle map with long range stand off missile fleet.  SD2 has  By FAR the most engaging and fun tactical space combat in any 4x game.  -1 point for some lingering bugs/ AI issue/ things need to be fleshed out (occasional Crashes)  but with future mods an patches this game will deliver me (and any 4X fan)  years of fun.

reviewText:
This is a gem of a game.

A steep learning curve and a few combat & diplomatic balance issues mar an otherwise delightful exercise in grand and tactical strategy.

Space is unforgiving in Star Drive 2. A wrong choice can cost you a planet in the the blink of a few turns, and random alien and pirate attacks are only slightly more dangerous than your own poor choices when it comes to colonization, research focus, and ship construciton.

My favorite thing about this game, and I why recommned it to any 4x-Space fans, is that Star Drive 2 comes closer to modeling real space colonizization (at least the way I imagine it) than any other game of this type that I've played. Despite the seemingly small number of star systems, space is big and you don't have enough ships to protect all your borders. As with other excellent military strategy games, SD2 starts you off with barely enough power to defend a single front. Overextension is as a dangerous as too little expansion. And if you designed your ships poorly, well ...

Beyond the challenging strategic (and tactical! w/ ground units) military aspect, the game has a difficult, frustrating, potentially rewarding, and potentially disasterous diplomacy system. I love it. Never has a game come closer to modelling something as futile and hair-pulling as real international diplomacy. Some of the time, you can get 1/4 of what you want, and it usually comes at a cost that makes you nervous about repurcussions down the road.

The writing is funny. The tech tree is challenging, rewarding, and full of great literary and film sci-fi references that made me smile. The music is solid, and the map is pretty. Races can be customized, and difficulty can be greatly upscaled to match increased knowledge of the game's tech and combat loopholes. All of this to say, re-playability is high.


TLDR:

This a funny, atmospheric, and surprisingly difficult game that required me to think more than most 4X games.
Once I stopped being mad about dying more than usual  XD  I loved it.

reviewText: Amazingly fun game.  While people complain that it is bad because it isn't like most 4X games, they are wrong because it is trying to be something else. If you are looking for real time space battles where you design your own ships, have good visuals, and decent strategy map then I highly recommend it.  Ground combat could use some work, but you can just auto resolve all of them and focus on space.

reviewText: This game is awesome! Super fun, super difficult, and super addicting. The ground troops building is very confusing. They appear when you build an infantry base, but the number varies and the time to spawn or if they respawn is not obvious, still good though. However the space AI does odd things. 386 command point fleet (chukk) crossed open space on cluster map and snipe colonies. They have about 14 colonies. I have more colonies and I have about 33 command limit. Now you can build past your limit, but it is expensive so I really have no idea how they are not bankrupt. The only thing I can think of is that they don't take upkeep on their buildings or they don't pay penalties past their command limit. The devs have said that the AI doesn't cheat and I believe him, but I just can't believe something glitchy or buggy isn't happening. By the way, this is on easy difficulty as well.\n\nQuestions I would ask are, does the AI suffer attacks from random events, remnant, crystal ***holes, and pirates and do they follow the fuel rules? Is their a cheat to toggle fog of war to see how the AI is doing this, and how do I take a break from playing this amazing game without withdraw symptoms?

reviewText:
A lot of good features from the first game.

Would like options to custom the design of starbases, or at least better information on what its current stats are.

Several bugs encountered, however massive improvement over first game.  I have yet to actually crash or be unable to complete a game. Auto saves and Prebattle saves insured impact was minimized.

Large battles could use optmization, however even though things slow down, it still works, which i call a winner so far.

AI clearly is able to bypass some of the limits in the game.  Fuel, CP limits, constantly nagging you for tech in diplomancy, so you can never actually build up points to ask for large, if you decline to trade you still lose points to ask for what you want later.

Late game the AI does not seem to have the ship designs needed for combat against high tech ships? Seems to spam low tech instead.

As with Stardrive 1, no real late game closer.  even on tiny galaxy, 40 systems, spreading domination across the map can take hours, though you've got death fleets moving in all directions. Just turns into an exercise in OCD.  Its like tracking down coch roaches.

Leaders don't actually manage, or build ques.  More then 10 coloneys there should be profiles for building things on each world.  The bigger it gets, the slower... kind of the problem.

Some things in the game arn't really clear... Whats on your starbases, what zombies do, rugs?, Infected planets?, space highways how to, what guns do what and fire at what. How many things you can build on your planet??

The shipyard needs a SIMULATOR, so you can test your design.

The big black ship on the other side of the worm hole is a beast, that was fun.  But thats it?  I was sure i would get something to help me kill everyone with.

The game is either too easy, or hopeless, or just too long.  Fun is shortlived once you start wining.

The fun is really in watching your ship designs work.  I honestly believe the future of gaming is in here somewhere,  When a game lets you design the content, but we are still a long way off.

Look at Reassembly, its single player, yet incorporates designs from other players into the player's experience... Seems like this would be a good idea here to apply.  The posiblities of ships and designs are more then 1 developer could ever come up with... what if the AI used valid designs from other players in its war effort?  Things they have the tech for from a pool of player made items?  You'd never know what to expect?

Ultimatlely I feel like this is a more finished version of Stardrive, the first game was commonly reguarded as unfinished, and as someone that put 100s of hours into the first game, I feel the game is unfinished, yet still had potential.

Stardrive 2 should be considered Stardrive 2.0 not a continuation of the game, but a more finished version of the first game.  It feels like the developer took what he learned from the first game, and improved on the game.  Discounting it for those that bought the first game, good call. Clearly Zero has put in a lot of work on this, and deserves a pat on the back, because this is far more then just an update on his first game, he's completely over hauled it.

Combat optimization, maybe some PLayer AI assistance both in combat and in over all map control could be helpful.

Ground combat is my only real beef with the game, its just bad in many ways... needs to be more like fleet battles, like a RTS when it goes down. and NEVER AUTO ground combat... really just dont.

Conclusion...

If you like 4x, pick this game up... the art work alone is great, I honestly love the aliens.  You already know what to expect from other 4x games.  Music is pretty good... bugs sure, but the developer seems to be addressing things harder for his new baby.

What else are you gona do?  Go outside?

reviewText:
Absolutely love the game.  The turn base aspect is a great improvement and it really gives you time to think.  One of the best features that I like is being evil actually has amazing benefits.  By making a race that can sacrifice people for research and money, taking the trait that allows me to assimilate other’s tech when I conquer them, then researching slavery and xeno assimilation.  Wow, I just advance up the tech tree.

I can walk into a solar system with my fleets, slave the enemy planets down to 1 population, capture the planet, get two technologies, and then all along the way be sacrificing my slaves for money and tech.
Once I have an enemy planet, I can just start cloning the population and sacrificing them.
Money, technology, and power come through slavery.  Other games have had the ability for you to “say you are evil”.  This game has captured the essence of being able to actually choose between what is right-“good” and what is easy – “evil”.

And the difficulty level! Horray for a challenging 4x game that will actually destroy me the more difficult it gets.  Rather than just being a milk run, I have to think, adapt and change my strategy.  If I have picked a bad strategy, I find out fast when I lose!

MOO was amazing, Space Empires V was fantastic.  Ever since those games I have been searching for a 4x turn based game with depth and replayability.  This game is exactly what I have been looking for!

reviewText:
Star Drive 1 was better. This one doesn't feel very unique. It's like Galactic Civilisations 2 lite. It tries to do a bit of everything in GC2, but doesn't excel in anything.

Prepare to go to war from the start of the game. There is no diplomacy in this game. AI will come knocking as soon as they meet you.

The space combat is average. Not like the first game where you can have hundreds of ships duking it out.

Ship design is like the first game. But your choices are simpler because you're not faced with as many units as the first game. You just have to kill whatever is in front of you before they close the distance to your ship, so mounting an array of long range rail guns and flak cannons (for point defense) = like shooting fish in a barrel.

The ground assault is meh. It's like XCOM but there isn't much variety in units, gear or abilities even with full tech research. The limited amount of troops (only 4 units) permitted in ground assault is a let down. I ended up bombing from orbit rather than deal with the frustrating ground assaults.

Planetary invasions are buggy. You clear out the sector of enemy ships, but then you can't invade or bombard. The only way is to leave the system and come back and try again. Annoying.

For $20... its ok. Not great but ok.
voteText: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Played, or at least tried every 4x Space Genre game for many many years.  As an original founder waiting patiently for Gal Civ 3, I was anxious to give SD2 a spin for something to do while waiting.....

Now this is a first impressions review and I have not logged many hours yet, but that said, first impressions are pretty important and SD2 made a good one with me.  So far I am lovin it!  I found it easy to get in to and was quite impressed with the interface and game systems.  Its clean and plays well.  I like the spin on a the tech tree where you have to choose a single tech in a given category/level and can only get the others in that category/level through diplomacy or espionage.  Decisions decisions!  I also really like the ship building.  Here again, many decisions to be made yet the construction interface is easy to use and makes sense.  More decisions when it comes to expansion and building.  I found that the normal 4x land grab rush may not work as well here due to various encounters and mechanics.  It can be pretty dangerous right out of the shoot even close to your home planet.  A more planned and thoughtful build/expansion strategy is required.

At the end of the day, I find the games mechanics to present many more meaningful decisions than some of the other 4x space genre fare out there.  Kudo's to the SD2 team!  Looks like you might have a winner!

reviewText:
One of the best Space 4x games yet. The ship/hull outfitting and customization is 2nd to none and is my top pick in that category on a 4x no holds barred wishlist.

Stardrive 2 is Master of Orion 2 remade with Stardrive integrated into it. And its all done extremely well. His politics and bargaining system is quite ingenious in preventing the typical barter everything at once exploit that no one else (of whose games I've played at least) has manged to do.

Combat is pausable real-time and what you outfit your ships with and  how you use them makes a difference. Same goes for ground combat which in most other 4x is largely ignored or marginalized.

Modding support looks to be great (I'm not a modder but already upon release theres a good playable Star Trek mod in progress)

The only area where some other 4x games have over this is victory scenarios other than all out total conquest. Thats it. Graphics, depth, ship/hull customization, ground combat, thought out diplomacy. This game has a lot! It may not score perfect 10s in ALL categories, but it does is some and high 8s or 9s in others. I highly, highly recommend this space 4x!

reviewText:
Disclaimer, I am only 5 or 6 hours into the game.
Wow, I was not following this game but i happened upon someone's let's play on youtube and here it was. This is a very well done remake/remaster of Master of Orion 2. Most elements are similer but very few are out right the same, and in every case i have seen they surpass the original. The fact it was mostly made by one person should shame AAA companies who have tried and failed with this genre for decades.
Well done sir, you will go far.
P.S. I normally do not buy new releases but wait for the price drop. No need here, support this man and maybe he will grace us with another gem.

reviewText:
The amount of content that is taken from previous games makes this both a attraction and kind of a hum drum. If you played the older games in the past you are looking for a modern version of them. This feel more like a remake than a new 4x.

I like alot about the game, and if you are looking for that feeling of MOO2 but more modern this gives you some of that. There is no multiplayer. And Ground combat is lacking... Bugs in the game make i difficult sometimes...

Arena seem to harder than expected, or I just lack understanding of how it works.

Overall it is worth the money, and if you are looking for a quick get away / reminder of the past it is great, but don't expect to have a full blown balenced 4x. Its just not there yet.

reviewText:
TL;DR - Overall the game was worth it for me, I think they got the pricing right on this one. Hopefully they patch some of the problem areas listed below.

The game is fun, interesting, and quite challenging at times. I enjoyed it, until I beat it.

Pros:
-I liked the diplomacy in this one with the 'tolerance' limiting your trades
-Ship design was a lot of fun
-It was fun to micro the ships in combat
-the tech tree was cool.

Neutral:
-The number of high-quality planets (i.e. planets that grow food) are quite low. So the game does sort of stove pipe you into some tech decisions.

Cons:
-Very large battles take FOREVER to process even with a decent computer.
-The end game needs some work
-no technological victory. If you are playing on a large universe you have to hunt down every single occupied planet. Quite a big turn off for me after being in such a dominating position.
-The above point really drags down the replayability for me.
-Canopy shields OP.

reviewText:
Keeps the ship design and awesome combat from StarDrive one, but with a turn based strategic map.

Added ground combat which is pretty dull, unless you liked the new X-Com - it's similar to that. If you auto-resolve the AI loses a bunch of guys when you'd lose one or none at all.

Depending on the race and traits you pick, your style of play will vary greatly. Even the enemies you fight - if they prefer to use fighter swarms, missiles or energy weapons.

Still an awesome game, more polished and focused than the predecessor.

Edit: The developer has been patching the game every 2 days since release, good support so far

reviewText:
If you like 4X games and a extremely difficult learning curve, this is a game for you.

Reasons:

1. Depending on your starting race you have an advantage instantiously when it comes to being able to colonize planets and expand so you can sustain a larger fleet.
2. If you pick a race that is inherintly needing a terran environment or a Human environment, good luck. I have done twenty random huge maps and in general you will only get your starting homeworld to being specific to your needs and maybe find 1 or 2 more planets that work for you. If you find more the NPC has already claimed them and is already about 10 more solar systems farther then you are.
3. The NPC is very advanced it seems. In the first 40-50 turns I was being invaded and I know it takes 23 turns for me to build my own frigate class ships yet the NPC had 3 of these along with a command point structure of 18. I personally haven't been able to figure out how this is possible. Also the NPC had 5 colonized planets which lead me to believe that even in Normal difficulty you are handcapped and the NPC is given an advantage.

I recommend this game not for the MOO2 similarities but the fact that is was a close remake of a genre of games I used to play from when I was 5-6 (MOO) all the way too now. It also tests you to see how to best start your first 20 turns and how to also judge and gadge what the NPC and what quests will help you in the long run.

A definite must in my opnion is that the tutorial needs to be better for people not willing to learn by failer.  I personally find this game frustrating and find my self restarting every 2 or 3 hours of gameplay because I was to slow or I never did enough diplomacy so that I could stay with the technological curve of things.

There are many more blemishs but also postives about this game. Those were what I found to be the most annoying so if you are not willing to play through trial and error for a few hours or even maybe days until you figure out what works just for the one race you keep playing, then this game is not for you.

reviewText:
The game got off to a rocky release, with some annoying bugs and some game balance issues.
Now tough most of that is fixed. Combat AI could be better, but i'm still not sure if that can be tied into lackluster AI ship designs.

The only thing missing is some more diplomacy fixes\options and a bit more game balancing and i'd say that would be pretty much it.

Even tough this might sound negative, it's not meant as such, as the game as it is, solidly stands on it's own and will provide dozens of hours of 4x fun. The developer has also already mentioned in posts that he is working on diplomacy and balancing.

As it is i would give it a solid 85% and recommend buying it. Tough for those on the fence, or those that don't really know what the game is about, watching some lets play on youtube is always good before making a decision.

reviewText:
Brilliant.
Played Galactic Civilizations III for 30 minutes, having been a fan of the previous games.
Bought StarDrive 2.
Far more love, care, passion and attention to little details went into this sequel. It is a true evolution of the previous game, an improvement and new direction in almost all aspects. For the better. Something which a previously mentioned high profile 4x title did not deliver.
StarDrive 2 is not a reskin of the same game with merely .ini mod-level changes.
It is a completely fresh redesigned game, and a bloody brilliant one at that.
This is the Master of Orion of the modern day. The dev finally got it right after the first game honestly kind of was a beta experiment.

Buy it now, if you are a fan of 4x games, such as Galciv, Distant Worlds, MOO, Armada or Endless Space.

reviewText:
Let me preface this review by stating that I'm a huge 4x turn-based fan (I've already pre-ordered GalCiv 3).

After making the horrible mistake of buying Worlds of Magic, I was looking for something to tide me over and I'm pleased to report that StarDrive 2 is quite satisfying.  I love the fact that one of the nearby civilizations picked a fight with me (Normal difficulty, first playtrhough) as I am tired of passive turn-based games where you can turtle, out-tech, then curbstomp the awful AI.  Reading all of the complaints that the game is too hard is what drove me to purchase StarDrive 2 as I was leery of another Indie developer releasing garbage like Worlds of Magic.

Edit: Another 10 hours in, and a few more great features.  Random, interesting events much in the vein of Masters of Orion and the infantry combat (capturing planets and other stuff) is turn-based with complete manual control.  I do find myself a bit overpowered with this but I love the addition!

If you are a fan of Galactic Civilizations, you will very likely enjoy StarDrive 2 -- this should last until GalCiv 3!

reviewText:
I read alot about people saying this game is too hard and how the AI is too agressive.
Well, to be succesful in this game, u need to understand how ship design works. its not that hard to figure out and its alot of fun, the best ship designer in any 4x out there hands down.

If someone says the AI is too hard on easy setting he has obviousely not understood some of the crucial mechanics!
(many of those reviews have less than 10 h gameplay which kinda says it all)

Now to my experience:
Pros:
-The game mechanics are strongly inspired by moo2 and it could easily be considered the first true succesor
-The graphics are pretty and the alien races have alot of character to them
-Shp design is super fun and meaningful, way more compelling than any other 4x
-The AI is pretty good which is a huge deal since its a SP only game and thus will add to replayability alot
-The game is, unlike many other games, in a polished shape in terms of gameplay and stability. It hasn't crshed a single time for me
-The developer is passionate about this game and working dedicated to make it better

Cons:
-Ground combat can be tedious and auto resolveing it can lead to bad results
-Compared to SD1, ships are smaller and the designer is more streamlined
-No MP yet (i think there is a fair chance that we get it later though if the game is succesful)

8/10
Could become a perfect 10 with more content, mods and MP
