reviewText:
StarDrive 2 has gone a slightly different direction than it's predecessor, which has split it's fan/player base somewhat.  To understand why some people don't enjoy this game, one needs to look at an overview of the first StarDrive game.

StarDrive 1 was a Real Time with Pause 4X space game.  It had a well crafted ship builder (one of my favorite aspects of the series), a streamlined planet management system, and entertaining combat.  It's biggest flaw was its bugs and engine issues late game, and the developer team discontinuing updates due to difficulties with the Unity engine.  That said, it was still an above average game in it's genre.

Along comes StarDrive 2, offering a more traditional Turn Based approach (though it's made to progress turns rapidly until something interesting happens).  Changing some of the aspects of the first StarDrive (though keeping the excellent races, lore, ship building, and real time combat), StarDrive 2 aims to mime Master of Orion 2.  This to me, is a good thing, as MoO2 is a classic for a reason, that hasn't been remade.  If any 4X game is deserving of a modern revamp, it's MoO2.  StarDrive 2 gets a lot of things right in it's tribute, and a few wrong, but is a very solid game overall, and aims to better itself over time.

StarDrive 2 does have it's share of bugs (currently), but it's developer is releasing patches on a regular basis to try and fix these, as well as rebalance passes to curb the difficulty spike (or easiness spike, depending on who you talk to) that many have experienced while playing.  So long as the team keeps at it's current rate, this will be an overall better game than the prior version.

Pros
---
+ Great ship building system
+ Real Time Instanced Combat looks clean and is uncomplicated
+ Follows the Master of Orion 2 template almost tick for tick
+ Events and Quests add spice/lore
+ Thematic, enjoyable music fitting a space empire
+ A new addition to diplomacy that limits player abuse while keeping it interestering
+ Unique races that each lend their own personalities (and in some cases, unique playstyles) to the game
+ Samurai Space Bears...

Cons
---
- UI could use a few more tooltips and usability changes (ship management for example isn't overly informative)
- Space Combat could be spiced up with more things to do / active abilities
- Ground Combat gets tedious fairly quickly and could be spiced up as well
- Auto-Resolve is currently terrible for both Space and Ground Combat
- Only one victory condition (extermination)... would be nice to have some more common 4X conditions like tech, diplomacy, etc... other ways to win the game other than wiping out all your enemies (though that is fun)

* Note: This is strictly a single player game, and while this has been a note of contention for some, shouldn't bias the game negatively.  That said, multiplayer would be a nice addition if another StarDrive game is made, as that is becoming fairly staple for the modern 4X genre.

In conclusion, StarDrive 2 is not without it's faults, but Zero Sum have seemed to have learned from their mistakes of the first game and have crafted a better product as a result.  While not for everyone, StarDrive 2 delivers an enjoyable experience to 4X fans that can easily keep you playing just one more turn.


TLDR: Different than the previous game carrying the StarDrive name, but better in just about every way (unless you really liked the original being Real Time).  Modern remake of Master of Orion 2.  Real Time Space Combat, Turn Based Ground Combat, Turn Based Empire Management.  Though it still has some growing to do, it's definitely a Recommend.

reviewText:
As a veteran of Imperium galactic series, Galactic Civ, and SD1 as well as a few others I have to say StarDrive 2 holds its head up high among its piers.

the gameplay is fresh yet familiar. I have to admit I was leery of the new turn based system but in the scheme of things it makes sense and it's a welcomed addition.

Currently I've restarted the campaign 3 times as I wrap my head around some of the new mechanics and because my poor human civilization was blasted to death by alien scum - which means either I'm terrible at this game or it's hard, which is awesome!.

The graphics are beautiful, especially the way space combat looks, the planets are all awesome looking as well, the new hex system and fresh.

The mechanics of researching and building your fleet is pretty much the same as SD1, which is a good thing.

Space combat is enjoyable and satisfying, nice big explosions and a slow motion mode too! One gripe I have in space combat is that weapons don't lead targets, they aim at where the target was, not at its expected position. Missiles don't turn to intercept targets instead they make weird turns trying to catch up to it... it all feels very unnatural and I hope it's addressed in a patch.

When it comes to planet colonization, the variety of planets is massive making the whole experience of picking and choosing where you want to focus the new seeds of your civilization as engaging as it is important.

I like the way they've handled the freighters. Moving food and colonists around really saves us from a lot of the needless planetary micro from SD1. However freighters are not controllable, combine that with the smaller fleet caps and it makes it difficult to protect freighters when your main fleet is off attacking or exploring, they will literally fly directly at an enemy and suicide themselves. We should be able to control freighters, either directly or give us the ability to force them to dock at the nearest planet until the enemy fleet is taken care of.

Fleet Caps: I really don't see the point of fleet caps. Since each ship has an upkeep cost which in itself is the fleet cap, to compound that with an additional cap to me seems redundant. I like the idea of the fleet cap but instead of having it give you a monetary penalty, it might be more interesting if it gave you a penalty to ships rearm and repair rate, maybe even a damage dealing reduction to ships. Reasoning being they just aren't receiving the maintenance they should.

Ground combat. The research and upgrades aspect of it is well thought out and implemented however the actual ground combat is meek, it needs a re-tune. If it would have followed in the footsteps of Fallout 2 or X-COM it would have been amazing! But currently, weapons have a hard limit of minimum and maximum ranges,

Covert Ops: Works similar to the first one, but different enough to be fresh, that being said I think it needs a re-tune. I have 5 spy's doing counter espionage which is the max and I'm still getting tech stolen from me every few turns, which is really quite frustrating. Perhaps remove the spy caps for home defense?

Spatial anomalies, these are quite fun and new, really enjoying them so far and is a very welcomed addition.

Interface: interface is well designed, lots of tooltips and the information is easy to understand and readily available in most circumstances. A few gripes I have, on the planetary screen, when cycling from planet to planet via the arrows - every time you click to go to a different planet, the arrows location move to a slightly different spot, making cycling planets in this way annoying, and dizzying. If a fleet is hovering over a planet, the planet under the fleet becomes un clickable, there's also a few other minor annoyances that needs that little bit extra polish.

Overall, StarDrive2 is an engaging experience and I will surely play many more hours of it as I attempt to conquer the universe however as much as I like it, it's not quite there yet. everything seems 70-80%. It just needs one more good thick coat of polish to make this game really shine

reviewText:
First off this game is difficult.  I think it could use some scaling back on how challenging it is right out of the gate. There have been some minor changes to the ship design that are a tiny bit irritating (like that you can't dictate your firing arcs of your weapons other than upgrade the arcs to be larger) .  The ground combat can be clunky at times.

Now having said that:  The game is a BLAST to play. I’m having so much fun with it.  There are a TON of scifi references to discover. The ship combat while still not 'perfect' is organic and you can win or lose a battle based on some micro managing tactics.  (which is nice) .  I'm having a ton of fun and have mitigated some of the difficulties by playing on easy mode and reducing the galactic threats.

Anyone who enjoys Space 4x games should enjoy this.

Challenging but fun.


Added:  The game isn't really difficult persay.  It just has some wonky pacing that one some play thrus will pit you against (non AI ) random opponents that most games wouldn't have you encountering until mid or late game.

reviewText:
Game is great!!!

It's back!
I don't believe it.
It's back....MOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO 2 is back.!!!

Back with a vengeance! Mixed in with XCOM and Stardrive. Awesome!
Finally somebody, has been able to fill Steve Barcia shoes. Cudos to Daniel DiCicco".

This is a thinking person's game.

Don't change anything with the AI. It's great.
It's tough at first but that forces you to analyze what you're doing wrong.

This... THIS kicks your brain around and forces you to analyze your strategic thinking.
There's no cheating by the game that I can tell going on here.
Everything is out there in the open and logical.

You must study.
You must observe.
You must remember.

You can study your opponents equipment on their ships before you go into battle.

The man has written and entire holographic simulator to test and evaluate how all the equipment you're researching works.  And most importantly how that equipment works with other techs added on.

I get the same old lost in the game feeling here as I did with MOO2.

And the same: "Just one more turn" syndrome as well.

It's like I've just met an old friend!

Live long and prosper mates

reviewText:
If there is one big flaw with this game, it is the total lack of Multiplayer. There are not even space or ground skirmishes against other players (at least as of 1.0c). This is a pure Singleplayer vs AI game. If you want Multiplayer strategy, that princess is in another castle.

For the rest, it takes some of the best concepts of other (indy) games. The game plays on 3 areas: Galactic, Space Combat, Ground Combat

Galactic:
Is turn based on a 2D map.
The colonisation and colony building closest resembles Civilisation for me. Other liken it to Master of Orion, but I have not playe that series. It focuses more on few, well developed colonies with the right buildings.
It borrows planetary effects and random events/miniquests from Galactic Civilsiations.
You can freely pick you fleets destiantion (no squars/hexes), but fuel greatly limits range outside of your territory.

Diplomacy has two unique turns:
1. The evaluation mechanic is open, with the game actually telling you leader personalities and the weighted values of diplomacy items.
2. The tollerancy mechanic means you cannot simply ignore negative relation modifiers or past deeds of the AI. Your people are a factor too and just won't allow certan deals to happen.

Research:
You can only research one tech per Tier" giving you some hard choices and you have to aquire the others via espionage or diplomacy.

Space combat:
Is realtime on a 2D map. It closest resembles space empires for me.
It seems to focus more on decisive
date: large scale battles rather then skirmishes.\nShip design is also seems heavily borrowed from SE
recommended: but simplified. Facings matter. There is few geartypes/hulls and almost no levels
hoursPlayed:
but there are lots of modifiers (1-4) you can apply to nearly every item.
Upgrading and retrofitting is seamless.

Ground:
Turn based on a isometic
voteText: square based map.\nBattles are fought by small elite teams or "boarding parties" rather then large armies.\nTroops can have up to 3 abilities (active and passive
helpfulPercent:
with cooldown or without) and based on technology and events you can almost freely choose thier gear while at a planet.
There is no boarding outside of events.

Documentation:
There a lots of tooltips and spoken/interactive toutorials.
Tech descriptions for new ship modules are often quite vague wich can result in picking the wrong tech."

reviewText:
I really like SD2 and do recommend it!

pros
1. I have read what other people say but i really do like the space combat. Its pleasing to the eye and real time.
2. Designing your own ships is a blast.
3. you have to make almost painful choices when choosing tech just like MOO2, and planning ahead is important. i really like that kind of choice in a game thats why its a pro although some may not like it.

cons
1. some bugs/glitches but when is a release not bugy even for AAA titles - this is one guy cut him some slack the game is still very much playable/ enjoyable
2. ground battle needs a lot of work it is fun at first but can become very repetative quickly dev really needs to work on this its probably the worst thing about the game so far
3. AI can somehow support enormous spy legions that will steal your tech quickly makeing it almost impossible not to spend a lot of resources on anti spy measures this is probably how the AI knows what when and where everything you have is located
4. a little overpriced



In conclusion this game is a lot of fun but a little overpriced, IF FOUND ON SALE DONT MISS IT!!!!

reviewText:
Stardrive 2 is amazing in so many ways. The scale and diversity of the gameplay is fantastic. The integration of space battles, land battles, stragegic play, creativity, DESIGN! diplomacy, both realtime and turnbased aspects is something from a gamers dreams. The fact that this is mostly one mans creating is mindblowing. Stardrive is mechancially more ambitious than AAA games like civilization finding a perfect ballance of deep mechanics but simplistic and easey to undersand delivery. Here are some examples of thigs the game encompasas: optomizing planets for specific puposes (food, production and science mainly) which gives them strategic value adding to the turnbased strategic play. Engaging in diplomacy and espionoge to try to give yourself an advantage over the other free-for-all combatants in the galactic rat race to the top. Taking the information you learned to design ships that help you to win the real time battles. Control of space allows you to transport your  troops safely to take the enemies planets in turn based tactical battles. Now that you have a planet we are back to the beginning although ingame you can have at a hundred systems with nine races to do this all at once with. So cool, soo much fun.
A few things worth noting:
The AI is pritty good not terrible!!! unlike other  AAA strategy games which is a huge pluse
The diplomacy is really well done and ballance except on brutal difficulty where it is supposed to be hard
The facty one person made this sometime shows with minor graphical buggs inconvienances like things on top of each other
The ground battles are not super fun and easily the weakpoint but still not terrible or even without stragety just not geat, I suggest using auto rezolve as there is little point to many of the battles where one force is 3 times the strength of the other, however I have had some tense battles that were importand and I was trying my hardest to win against poor ods.
Load screens can be slow and performance although improved is not amazing, of course that is in battles with thousands of units I was able to run this on my gpu-less laptop
Buggs happen but not too much.
There is a learning cuve and you will loose some games which is a good thing. I think some people get angry with this game because they don't understand this kind of strategy well enough and perceve the game as unbeatable or think the AI cheats like crazy. (In this type of game, difficuly has to be added in the form of better AI start locations, More units at start and lots of modifiers to their economies).

In conclusion this is so worth the money if you have any interest in any kind of strategy or 4X games. It is challanging in many ways but fairer than many strategy games. Designing ships is soo cool and addicting and the realtime battles where you get to put them to the test with your own skill commanding is just and amazing gaming expeience. The ground battles are the weakpoint but can be dealt with with bombing and then autoresloving the boring ones. My number one complaint is that there is no multiplayer not because the AI is bad my any means but because the gtame is soo enticing to my strategic side and creates such epic situations that I want to have that experience in a free-for-all galactic war with my friends.

reviewText:
I was able to pick up this little gem for $10 on a steam sale.  I played for about 100 hours and enjoyed the game thoroughly.  It may not be as grand as some 4x's but it is well made and worth what I paid.  As of today the developer is still active and fixing some of bugs in sporadic patches.  He apparently is working on new DLC or version.  I didn't seem to encounter or notice any bugs in my gameplay hours.  I had no crashes, just the program slowing some as I conquired every planet in the galaxy.

I played the humans during my play, other alien races are available and will be encountered and negotated and fought with.  The gameplay is not complex but has similiar depth to the old master of orion series.  Space combat is real-time that can be paused.  Ground combat is representative and turn based.  Difficulty can be selected from easy on up.  There is minor races to conquer and you can, if you wish, enslave other alien races to speed population growth and production.

The game captured enough complexity and depth of gameplay to hold my interest (not the easiest task since I own hundreds of steam games)....researching that next beam weapon or device to bombard the enemy planets with.  Perhaps, building new ships variants which are more powerful and faster.  Something always kept me engaged.  Ignore the board trolls, for some reason this particular steam board was inundated with them? Most have had nonsensical arguments or some wacky agenda now that I've actually played and seen the product for myself.

I would recommend giving this title a try for anything under $20 US dollars.

reviewText:
StarDrive 2 is so much fun - it feels like a much newer version of Master of Orion and totally worth it. After 127 hours I definitely haven't explored the entire game, but I do feel like I've exhausted most of the appeal. Hopefully they'll fix a few of the things below and then it will be even more awesome.

***Things I've liked about it***

You can customize your ships by placing individual components onto the hull at different locations, and you have to consider the cost, power, weight, size, and hitpoints of different systems. Not all the components are the same size/shape, either, so designing a ship is a lot of fun.

In battle, ships acceleration matters - you can't accelerate to maximum speed instantaneously and can't turn immediately either.

There are many styles of weapon - beam weapons with essentially infinite speed (but still limited range), artillery with long range but no guidance after they're launched, and rockets with good range that home on enemits, plus many, many other weapons and/or variants.

Ground combat is interesting and doesn't feel contrived - there are lots of different weapons, and the units have actual coordinates during ground combat, allowing for more strategy.

You can customize your race at the beginning based on whether you want to boost research, production, combat, and lots of other things. Each race also has a few race-specific technologies and/or abilities that can't be customized and add a little more flavor.

The tech tree is interesting because there are several branches that are independent. Also, each branch has tiers of three technologies where you can only research one of those three technologies before moving on to the next tier. This leaves you to get it from another race (by trade, extortion, spying, or assimilation), or to live without it.

***Things I don't like about it***

The battle arena prepares you for a much harder game than this actually is. Once you design a sufficiently good ship to win the battle arena, that ship is probably roughly 12 times as powerful as another AI ship of similar cost, and then the normal game gets pretty easy (you can build no military, wait for them to declare war on you, and then quickly build a ship to wipe out their entire fleet by the time they arrive). The way that I'd like this to be fixed would be for the AI to more clearly pay attention to the kinds of ships that it knows/expects that you have, and to build ships designed to beat those ships. I'd also like for it to design slightly better ships in the first place.

StarDrive 2 has the same problem as lots of empire-building games where as your empire grows, it takes more time to micromanage all of it if you feel that urge. Unfortunately, if you don't assign a planet to build anything then it doesn't build anything, and the game doesn't remind you that some planets aren't building anything. There are notifications when a planet finishes building its latest building, but sometimes those notifications dissapear if other things are happening in that turn too. The way I'd like this to be fixed is first for the turn to not allow ending if planets are idle, and second to allow the user to set a default build order that planets follow if they have no planet-specific orders.

The AI doesn't know how to evaluate the ships that I build. When I try to autoresolve a battle, the AI is much more likely to favor the opponent than if I were to actually fight the battle. That's understantable, but it's unfortunate when combined with a bug where in some battles (perhaps 2%), if you click to fight the battle then there never appears the button to actually start the battle, and the game is then stuck. Usually this can be fixed if I reload the game from a save, but not always.

When forming a team for ground combat (which is a lot of fun (unlike what I expected); good job guys!), sometimes characters will be designated as starting the battle with fewer than their maximum hitpoints. This can be reproduced if you have two preset loadouts, one having the Bone Weave attribute and one without it. The steps are 1. Restore the character's equipment from one preset loadout. 2. Restore the character's equipment from the next preset loadout. 3. Toggle the presence of the Bone Weave attribute by clicking manually. Note that now the character's starting hitpoints has adjusted by 20 (positive or negative depending on which way around the loop you went). It looks like someone else noticed this at http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=422949843 and was even able to make a unit whose starting hitpoints was negative (presumably by going around the loop three times)

The zooming could be a bit smoother - I wish that the zoom would spend less time animating and instead would adjust more quickly.

Sometimes colony ships will get stuck on the strategy map and won't respect orders to colonize the planet that they are at, but if you tell them to move away from the planet and move back to that planet then they are willing to colonize it.

The AI's don't have as good of an alignment between their diplomatic goals and strategic goals as I'd like them to have. Mostly it feels weird that they tell you upfront how much they value each technology, but they don't adjust their valuations based on circumstances. I've been able to give some unimportant economic technology to an enemy who was about to take one or two of my four planets in exchange for a peace treaty that bought me more than enough time to build up a much bigger army. The AI diplomacy doesn't really bother me that much since it's a very hard problem, but it's still another opportunity for improvement.

In some special-mission ground combat battles (but none of the important planet-taking or planet-defending ones - don't worry) , the zoom prevents the leftmost column of squares from being visible, so I can't select my units and therefore can't fight :(

reviewText:
Overall I give a positive review of the game. Is it perfect?  Well no, but it still gave me several dozen hours of fun (and the developer intends to support the game further).

The game's biggest flaw is that as it stands (and this is intended to change eventually) there are only two victory conditions (one official, one secret that says you won when you beat a final boss encounter).  Diplomacy as it stands cannot be used to form long lasting alliances and the end goal is always conquest.  The player can mentally set their own goals, such as controlling and containing all threats, or getting friendly with as many other civilizations as possible, but there are no built-in alternate victory conditions yet, and the ability to win by forming an alliance would add another facet to the game.

The ground combat has a very mixed reaction.  Personally I like it, but I can see why some do not.  The developer does want to improve this eventually.

Just like the first game, ship building is a huge aspect of the game's fun.  To summarize, I think it's a really good game but focuses a bit too much on the aggressive side of 4x play, but as I said the developer is accepting feedback and does want to fix that.  I do not feel an imperfect situation is enough for me to give a negative review.

As far as how the game looks and feels, for the most part I think it feels quite well done.  Perhaps my play time speaks for itself.  My stance is if I put this much time into the game, how could I at least not recommend it?

reviewText:
I would love to recommend this game, but I can't. While I was a huge fan of Stardrive, the sequel just rings hollow.

The first title was born of Steam Early Access, and gave the developer a large swath of suggestions, criticism, and feedback during its cycle. The developer would later make it pretty clear that he wasn't terribly fond of getting feedback during development, that there were too many voices in his first game and chose to develop Stardrive 2 behind closed doors.

Unfortunately, this is the result of a developer and his hubris stuck in an echo chamber. There's no one to point out flaws in design, resulting in poor decisions being reinforced as good ones inside one's own head, where they become entrenched.

Ship design is still good, but not quite as dynamic as SD1. There's far less freedom to build.  Faction customization is expanded. The tech tree is improved, but still not great and leader missions are fun the first time, but grow stale.

Outside of that, everything just falls flat. Ground combat is half-baked. Colony management interface is poor. The AI leaves a lot to be desired in both strategic and tactical combat (mathematical advantages are applied to make up for it). Diplomacy is even less useful. The move to a turn-based strategy map has taken away the immediacy of naval engagements.

Even with all the bugs, which I can forgive, this culminates into the two most damning critiques of this game:
* The game is shallow and has no spirit.
* It's flat out boring.

reviewText:
IF you keep hearing comparisons to the Civ or Gal Civ series then ignore them, this is a very different kettle of fish.

What this game really should be compared to is the Space Empires series.
-Turn-based empire building
-Real-time space combat
-Directly controlable ground combat
-Fully customisable troops and ships

Stardrive two is basically an updated and much refined version of those games, and for that this game rocks.

Reasons to play
-The right things are automated.  You have full control, but a lot of tedius micro is done for you by the fraighter system.
-The research tree presents you with hard choices, but doesn't mean you can never have the things you don't research.
-The planets have several characteristics that make for more hard choices when colonising.  You might desperately need an outpost for your war, but all the planets in that system are small and toxic.  You'll hate it, but love it too.
-The whole theme and charictorisation of the races is both cool and comedic.  From samuri bears in combat, to deplomacy with cathulu's kids, to plant people on little trackers and distictive ship designs.  The art style is a gem of the game.
-The AI makes you work.  The AI will change its plans.  IF it sees one of your fleets out matches it, they will turn and run, wasting your time if you chase.  They will split into smaller fleets and raid you if you have one big fleet.  They will bombard worlds they can't capture.

Reasons not to buy
-Sudden onsent of insanity.  See you doctor.  Or of course, if you don't like 4X stratagy.

There are still a few relatively minor bugs and bits that could be smoothed a little, but this is the launch version and I expect these things to be ironed out over time.

I can't recommend this game enough.  The first stardrive dissappointed me a bit, but I'm glad I gave Zero a second try, and he came through a trooper!

reviewText:
The learning curve is what threw me off so many 4x games in the past but this game has such a great tutorial (voiced over too!) that I felt like I picked it up in 15 minutes. Anything else I couldn't figure out what easily learned from the help menu which covers extra details like food and transports etc, maybe 10+ minor topics.

Building your own ships is super intimidating at first because you have no idea what counters what, but once you get the hang of it (make a save a few turns before a battle and experiment!) it's super fun to see what you can cook up! TIP: You eat the infinite missile stream of death a few times before you figure out ~3 or so tiny laser turrets can pick them off before they hit your ship.

Custom races traits are also REALLY great. Want to make a cybernetic race of bears that lives underground? It's possible. And it's fun!

Most addicting game I've played in space in a long time.

The one CON I can list for this game is that their are Command Points limiting your # of ships, but each race's ship layouts are unique, and some races get significantly more tiles to build on per ship type than others. This could be turned into a plus if you decide you want to play the easiest race (cybernetic guys) first then move on to the hardest (bugs/wolves, etc)...

reviewText:
I cannot emphasis enough just how good Stardrive 2 is. Apart from the similarities to MOOII it's ship design system is easily the best of any game I've seen so far yet. Ground combat is dealt with in a style similar to XCOM, sometimes I like it, other times I don't. Its good for the away team themed 'events' but lacks realism for planetary invasion.

The strategic layer and ground combat are turn based with ship combat being realtime. Ship combat needs a minimum of input generally your main input is to dictate which ships should focus on broadsides or frontal volleys. Really you should be able to default this in the design screen. You can micromanage as much as you like but I prefer to click begin and watch my ships crush the opposition. Speaking of which the workshop has already started to pump out ship models of the classic sci-fi races with the inclusion of the Federation fleet.

There are so many nods to the SciFi genre in this game. Especially in the achievements and in the tech tree. The game is a unabashed celebration of science fiction.

This may be my favourite 4x yet. It has some issues (see cons) but I'm hopeful they'll fix them soon.

Pro's:
Ship design
SciFi geek out
MOOII
Good AI opponent's
Excellent plot / event scripting

Con's:
Needs AI planetary governors
Needs auto colonise or 'Send Colony Ship' option on the Planets screen
A 2x or 4x speed would be nice in ship combat.
Ground combat doesn't feel right in planetary combat.

reviewText:
So far, pretty fun.

I enjoy the turn-based breakdown of this game. In the first Stardrive, it was not uncommon for me to forget about one of the many moving parts of my empire and accidentally stagnate somewhere. The turn breakdown helps me keep track of everything and manage my empire more effectively. All the old familiar faces are back, plus one new race. To be honest I hoped there would be more and a little more variety in the AI personalities, so far everyone just wants to go to war with me.

I like the inclusion of extra events going on in space, it's just hard to go and investigate some of the phenomena I encounter when everyone around me wants to go to war.

There are some bugs though. Mostly sound bugs and they'll destroy your eardrums if you're not careful! I have my audio set at 4 freaking percent and the music played when I discover a new technology could wake the dead! The sound effect of a fleet exploding is also ear-splittingly loud and the beam weapons used by the crystal shard ships are also set to deafening volumes. I noticed many of the space battle sound effects are turned up far above everything else in the game.

I also noticed a bug! Sometimes when I complete a space battle, the game freezes while loading the turn.

So far, yes I'd reccomend the game. It's fun and can be pretty challenging. (First game I played I spawned in the center of the galaxy with no colonizable planets nearby and was surrounded by warlords who want my stuff.)

TL/DR: IF YOU DO WANNA GET AND PLAY THIS GAME TAKE YOUR HEADPHONES OFF!!! That's my only warning! Some sounds will break your ears! Otherwise is great game! Lots of fun! I will be updating this review as I play!

reviewText:
StarDrive 2 is so much fun - it feels like a much newer version of Master of Orion and totally worth it. After 127 hours I definitely haven't explored the entire game, but I do feel like I've exhausted most of the appeal. Hopefully they'll fix a few of the things below and then it will be even more awesome.

***Things I've liked about it***

You can customize your ships by placing individual components onto the hull at different locations, and you have to consider the cost, power, weight, size, and hitpoints of different systems. Not all the components are the same size/shape, either, so designing a ship is a lot of fun.

In battle, ships acceleration matters - you can't accelerate to maximum speed instantaneously and can't turn immediately either.

There are many styles of weapon - beam weapons with essentially infinite speed (but still limited range), artillery with long range but no guidance after they're launched, and rockets with good range that home on enemits, plus many, many other weapons and/or variants.

Ground combat is interesting and doesn't feel contrived - there are lots of different weapons, and the units have actual coordinates during ground combat, allowing for more strategy.

You can customize your race at the beginning based on whether you want to boost research, production, combat, and lots of other things. Each race also has a few race-specific technologies and/or abilities that can't be customized and add a little more flavor.

The tech tree is interesting because there are several branches that are independent. Also, each branch has tiers of three technologies where you can only research one of those three technologies before moving on to the next tier. This leaves you to get it from another race (by trade, extortion, spying, or assimilation), or to live without it.

***Things I don't like about it***

The battle arena prepares you for a much harder game than this actually is. Once you design a sufficiently good ship to win the battle arena, that ship is probably roughly 12 times as powerful as another AI ship of similar cost, and then the normal game gets pretty easy (you can build no military, wait for them to declare war on you, and then quickly build a ship to wipe out their entire fleet by the time they arrive). The way that I'd like this to be fixed would be for the AI to more clearly pay attention to the kinds of ships that it knows/expects that you have, and to build ships designed to beat those ships. I'd also like for it to design slightly better ships in the first place.

StarDrive 2 has the same problem as lots of empire-building games where as your empire grows, it takes more time to micromanage all of it if you feel that urge. Unfortunately, if you don't assign a planet to build anything then it doesn't build anything, and the game doesn't remind you that some planets aren't building anything. There are notifications when a planet finishes building its latest building, but sometimes those notifications dissapear if other things are happening in that turn too. The way I'd like this to be fixed is first for the turn to not allow ending if planets are idle, and second to allow the user to set a default build order that planets follow if they have no planet-specific orders.

The AI doesn't know how to evaluate the ships that I build. When I try to autoresolve a battle, the AI is much more likely to favor the opponent than if I were to actually fight the battle. That's understantable, but it's unfortunate when combined with a bug where in some battles (perhaps 2%), if you click to fight the battle then there never appears the button to actually start the battle, and the game is then stuck. Usually this can be fixed if I reload the game from a save, but not always.

When forming a team for ground combat (which is a lot of fun (unlike what I expected); good job guys!), sometimes characters will be designated as starting the battle with fewer than their maximum hitpoints. This can be reproduced if you have two preset loadouts, one having the Bone Weave attribute and one without it. The steps are 1. Restore the character's equipment from one preset loadout. 2. Restore the character's equipment from the next preset loadout. 3. Toggle the presence of the Bone Weave attribute by clicking manually. Note that now the character's starting hitpoints has adjusted by 20 (positive or negative depending on which way around the loop you went). It looks like someone else noticed this at http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=422949843 and was even able to make a unit whose starting hitpoints was negative (presumably by going around the loop three times)

The zooming could be a bit smoother - I wish that the zoom would spend less time animating and instead would adjust more quickly.

Sometimes colony ships will get stuck on the strategy map and won't respect orders to colonize the planet that they are at, but if you tell them to move away from the planet and move back to that planet then they are willing to colonize it.

The AI's don't have as good of an alignment between their diplomatic goals and strategic goals as I'd like them to have. Mostly it feels weird that they tell you upfront how much they value each technology, but they don't adjust their valuations based on circumstances. I've been able to give some unimportant economic technology to an enemy who was about to take one or two of my four planets in exchange for a peace treaty that bought me more than enough time to build up a much bigger army. The AI diplomacy doesn't really bother me that much since it's a very hard problem, but it's still another opportunity for improvement.

In some special-mission ground combat battles (but none of the important planet-taking or planet-defending ones - don't worry) , the zoom prevents the leftmost column of squares from being visible, so I can't select my units and therefore can't fight :(

reviewText:
Overall I give a positive review of the game. Is it perfect?  Well no, but it still gave me several dozen hours of fun (and the developer intends to support the game further).

The game's biggest flaw is that as it stands (and this is intended to change eventually) there are only two victory conditions (one official, one secret that says you won when you beat a final boss encounter).  Diplomacy as it stands cannot be used to form long lasting alliances and the end goal is always conquest.  The player can mentally set their own goals, such as controlling and containing all threats, or getting friendly with as many other civilizations as possible, but there are no built-in alternate victory conditions yet, and the ability to win by forming an alliance would add another facet to the game.

The ground combat has a very mixed reaction.  Personally I like it, but I can see why some do not.  The developer does want to improve this eventually.

Just like the first game, ship building is a huge aspect of the game's fun.  To summarize, I think it's a really good game but focuses a bit too much on the aggressive side of 4x play, but as I said the developer is accepting feedback and does want to fix that.  I do not feel an imperfect situation is enough for me to give a negative review.

As far as how the game looks and feels, for the most part I think it feels quite well done.  Perhaps my play time speaks for itself.  My stance is if I put this much time into the game, how could I at least not recommend it?

reviewText:
I would love to recommend this game, but I can't. While I was a huge fan of Stardrive, the sequel just rings hollow.

The first title was born of Steam Early Access, and gave the developer a large swath of suggestions, criticism, and feedback during its cycle. The developer would later make it pretty clear that he wasn't terribly fond of getting feedback during development, that there were too many voices in his first game and chose to develop Stardrive 2 behind closed doors.

Unfortunately, this is the result of a developer and his hubris stuck in an echo chamber. There's no one to point out flaws in design, resulting in poor decisions being reinforced as good ones inside one's own head, where they become entrenched.

Ship design is still good, but not quite as dynamic as SD1. There's far less freedom to build.  Faction customization is expanded. The tech tree is improved, but still not great and leader missions are fun the first time, but grow stale.

Outside of that, everything just falls flat. Ground combat is half-baked. Colony management interface is poor. The AI leaves a lot to be desired in both strategic and tactical combat (mathematical advantages are applied to make up for it). Diplomacy is even less useful. The move to a turn-based strategy map has taken away the immediacy of naval engagements.

Even with all the bugs, which I can forgive, this culminates into the two most damning critiques of this game:
* The game is shallow and has no spirit.
* It's flat out boring.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
StarDrive 2 has the same vices as StarDrive, though to a lesser extent. There are peripheral areas of the game which feel rushed or unpolished, not for lack of effort as I understand it, but lack of manpower. Unlike SD, the mechanics and overall gameplay is SOLID. I liked SD but there are segements of that game which were flawed.

Diplomacy is much more responsive and worthwhile in SD 2. The different factions in StarDrive have a lot of character and its something you actually want to engage in.

Not feeling the need to slow down time to a crawl in order to micromanage every detail of a star-spanning empire, is great. While I miss combat actually happening on the stategy map, turn-based allowed the rather spartan and unwieldy management aspects of the game to flower.

It can almost go without saying that StarDrive's defining aspect; ship design and combat have been developed, honed and polished to outshine any other 4X. It moved ahead in leaps and bounds, and it is fun, fun, fun. The are more options and everything is really slick. On top of that, there are special technologies and components you acquire outside of the actual scientific tree through various means. Some are stellar, others feel gimicky - which isn't a bad thing. The only addition I don't like is the proto-molecule device which is underwhelming - not because it underperforms, but because it is pretty superflous and there is a sizable build-up to actually getting it. Also because the mechanics which underpin it are perhaps the one weak point in SD2's fleet combat

It highlights the one real complaint I have with shipboard weaponry in the game. Ships can carry massive Subspace Artillery and Mass Drivers which by any yardstick should be able to get the job of bombarding a planet done. Instead ships have to carry a seperate arsenal of otherwise useless weapons, which take up precious space, in order pummel planets into submission. It is extremely arbitrary, especially one one considers that tactical and strategic nukes are available form the very start of the game - long before any sort of ground-based counter is available. A doom fleet in orbit, armed to the teeth with kinetic weaponry and only able to 'blockade' is a sorry spectacle. Maintaining planetary defenses on more than a few planets seems prohibitively expensive, even of it wasn't useless because most of the AI strategy is based around landing troops anyway.

At times playing on defensive boils down to playing wack-a-mole with invasions fleets amongst your holdings. That will probably be alleviated somewhat by wormhole junction forts and other defensive options in the 'Sector Zero' DLC.

Planetery invasions were unwieldly (in capital letters) in SD1, and while massive focus has obviously been put into tactical ground combat in StarDrive 2, it feels tacted on and doesn't really add much to the experience at this point in time.

Overall though, the game is fun which is to say that what it does well, it does really well. The feature set it touts is there and it is solid. It is the little things where this game looses ground. I dwell on the little things a lot, but that is nitpicking. This game deserves a much better rating then it has.

reviewText:
If there is one big flaw with this game, it is the total lack of Multiplayer. There are not even space or ground skirmishes against other players (at least as of 1.0c). This is a pure Singleplayer vs AI game. If you want Multiplayer strategy, that princess is in another castle.

For the rest, it takes some of the best concepts of other (indy) games. The game plays on 3 areas: Galactic, Space Combat, Ground Combat

Galactic:
Is turn based on a 2D map.
The colonisation and colony building closest resembles Civilisation for me. Other liken it to Master of Orion, but I have not playe that series. It focuses more on few, well developed colonies with the right buildings.
It borrows planetary effects and random events/miniquests from Galactic Civilsiations.
You can freely pick you fleets destiantion (no squars/hexes), but fuel greatly limits range outside of your territory.

Diplomacy has two unique turns:
1. The evaluation mechanic is open, with the game actually telling you leader personalities and the weighted values of diplomacy items.
2. The tollerancy mechanic means you cannot simply ignore negative relation modifiers or past deeds of the AI. Your people are a factor too and just won't allow certan deals to happen.

Research:
You can only research one tech per Tier" giving you some hard choices and you have to aquire the others via espionage or diplomacy.

Space combat:
Is realtime on a 2D map. It closest resembles space empires for me.
It seems to focus more on decisive
date: large scale battles rather then skirmishes.\nShip design is also seems heavily borrowed from SE
recommended: but simplified. Facings matter. There is few geartypes/hulls and almost no levels
hoursPlayed:
but there are lots of modifiers (1-4) you can apply to nearly every item.
Upgrading and retrofitting is seamless.

Ground:
Turn based on a isometic
voteText: square based map.\nBattles are fought by small elite teams or "boarding parties" rather then large armies.\nTroops can have up to 3 abilities (active and passive
helpfulPercent:
with cooldown or without) and based on technology and events you can almost freely choose thier gear while at a planet.
There is no boarding outside of events.

Documentation:
There a lots of tooltips and spoken/interactive toutorials.
Tech descriptions for new ship modules are often quite vague wich can result in picking the wrong tech."

reviewText:
this will be short but I want tog ive my two cents in.

I know people were clamoring for a multiplayer aspect to be added but in all honesty I don't know how it would work, especially with waiting for real time battles to finish up, unless all real time battles happen at the end of a turn which can seriously derail someone's strategy even moreso if other players are allowed to do things while a real time battle is going on.

Stardrive 1 was fun but it had issues, primarily with the bland proceduraly generated race descirptions and while a fully real time setup was a novel idea it presented too many issues to work around vs the traditional 4X turn based game. AS it stands, making Stardrive 2 into an equivalent of Total War in Space" was probably the best idea
date: yest you can't reinforce fleets in battle anymore but at least the game kept it's staple of real time combat scenarios to help it stand out.\n\nMy only major compaints with the game are as follows: the lack of victory conditions and no sandbox ship editor. There's no turn limit (at least not that I've found) and no other way to win excepyt total military conquest. reviewText:
The games basically MOO2 (Master of Orion 2) under a different company and with updated graphics. It's pretty decent as far as 4x games go, and there really hasn't been a good one since MOO2, *and no Galactic Civ is terrible*.

What i have played I have enjoyed, it has everything you could want in your typical 4x game and the game is still in development.

What I will point out is what I feel is missing or dislike.

* Story frame of reference - So many of these games are just > load game > load race > start. What would be nice would be some more depth to the history of the races and the galaxy itself, add to the immersion of the game.

* Not a fan of the ship design UI, feels very clunky and doesn't really match the feel of the rest of the game, some people might like tediously placing 1 tile at a time when making their ship designs but its basically lego on an established blueprint. The whole system could be completely redone in my opinion. *hint hint, MOO2's design screen worked well*. Also with regards to upgrading/refitting/redesigning ships if they stick to the clunky model, have a way to sort weapons and equipment by technology level and stats.

* More depth for your *not Antaran* incursion race, and fix the dimensional portal. It's bugged three times now in my games and cannot access it even though it says go explore it".

* More race traits and customisation options.

* More anomalies and galactic events
date: as well as more unique planetary anamolies.\n\nThe game is really good
recommended: and it has a huge amount of potential. I would recommend it to players."

reviewText:
I was able to pick up this little gem for $10 on a steam sale.  I played for about 100 hours and enjoyed the game thoroughly.  It may not be as grand as some 4x's but it is well made and worth what I paid.  As of today the developer is still active and fixing some of bugs in sporadic patches.  He apparently is working on new DLC or version.  I didn't seem to encounter or notice any bugs in my gameplay hours.  I had no crashes, just the program slowing some as I conquired every planet in the galaxy.

I played the humans during my play, other alien races are available and will be encountered and negotated and fought with.  The gameplay is not complex but has similiar depth to the old master of orion series.  Space combat is real-time that can be paused.  Ground combat is representative and turn based.  Difficulty can be selected from easy on up.  There is minor races to conquer and you can, if you wish, enslave other alien races to speed population growth and production.

The game captured enough complexity and depth of gameplay to hold my interest (not the easiest task since I own hundreds of steam games)....researching that next beam weapon or device to bombard the enemy planets with.  Perhaps, building new ships variants which are more powerful and faster.  Something always kept me engaged.  Ignore the board trolls, for some reason this particular steam board was inundated with them? Most have had nonsensical arguments or some wacky agenda now that I've actually played and seen the product for myself.

I would recommend giving this title a try for anything under $20 US dollars.

reviewText:
Not sure this game really has anything outstanding going for it.
There are a few annoying bugs - but I can deal with those.
There is no 'governor' feature - so you have to manage all your planets' decisions.
There is a lack of good list UI for just about everything that you want a good list UI for.
- planet list doesn't include things like current/max pop

Played three games, winning the last one.  The grind at the end was just annoying.  And it crashed on victory.

Meh.

reviewText:
I played one game as a subterranean cybernetic faction who never expanded from their massive homeworld. I teched up, beat back the pirates and remnants until I sent a single monstrous titan to each civilization and annihilated them all simultaneously.

I played another as an insectoid race of holy warriors who were prolific slavers, sacrificed their captives and assimilated their enemies technology. I would cripple enemy fleets, take half their population, capture most colonies and leave, declare peace and sell them back their destroyed colonies only to return 50 turns later to repeat the cycle.

Pros:
Extensive ship building and empire management.
Huge diversity and replayability.
Custom races enable role playing.
Multiple ways to play (Tall vs Wide, both are viable).
Great art and sound design, particularly with the diplomacy screens.
The developer is patching the game like crazy.
Land and space based tactical combat.
Can't research everything. Choices matter and tech trading is necessary.
Choose a doctine. All artillery and armour? Go for it. Shields and lasers? Sure. Huge carrier fleets? Awesome.

Cons:
Diplomacy, while cool with the tolerance mechanic, is easily exploitable. Returning pillaged colonies is rewarded far too much.
No diplomatic options for borders. Can't negotiate or forbid military access/ expansion.
Inconsistent difficulty. First few games can be incredibly difficult (powerful neutral factions)
Factions need proper battleship and titan designs and should be able to field them more regularly.
Finicky controls. Difficulty splitting fleets on the campaign map. Releasing and targeting fighters is a pain.
Some technologies become completely redundant and on repeated playthroughs aren't worth taking (speed bonuses/command point research for example).
Land battles are unbalanced. AI needs to be taught how to upgrade and use their ground forces better.
No victory conditions aside from domination. Superweapons/ faction specific uber technologies would be cool. Instead of a deathray, what about a victory condition tied to the remnants?

Honestly though these aren't real significant detractors. I still want to play more games with different factions and many of these issues will likely be resolved by the developer. Hoping the game gets a bigger following and mods are developed.

Fantastic game, one of the best 4x games I've ever played. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
This game is the closest to the feel of MOO2 of any other space 4x I've played.
Graphics, sound and interface are all first class in my opinion, especially the screens when interacting with alien races.

Lots of atmosphere and flavour to the game, the random events (such as one of your arctic planets founding a ski resort), are nice little touches that help give the game it's own personality.

The space combat is fun, it's good to see your latest weapon making mincemeat of an enemy fleet, plus as it's real time the battles are over fairly quickly so you don't get bogged down.
The land battles have potential, but they aren't up to the same standard as the space battles.

Bear in mind this is entirely a war focused game; the alien races are very aggressive and at the moment there is no option to form alliances with a race.
You can make a non aggression pact but at best this just buys you some time before you will need to fight that empire.

If treated as a Total War in space" type game it's really good. To stand up better against other 4x's I think an expansion may be needed to expand on the non-combat aspects of the game
date: such as wider diplomancy options and perhaps improved espionage."

reviewText:
If you are a child of the early 80's or late 70's, you may remember Master's of Orion II. It was, for lack of a better term, a masterpiece. The graphics were worse than the modern game FTL, but at the time that was the standard. And in this game, that didn't matter: You were the commander of a space empire with distinct characteristics. You designed spaceships, sent them into battle, researched exciting new technologies, and negotiated with other empires for exchange of goods, technologies and money.

The Good: Stardrive II is a modern reinvention of that game. It does nothing to reinvent the 4X genre, but the execution is the closest thing to the old Masters of Orion II that any game has in recent history. Trust me, I've played them all. This game gets some things brilliantly right, however: Turns play out at a pace you set, either calculated and one at a time, or mash the turn button and let it run for a few turns. Space combat is semi-real time, while ground combat is turn based. Outside of certain scenarios, they are also auto-calculable, which is nice at times-- Battle can feel slowly paced, and skipping it can be appealing.

The Bad: The game is also riddled with bugs and poor interface decisions. Hero's skills, like Bloodthirsty
date:
which allows a hero to gain passive governing bonuses for every enemy defeated in ground combat, doesn't work at all. Loot, which gives you bonus BC (money) doesn't either. Occaisional crashes happen, and the game doesn't support multi-monitors or borderless windows. Ground combat is also tedious, and it can be easy to make an uncorrectable mistake that costs you a battle due to the poor interface.

MOO Fans will enjoy the fact that most of the old species play style can be recreated, despite certain traits not being present in the default characteristics. Creativity, for example, allows you to research every technology in a tier, just like MOO2 Psilons-- but requires taking a lot of negative traits to achieve, like low gravity homeworld.

I can't say that this game will be appealing to a newer audience. But if you loved MOO2, you'll love Stardrive 2.

This game is an interesting sort, in which it makes it look like the game has a lot more in it, than it actually does. This game is just outrageous in so many ways it's hard to pick one that I dislike the most, but I'll try anyway.

Pros:
+ Looks nice
+/- Factions look different
+ Interesting to create new ship designs, even if it is just like trying to pack as much useful stuff into a suitcase that's two sizes too small

Cons:
- Every faction plays exactly the same. If you removed the faction picture and name, you couldn't tell the difference.

- Everything takes a ridiculous amount of time to do. Building ships, researching new technology, even moving a fleet from point A to point B. It takes 30 turns just to build the most simple building, and trying to erect a fleet quickly to stop enemy ships that just suddenly decided they hate you? 13 turns a piece. The smallest ships available are around 8 turns. Seriously?

reviewText:
Not sure this game really has anything outstanding going for it.
There are a few annoying bugs - but I can deal with those.
There is no 'governor' feature - so you have to manage all your planets' decisions.
There is a lack of good list UI for just about everything that you want a good list UI for.

- fleet list doesn't include ship types without hovering over every one

Played three games, winning the last one.  The grind at the end was just annoying.  And it crashed on victory.

Meh.

reviewText:
This game is the closest to the feel of MOO2 of any other space 4x I've played.
Graphics, sound and interface are all first class in my opinion, especially the screens when interacting with alien races.

Lots of atmosphere and flavour to the game, the random events (such as one of your arctic planets founding a ski resort), are nice little touches that help give the game it's own personality.

The space combat is fun, it's good to see your latest weapon making mincemeat of an enemy fleet, plus as it's real time the battles are over fairly quickly so you don't get bogged down.
The land battles have potential, but they aren't up to the same standard as the space battles.

Bear in mind this is entirely a war focused game; the alien races are very aggressive and at the moment there is no option to form alliances with a race.
You can make a non aggression pact but at best this just buys you some time before you will need to fight that empire.

If treated as a Total War in space" type game it's really good. To stand up better against other 4x's I think an expansion may be needed to expand on the non-combat aspects of the game
date: such as wider diplomancy options and perhaps improved espionage."

reviewText:
If you are a child of the early 80's or late 70's, you may remember Master's of Orion II. It was, for lack of a better term, a masterpiece. The graphics were worse than the modern game FTL, but at the time that was the standard. And in this game, that didn't matter: You were the commander of a space empire with distinct characteristics. You designed spaceships, sent them into battle, researched exciting new technologies, and negotiated with other empires for exchange of goods, technologies and money.

The Good: Stardrive II is a modern reinvention of that game. It does nothing to reinvent the 4X genre, but the execution is the closest thing to the old Masters of Orion II that any game has in recent history. Trust me, I've played them all. This game gets some things brilliantly right, however: Turns play out at a pace you set, either calculated and one at a time, or mash the turn button and let it run for a few turns. Space combat is semi-real time, while ground combat is turn based. Outside of certain scenarios, they are also auto-calculable, which is nice at times-- Battle can feel slowly paced, and skipping it can be appealing.

The Bad: The game is also riddled with bugs and poor interface decisions. Hero's skills, like Bloodthirsty
date:
which allows a hero to gain passive governing bonuses for every enemy defeated in ground combat, doesn't work at all. Loot, which gives you bonus BC (money) doesn't either. Occaisional crashes happen, and the game doesn't support multi-monitors or borderless windows. Ground combat is also tedious, and it can be easy to make an uncorrectable mistake that costs you a battle due to the poor interface.

MOO Fans will enjoy the fact that most of the old species play style can be recreated, despite certain traits not being present in the default characteristics. Creativity, for example, allows you to research every technology in a tier, just like MOO2 Psilons-- but requires taking a lot of negative traits to achieve, like low gravity homeworld.

I can't say that this game will be appealing to a newer audience. But if you loved MOO2, you'll love Stardrive 2.

reviewText:
I really wanted to enjoy this game, but even on easy it all boils down to combat, combat, combat.

Pros:
- ABSOLUTELY LOVE the ship editor.  By far, I think it's the most robust unit customization mechanism I have ever seen.
- Intuitive and streamlined planet/resource management

Cons:
- Even on easy, end game ends up one big ship slug fest with limited diplomacy options
- Diplomacy overall is limited, although I can appreciate some of the unique elements in it (racial tolerance for deals)
- Some missing quality of life features

So if you want to just design the cheapest, most effective ships and go conquer other people, this game is for you.  If you want to run a peaceful federation with ships that explore, do science, and occasional light combat, maybe wait for a patch or some mods.  Until then, I am not recommending this game in the current state.

reviewText: A great modern take on the Master of Orion or Sword of the Stars style of gameplay. It follows the standard formula of 4X but everything is top notch. reviewText:
Probably the closest thing in existence to a Master of Orion II Successor.

True ship customization, not simply aesthetic nonsense. Acceptable variety of tech to put on your ship(s) ranging from ballistic weaponry, missiles, energy weapons & hangar bays. More would be nice, but it leaves room for improvement.

Better ground based combat than MooII / Stardrive 1 - could be enhanced ( Have not played DLC as of this posting* )
More games should go for the tactics" based feel.

Real time combat is handled well
date: though the fluidity of Stardrive 1 was more desireable it certainly could cause some serious lag late game
recommended:
so the instanced combat is an understandable compromise.

If you are a fan of true 4X & not the horrible knockoffs that we've seen in the last decade you will love this game & its predecessor (despite it being a bit clunky)

The only other space-based sequel with as much care poured into it as Stardrive II is perhaps Starpoint Gemini 2(which is more of an Escape Velocity successor).

Every other 4X should take note of how to make a proper game.

9.0/10

Stardrive 3 had better be Multiplayer

reviewText: StarDrive 2 Future DLC ideas or Ideas for StarDrive 3\n\nYou should make another dlc that allows lunar colonization. It is a shame you cannot colonize moons, gas giants, or even stars. What what am I talking about? Well the moon part should be very easy to understand Ganymede is larger than Mars and if it wasn't orbiting Jupiter, it would be another planet in our Solar System between Mars and Venus in size. Titan, Europa, Triton, Calisto, and Io are also moons of relative planetary likeness. I know adding in EVERYTHING" would be an impossible task
date: but you could at least extend to eight planet bodies with at most 4 moons. Although moonlets like Phobos could also be considered but for decoration since it would addup too much clutter. So you can have additional "moons
recommended:
but you they would just be for show, like what you currently have for moons.

What I would consider is something like Endless Space but instead of solar systems, you click on a planet it will pop up that particular planet with its moons (the ones you can colonize) right after the planetary entity.

http://media.moddb.com/images/mods/1/21/20976/EndlessSpace-2012-05-05-22-51-52-96.jpg.jpeg - Like this, just with the first entity on the left being either a gas giant or a large planet like entity and its most likely to colonize moons.

You can click on each celestial body and it will pop up into your planetary management window that you would currently experience with StarDrive 2.

This also means you might need to modify the govenment management tab so that you can easily list moons with planets. Since this is quite a lot, you should also be able to have automation with a little more focus on what you can do to modify how your governors behave. Sort of like a gambit system from FFXII (Final Fantasy XII), build, if not build, then trade or maximize on science. You can do the same with fleet admirals as well. This is very similar to what you can already experience in Distant Worlds.

This way when you decide to colonize say Titan, you send a colony ship to Saturn and it will pop up a menu in which you can look Saturn and its moons.

Colonizing a Gas Giant is something more practical after you develop matter alteration technology, although you should be able to mine it before colonize it. Similar you should be able to mine Asteroids and worlds without an atmosphere before you can colonize it. Mining should allow you to gain resources, thus increase income and gain access to valuable resources, but you won't be able to build anything or have a thriving population until you colonize it. This could be done with a constructor.

Eventually you should be able to colonize a star, but this is done in steps after you have the technology to colonize a gas giant, starting with Brown Dwarfs, then Red Dwarfs, then Average Stars, then Giant Stars, then White Dwarfs, then Supergiants, and then Neutron Stars.

What is this technology. Well you can create floating population centers similar to the one in Star Wars Episode V. This also means there should be different types of gas giants. Helium, Hydrogen, Methane and Oxygen types. Hydrogen is easiest to synthesize, making it the easiest to colonize when you got the right tech. Helium is difficult, but offers an easier abundance of Helium-3. Methane types also offer valuable resources and oxygen types are more practical for environmental residences, because you already have air you can breathe, well with minimal adjustments considered of course.

As for Stars, we are talking about a dyson sphere. Take everything concerning a gas giant and just multiple your gains a hundred fold at least.

You also need those sorts of anomalies you can mine like in Galactic Civilization 3. Antimatter is easier to acquire from a black hole and that needs to be a resource you should acquire. I suggest looking at Distant Worlds, Endless Space and Galactic Civilizations 3 to see what types of resources should be considered as strategic for certain uses necessary in the game.

reviewText:
In my opinion this game is completed by the DLC. Although a bit of a questionable move, I can understand why the developer has chosen to go this route.

The DLC makes the game much more fun, the addition of the hex tiles means sensor range is more sensible now and the construction ships offer an additional gameplay mechanic with more resources to control. The new ground combat is much better and more suitable for 4X games.

Please don't be put off by the learning curve, even on normal it will take a few games of getting your ♥♥♥ wiped on the floor by the AI before you learn how to take them on. What's great is that everyone will develop their own strategy naturally.

My one gripe is the AI. Now I like diplomacy in 4X games but you HAVE to keep in mind that the AI is also trying to win and there can only be one winner. As soon as the AI thinks you're weak, they will take advantage. My advice is to avoid AI until you can defend yourself but be warned, from mid-game onwards the AI will produce fleets that will literrally take up the whole screen before the battle starts, so build a fleet you think will be of adequate size, then make it tenfold.

Also, try not to use the default ships as they're a bit lacklustre, make sure you take the time to experiment in building your own ships.

Enjoy!

reviewText:
The original Stardrive was a fun little game, and I probably spent over a hundred hours on it. But it had quite a few problems too, so I was a bit skeptical in how the sequel would be.

I was however positively surprised! This game addresses nearly all my issues I had with the first title. The presentation, and game flow feels far better this time around.

It does however still have a few random bugs every now and then, even if none of them game breaking it can be slightly annoying. Besides that, the game itself runs smooth, and the turn changes are near instant. The prequel had a tendency to become near unplayable at higher difficulties due to performance drops, as the enemies would clog the galaxy with endless fleet battles. I think the new instanced battle system is an improvement from the old one in that regard ( no late game lag anymore ).

As for the people complaining about the AI “cheating” in some reviews – I see no proof of this, and I have no trouble personally keeping up with the AI at medium and hard difficulties ( currently halfway into a game on hard as Vulfen, with me owning 1/4th of the galaxy ) . The game however does have bit of a learning curve, and the AI is quite aggressive for some races. Expect to die a few times before you learn the ropes.  ( when to expand, what to research first, figuring out what ship designs to make etc )

I for one like the AI this time around, it feels more clever than before. Although I’d guess a “Beginner” difficulty setting wouldn’t be a bad thing though, to let new players get to learn the game at a slower pace. (I might write a beginner guide sometime )

I don’t really have a lot more to say. The gameplay is fun, the races varied, and the artwork is neat. If you like x4 games, and don’t mind a challenge. This is a solid indie buy and I would recommend it to my friends.

reviewText:
This was really hard to recommend, and if it wasn't so fun, I wouldn't.  But be warned...there are some bugs to be aware of.  I only encountered 2 bugs, but they were rather game breaking, and I hope I'm the only one who is encountering them, though I doubt it.  Read the rest of this review and other reviews before you buy, and you'll probably want to buy this on sale, like I did, though if you have the original SD you already have a 33% discount(I waited for an even better deal).

Pros-
In depth ship customization
good diplomacy
fun battles
great empire building
customize your own race

Cons-
The game will crash if you don't auto-resolve battles with too many ships, as it will crash upon trying to load casualty lists
If you auto-resolve even larger battles, the casualty list will cover your screen, causing you to be unable to do anything.  AT ALL
The auto-resolve is bad...though it is also pretty much the same in other games.  I played out a battle, won without losing more than half a dozen small ships, crashed trying to load casualty list, auto-resolved, lost my whole fleet, and the casualty list from THAT covered the center of my screen and made it so that I couldn't click on anything and I could only use hotkeys and had to alt+tab and close out the game

Conclusion-
Fun overall, but it has some game breaking bugs, and is poorly optimized.  Judging from past experience, I'm not sure whether or not Zero will even optimize the game or finish bugfixing...he abandoned the original Stardrive long before it was done, and moved onto this project.  Let's hope he doesn't do it again.

reviewText:
Oh. My god. I'm not saying it's a difficult game. I'm just saying that Dark Souls is like Kirby's Epic Yarn in comparison to this game. That said - once you realise that you need to play it smart and stop thinking in terms of this being a 4X game - the game becomes really interesting.

The only way to win is to take an intimate interest in your empire's stats. Like some kind of super micro managing mother. Use all the tools you are given to carve out a bloody path for your empire to success, because otherwise someone else will carve a bloody and desperate path right through your face.

Pros:
The UI is buttload better than most of the other space strategy games out there. It's not great. It's just better than most, which I call a pro.

The management of the planets and ships makes sense. I've yet to go Oh. I wish I could do that."

Customising the loadout of your ships both works great and is absolutely vital to victory. Because only you know what kind of ship you need for what kind of scenario. Need a pure tank to absorb the initial attack and then a bunch of fighters slam into the enemy dealing the real damage? You gotta make it happen yourself. And you can. And it's awesome.

Cons:
The tutorial. I sort of didn't want to put it as a con
date: because it's not bad compared to other space strategy games. But it's still narration. "Do this
recommended: this happens." That said - it's short
hoursPlayed: to the point and gives you the important stuff. As someone who never pays attention to tutorials

reviewText:
I bought and quite enjoyed SD1. I do seriously lament the lack of multiplayer, which is not yet present here either, but to be honest, for now I'm quite happy to play SD2 by itself, which is weird for me because I'm very MP oriented.

I really thought I would miss the contunous play aspect of SD1, but to my surprise the instanced fleet action gives a bigger sense of scale than was present in SD1, which for me, at least for now, makes up for the smaller map sizes. This is much more a spirtual successor to MoO2, with proper characters, events, and buffs/penalties. The graphics are excellent and it runs quite smoothly on my, admitedly powerful, laptop. There are some minor bugs that i've come across, but no deal  breaks and I've no doubt that Zer0 is working hard to fix whatever crops up.

I was fortunate to get the SD1 discount, so this worked out to be slightly more expensive than a trip to the movies, and there is no doubt in my mind I will get more than 2 hours of solid enjoyment out of it. I strongly reccomend playing without creative selected, as this makes your research choices much more important and leads to much more replayability.

reviewText:
It doesnt suck!

I play alot of games, most of which suck, not this one doe.

If you like 4x games and you like space themes your gonna like this game.
interface is clean, research is straight forward tho geared a little more towards unlocking new weapons for your ships then say a shiny new building.

Combat is where this game stands above the rest for me. your ships can be bound to a fleet and move as a single unit across the strategic map but once you encounter a enemy your brought into a real time battle where your ships are controlled individually and the battles are always exciting. and for those of you that don't like the pressure of real time combat, don't worry, you can slow the combat down to issue orders.

The second best part about this game is the turn times, if you've ever played civ 5 you'll know what i mean when i say theres nothing more frustrating then finnaly building a empire just to quit the game because you don't wanna wait 20 min for the ai to take thier turns. just isn't an issue with stardrive 2. every time i hit end turn, the next turn starts right away. crazy huh?

The only bad review i've seen so far are from people who are getting beat non stop by the AI.

They arent lieing the ai is smart and ♥♥♥♥ing scary, when i get threatened by another race or see them approaching my borders i don't laugh at thier feeble armys. i ♥♥♥♥ my ♥♥♥♥ing pants!

If i still havent convinced you to buy this game, think about the fact that this game was made by a smaller team then any game you've probably ever played, yet still gets fast updates and you can count on the devs to help you anytime you find a bug. hell i even saw zero helping a dude who was simply missing video card drivers.

Great game by a great team. buy this ♥♥♥♥! even if only to support good game devs.
