reviewText:
Better than SD1, yes.

Better than SP alternatives:
Star Ruler 2, yes.
Distant Worlds Universe, no.
MOO2, yes.

I found the game too easy on normal.
The starting position can screw you but that's very MOO2.
Ground combat and the GC side missions, I could have done without.  I'm hoping this gets replaced with something better in a DLC.

Overall the game is fun and almost MOO2 like but it is missing some nuances and because its so similar I wish zerosum had been able to replicate MOO2 even more closely.  Except for space combat.

I paid $20 (SD1 owner discount) and it was good value for money.  However I would have paid the $30 and it would have been ok value at that price.

Overall a positive experience and I expect to be playing it for a while yet.  Probably more than SD1 but that's a while off.

reviewText:
Excellent successor to MOO2

+Great art and design, everything looks nice and spacey
+Excellent atmosphere and storytelling which is missing in most games notably Endless Space etc
There are tons of funny sci fi references and the style of it all is excellent
+Complex game mechanics, it takes what made MOO2 and adds several more nice features, note that the ground combat is super basic and I could have done without
+ Designing ships and space battles is fun!

BUT... it is a little rough around the edges.

- The UI is clunky at times and can be a pain to navigate, it doesnt break the game but it makes it a pain to click on what you want to.
- The game is not currently balanced very well. Specifially the AI difficulty is ramped up, the diplomacy system works well but all of the AI will inevitably demand all your stuff then declare war
- The ground combat was a nice bonus but it does feel tacked on and rather simplistic


This game is very promising and quite excellent as is, i expect much of the negatives to be patched as there is nothing too serious

reviewText:
It's a great 4x strategy game. If you like things like empire management, designing ships, tech trees(not quite a tech tree but something better imo), and some good old real time tactical spaceship combat then this game might be for you. There's just one thing you might want to consider before buying it. Do you like a challenging game that has a lot of depth that is hard to learn and hard to master?

At first I found the game very frustrating. The first half a dozen games I played ended in utter failure. In my first couple of games the AI got a huge lead and dominated me. I did better in the next two and managed to compete with  and beat some of the AI empires but one still got a lead in the end and beat me. The last two I was doing well and it looked like I was going to come out on top but I ended up making a huge mistake and it ended up setting me back enough that I lost. I'm on my seventh try right now and I think I might actualy win this one though I'm not certain as I suffered a fairly big set back before I decided to turn in for the night.

A lot of peopel would be upset by this kind of experience and I can understand why. It's very frustrating to be beaten so badly and wonder how things could have gone so wrong. It can feel down right oppressive and if you don't enjoy a challenge then it is certianly overwhelming, but the thing that has made it all worth it to me and the reason I am recommending this game is because I'm getting better each time I play and I'm enjoying more each time I play too. The game has a lot of depth and I've only scratched the surface so far but each time I play I understand more about how the game works. I'm not confused as to why I lost so badly in my first couple play throughs now. I now understand the mistakes I made and I won't be making them again.

The game is not easy to learn and that is going to scare a lot of people away but it's very rewarding for the persistent. If you play this game you are probably going to lose pretty badly on your first games and that's a tough sell for most people. However, if you stick with it and keep playing you will find enjoyment in this game and won't regret the purchase.

reviewText:
first of all,keep in mind  this is my second 4X game i have played, so im not an expert on them.

since I played the first game and really enjoyed it, the second I saw this game came out (and the discount it had from having the first one) i bought it. the tutorials make it clear that stardrive 2 is very complicated, and right they are. I've been playing as the opteris( cybernetic bugs, passion to expand and destroy everything in their way) and I've restarted probably about 8 times now.

the first mistake I made was ship design, trying to cram good weapons into frigates and make as many of them as possible. its simply not practical since the AI somehow created a fleet of 400( yes, FOUR HUNDRED) frigates and were about to wipe me off the face of the galaxy.

at first i thought this game really did cheat the AI into being a ship building superpower, raining death on everything like others say. I ws going to shelf this game for good,  but then i started playing in the battle arena, and realised its all down to how you design your ships! now after many attempts at starting an empire and failing, I am on my way to completely eradicating the squid people, all thanks to about 5 ships designed by me, tearing through these masses of enemy fleets!

so if you are thinking of buying this game, I would get the idea of amassing a huge force out of your head and binning it. stardrive 2 runs on brilliant  ship design, trial and error, and understanding how to create as few fleet killing ships as possible, rather than a massive armada to do your bidding.

so if you enjoy a challenge, love an in depth design system full of a hundred different weapons/ systems to choose from, and won't cry when the odds are against you, buy this game. I've had great fun playing the game so far and will be playing around in the shipyard a lot more!

reviewText: Daniel pretty much fixed everything that was bothering me in the first game, but I do hope he keeps fixing and updating the game post-release. The only thing that REALLY bothers me at the moment is the lack of proper long term peace treaties and alliances in the otherwise vastly improved diplomacy screen. It gets a bit samey if my only option to win the game is to wipe out everyone else, and having to constantly renew the numerous short term non-aggression pacts and trade treaties gets a bit annoying after a while. So, please add more long term diplomacy options (only available with good very good diplomatic relations of course) and I will be extremely satisfied with the game.

reviewText:
After being kind of disappointed with Endless Space I decided to give this one a go.

Gameplay may be just a bit too slow for my taste but i LOVE the way you can set up and customize your ships. If you like to have a lot of personalization with your units this is a must have for you.

Imagine something like Gratuitous Space Battles + decent X4 space TBS + surprisingly nice TBS ground combat.

For all you SD veterans reading this, sorry I didn't play the first StarDrive and can't compare the two.

reviewText:
And there goes my last ship......

If your not a fan of really great space strategy games then you wont like this but if you do then man will you enjoy this game.  Firstly this game does what other space strategy games get wrong.  It has real time space battles that are fully controled by the player with really awesome spaceships to fight with.  The artwork in the game is great fun to look at and even though i like a more serious tone to my games the design of the races are fun and badass at the same time.  The game has a sort of humour intermixed with some serious lore.  The idea of cycles of destuction with the races of the galaxy destroying each other each cycle.  Theres also fun side quests that pop up every so often with crystal ships, ancient black cruisers appearing from insects, space worms and of course space pirates.

However there are some problems,  like the races are a little overly psychotic and are not interested in deplomacy like other games.  It can go from a promising start to instant war just from discovering your existence.  Some races also have way too much power and shoud be nerfed slightly.  Theres a couple of bugs and battles can run a little slowly if alot is happening.

But for all of the problems their is still alot of patching and tweaking here and there so im sure itll get better.  In my opinion if you want to wait it out fine but id recommend picking it up cus man you will not regret it.

reviewText:
Short: A clean, solid 4X game.

Less short: A good mix of everything from other 4x games. It won't win out on orginality of the nth degree but what's here is workable and enjoyable. The dev has been in constant contact with the community on the steam forums and his own in adressing the issues that have been cropping up.

It can be difficult but after a few tries i've finally reached a point in the game where I have a foundation to whack back.

I personally found the pacing to be ideal as the starting game doesn't feel like it takes forever like Civ V or Gal Civ does. Your on toes from the get go which for some this may not appeal too.

Overall as stated earlier the UI is clean and responsive. The gameplay is tough but rewarding.

My main gripe is other empires colonising in my sphere of influence. I hope this gets fixed.

reviewText: StarDrive 2 is the most fun ive had for a long time with a strategy game, the ship design mechanic is its best novelty and this really allows you to combat any threat that comes at you (and there are a lot). It really makes you feel proud when one of your designs obliterates your enemies, or some fancy tech you researched saves your ♥♥♥. This alongside the customisable races gives an extreme level of diversity and really makes you the ruler of your own empire, not as though you've simply been given to you to take control of. The game itself is fun and enjoyable and I recommend it highly, however although graphicly the game is simple, theres a lot of hidden calcualtions and which really slow it down, as I do not have a powerful PC i thought this game would work well  ( SOASE works fine with huge fleets) however this does not. reviewText:
OK I will make this short and sweet

Pros

+ Space battles are fun to watch and control!
+ Diplomacy is ok
+ customizing your ships!
+ Visuals are amazing (for some parts kind of iffy)
+ planets are highly detailed and it has a Galactic Civil feel.
+ Ground battles are intresting
+ Music is good!

Cons

- Minor bugs. i had a funny glitch where I could control the invaders.
- has a low end Xcom feel (ground battle.) it would be better if they added a cover system.
- the models are not that detailed for the races but its good enough


So in conclusion, this game is fun as hell and has tons of replayability but it has some minor set backs.

(Yes I have played Master of Orion 1 and 2 so I know that this game is a copy" but I can care less because at least the developer (s) revamped a game I haven't played in years."

reviewText:
I really like this game, a lot. There are so many unique possibilities for ship design and strategy, both tactically and strategically. The game is a lot of fun and quite challenging at times.

However, I'm really frustrated by the game as well. I've encountered quite a few bugs that range from minor to almost gamebreaking. Fortunately, the developer is actively improving the game so I expect that the bugs will be mostly quashed with time.

In the end, this game is enjoyable enough that I would recommend it even as it is now: Definietly not perfect, but still worth the money and getting better with time.

reviewText:
Thumbs up for a game that surprised me unexpectedly in a positive way.

In the first place I was very cautious to buy it while reviews were very contradictory and controversial. However I did get it and... surprise! Had so far some great time with fun and lots of adrenaline. A mixture of ingredients from other similar games that even reminded MOO but with original components as well.

But honestly for some reason I find it difficult to make a sort of “traditional” review because there are many issues and aspects to put down on the ground. So I will choose a rather unconventional method of approach...

Stardrive 2 is definitely not like an expensive gourmet restaurant ala card menu. Neither is ma's or granny's good old dish. It is like a neighborhood canteen junk Food! But a very tasty one, addictive, full of fat, crunchy and juicy, spicy with lots of exotic stuff inside it.

Now if you are the kind of person that likes variety in food styles then go for it. But if you are the “snub” kind of a character that likes healthy food and especially sensual delicate pleasures in taste, than i should tell you to stay away from it. But I won't. And yet for this to happen the devs must in the fist place prove that the game will soon get to it's promising potentials making some improvements, developments even changes as well.

Just really hope to see this things happening in future updates because this game can really become a hit.

Bon appetite!

P.S And one thing to start with improvements, among others, is just changing the ridiculous ground battle mode where it doesn't fit the general grand strategy idea(!) where in some level the game flirts with.

reviewText: I will start by first saying I am allitle Biased.  I loved stardrive one, it was easilly my favorite game durring that period and I sank hours into it.  When I heard that they were making a StarDrive 2, I thought it was going to be a money grab.  I was a little dissapointed.  I am glad to say that I was pleasently wrong.\n\nLooking at StarDrive 2 on its own merrits, I enjoy it a lot. To me the best part of the game is the customizable ships.  While some parts are more simple then Stardrive 1's but it works.  What they did with the randomish quests and story elements really reminds me of playing Masters of Orion Two with a updated UI and real time space battles.  I would recomend this game to people that are a fan of space combat games or Masters of Orion.  If you are looking for a clone of the first game this is not the game for you.

reviewText:
SD2 is a difficult 4x strategy game with homicidal AI and some very good game mechanics. Overall the game is very solid but in its current state if falls just short of a classic. A must have for space strategy fan boys, not a good buy for a casual gamer or those new to the genre.

The Good:
* Customizable options for the factions and starships lends to great immersion. I have made plenty of flagship battle heavy titans that get smashed because I didn't place armor in the right places or had too many spinal mounts that could hit anything far away but the big ship couldn't turn fast enough to handle flank attacks.
* Graphics are awesome. Clicking on planets and watching the cities light up on the dark side increase with population is a nice touch. Ships blow up into several smaller pieces and actually come apart instead of an explosion cloud animation.
* Space battles tend to devolve into choatic melees despite the most careful planning and ship design ( I consider this a realistic plus some micromangers may get frustrated with the lack of form in battle) A formation button would be a plus.

The Bad:
* Homicadal AI that will attack at immediately when weakness is shown
* AI sends massive doom fleets that are kinda of fun to destroy with some well built smaller fleets, but it is easy to be get overwhelmed
* Some characters cause some serious headaches. Watch your ♥♥♥ if you hire Zapp Groening, because the AI will go ape ♥♥♥♥. (-20 diplo for a 30% firepower bump)
* Ground combat seems a bit underwhelming. Troops are determined by population so 6 soldiers defending a world of 6 billion doesn't seem right in scale.
* Tech tree are based on difficult choices. Each category has one of three options. If you just start playing and researching blind you will find that you have a broken economy and a disfunctional empire mid game.

Summary:
* Active community with a developer who reads the damn forums and reacts with frequent patches
* Hard but satisfying when you develop a winning reciepe
* A beautiful game with great FPS for the graphics (34 hours in no CTD)
* A lot of bang for 30 bucks
* Samurai Space Bears
voteText: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful

Bought Stardrive 1 Loved it even if it had its drawbacks, and its the same with Stardrive 2 The biggist problem for this game is that the diffculty is quite high for normal (I fair well on it) but not so for other people.
Yet avast ye land lubbers patches galore! The dev for this game treats it like a baby and listens to the people, its had some manjor bugs in it but it was patched the day right after, most bugs were squashed, also I have found out Daniel (the Dev) is doing modding tutorials to help people mod his game after they asked him to make it moddble as possible (Star Trek, Star Wars anything space related)
Pros:
1. Muther F***ing Space Bears
2. Muther F***ing Space wolfs
3. Module ship building design (make your ships how you want them you want your battle ship to have only armor with no weapons then let it be you crazy f**k)
4.Its a 4X game that works
5.Interesting/ awesome art design (space bears!!!!)
7.Cool 3D enviroment battles, ships will go over and under each other to get an advantge.
8.Skill level system, ships gain veterency and improve their aim and flying skills.
9.Land battles this one is a bit of meh, Its Xcom based gameplay I love, the skills are only very interesting too!
10.Name everything! Name your ships! name your planets, name your race and choose different trait  for them like better ship builders (20% faster at building ships) or have replusive as a trait (making them ugly as ♥♥♥♥!) and no one wants to be your friend!
11. Leaders, you get an abundance of leaders to pick! some of which are jokes from star wars or futurama. (you can get zapp brannigan as a space leader!)
12.The music, omg the music its amazing, I just can't believe how nice it is, its  like Frank Klepacki did the music for this game like Star wars Empire at war, its just ♥♥♥♥ing great! You can really feel the atmostphere for the game.

Cons:
1.High diffculty
2.Land battle AI is pretty dum.

4.Need more space encounters like some kind of awesome rebellion. (abit like the warharks)

reviewText:
It will be a great game if this thing is patched and expanded. As a hardcore fan of MOO1 and to a lesser extent MOO2, SD2 is about as MOO2 as it can be done without calling it MOO2. Basically everything is same but with improved engine.

I will recommend this game on the grounds that it's basically MOO2 in new clothing. However potential buyers should be aware that game have issues and glitches. Most infuriating are big battles. If you go into batle with hundred of ships in both fleets, game (battle) is guaranteed to crash at the end.

What I would love to see is to expand the universe even further. 100 star systems max is not exactly ground breaking, many other 4X have thousands, so building massive empire is not exactly possible. One of the problems of SD2 is that you bump into other races far too quickly (at least IMHO). And tech tree is rather primitive (same system like MOO2).

To sum up: If you want to play newer version of MOO2 (without DOS or W95) go ahead, but be advised because of the bugs you may get very frustrated on more than one occasion.

reviewText:
StarDrive 2 is a very enjoyable game that offers many choices and an engaging universe.
It has good looking visuals, a nice ship customization feature. Theres humor and alot of fun events during gameplay that I think adds alot to the charm of the game.

Space combat is simple but good. The ships get experience points from combat and medals that give bonuses so I think it's a part that really adds identity to your fleets. Like sending in your veterans to kick ♥♥♥.

I get beaten by the AI some times but I keep coming back to try again because I feel its possible to try a new strategy or start a new map with a few tweaks to get a better chance.

I know there are some bugs and parts that are lacking but I keep playing the game and I really hope it will be improved in the future.

reviewText:
Boo.  I played SD1 and it had some interesting ideas but also had some big flaws that made it hard to enjoy playing for very long.  There seemed to be some changes in this version so I tried it out.  Long story short, while it has some nice bits the pieces do not fit together well at all.  Some UI elements that you have to use every truen are tedious to access.  Many turns, nothing happens.  The AI is poor and only excells at massively cheating up units.  I experienced multiple crashes and lock-ups in the later game and late game fights were slooooooooow.  And this is a super minor thing but the background 'spaceship' sound effect is not controlled by the audio sliders in game, so I had to turn off all sound from the game to keep it from making my head hurt after a while.

The wrost part is some aspects are less good than the first one.  Such as the ship combat and ship design, both of which I think are more simplified to the point that they are just busy work.  The ground combat got an upgrade but it is still tedious.

I doubt I will play any more games of this.  It was not expensive, but still not worth the time invested for a game that feels half baked.

With all this though the true reason to not get this is becuase of what the creator did to everyone who got the first one.  Completely walked away from it to make the second and it is the same game.  Charged people twice while promising the world.  Just buy a game from EA. Even they aren't as corrupt or immature as the zero who made this.

reviewText:
With about 20 hours into the game I am done with this game, this should be considered a first impression rather than a review as I don't feel that I have enough time played to call it a review. I will give it the caveat that my system meets the minimum requirements listed, but not the recommended.

For me this game is riddled with bugs, I have started 6 games, each of them encountered a game ending situation that wasn't due to game mechanics but rather game engine issues, three times combats that wouldn't hang up the game, twice fleets caught pinned to a planet and when I would retreat it would retreat me to where I started the combat initiating the fight again, and once due to my save file loading me into a frozen game (it wasn't frozen when I saved and logged off for the night).

When it works it is an interesting game, however I am looking for a long game played over multiple session not a game that I have to either save constantly in case I need to reload for bugs, or start over.
voteText: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I absolutely love a ton of features in this game. But there are some things that make this game beyond broken and not worth the money.

Firstly, the AI is stupid, it buys every upgrade, masses little ships, has no strategy, and on higher difficulties all it does is cheat more, no extra strategy, just gets extra stuff for free. It has complete map awareness at all times, knows where your fleets are on any difficulty, and a plethera of other aweful things.

Secondly there is a ♥♥♥♥ ton of ♥♥♥♥ing bugs that makes me question, how on earth this game even is released as a compelte game. Crashes all the damn time, during space fights enemies will run off the map where you can't see them, so the fight never ends and the only option is to forfiet destroying all of your ships... Seriously that is the only thing you can do, and hope you saved before the battle.

The end game is bad, just plain bad. There are 70 solar systems in a normal game, and the information displayed to you makes it nearly impossible to navigate your enourmous empire. Allocating resources, troops, knowing populations, will take you about 40 minutes a turn once you start to get a lot of stuff. It's not am enjoyable 40 minutes either, it's trying to remember how much population planets have, which planets are where, what type of abundance are they, etc etc. and you generally have to navigate 3 to 4 different screens just to try and gather all this information... It is beyond frustrating.


There are some wonderful features in this game,random encounters, ship design, good humor in the stories of heros and missions, andship battles(if there was a bit more strategy, but it's still fun blasting 100 enemy ships into dust with long rauge gauss cannons before they reach you). But these features will not satisfy you. Avoid blowing your money on this game and support a game that actually designs quality games.
voteText: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Just buy the first one.

The combat in this one is stale. The Ai just spams smaller ships that use rockets, so equip 20 ships with long range weaponry and just retreat to win. Battles also take so long and don't feel like they have a big impact on the game.
In the first Stardrive the space battles felt important, theres a huge fight above your homeworld and you have to decide to divert a fleet there or to your border planet that has huge production, all in real time.

The ground combat in the first one felt epic, throwing hundreds of soldiers at a planet and watching this huge battle. The second one is turn based with special abilities and feels dry as ♥♥♥♥.

Only thing the second one does better is graphics, diplomacy, and empire borders.

For real, if this game interes you just buy Stardrive 1, you'll enjoy it way more.

reviewText: Ah, a not too complex blended real time with turnbased strategy game, thoroughly fun to be sure. The turn based method of colonizing planets and tending to your growing civilization is well executed, as the real time space battles are fun and a visual feast, but perhaps lacking in complex strategy. The characters that represent the various factions are all fun  to interact with and play as. The true meat of the game is in designing the various starships you make fleets out of, this is what really defines battle strategy and is very fulfilling when you can build your next evolution of ship for your fleet. Where this games sees some major downpoints is a lack of multiplayer, and some difficulties late game as the number of ships in battle can reach  in the hundreds per side as the game needs to calculate trajectories for every shot and damage for every piece that makes up the ships you design. another annoyance is that while you can redesign your ships as you aquire new tech, the other factions do not and are relegated to predesgined ships that simple dont put up much of a fight. the game makes up for this as the enemy may amass giant fleets, that will cause the game to stutter as i said before. This is great fun and hours of play go by as the 'just one more turn' syndrome hits hard.  the characters are all fun, the game plays great, but despite some late game issues and a lack of multiplayer, its still a recommendation. The full price of the game is fair, but if it drops in price with steam sales and such, its a definate buy.

reviewText:
I was impressed initially, but after hours of gameplay, I feel this game falls short.  AI is terrible....makes totally random choices, nothing seems in character for the opposing races.... (everything looks to be simple dice rolls).  Colony management interface only half works.  Can't withdraw from battles as in Mo2.  When initiating a retreat, SD2 locks  you in a loop.  Your fleet keeps warping to the same escape point and re-initiates combate over and over.  I can go on but overall i'm  just terribly disappointed....

The real time combat is probably the best feature when it doesn't lock the pc.

The DLC does improve on the base game adding  more techs, some new twists,  and such.  If you're looking for what amounts to a space-shoot-em-up and are not interested in aspects such as diplomacy, strategy, etc, then this is an ok game.

I will give a thumbs up to Zero who is responsive, listens to the community,  and has been fixing bugs, but there as simply too many issues (imo) to overcome.

Here's hoping Master of Orion 4 hits closer to the mark...........

reviewText:
I'm not even sure to recomend it or not,

There is soooooo many bug and even more when you get late game! My ship simply cannot use wormhole because they keep ''overshooting'' the thing! I even sometime see the AI having trouble with the bug.
The auto combat is stupid! Got 5 of my titan coming out with all of their armor destroyed against a few cruiser and corvette when i can easily take out a fleet of 10+ battleship with a single titan. Same thing with ground combat! My mech get almost destroyed and reduced to 5-20 hp when they are maxed at 220! It would be fine if i could heal them outside combat but nooo. They can regenerate 5hp/turn but can't regenerate 50 hp in 10 years. even with a hospital built. Not enough time i guess....
And one funny bug that i found but not able to recreate is when i switch fleet with the AI, i control his ship and he control mine so i just suicide his long-range ship and send one by one his close range ship...

And there are many more bug that i wont list since i dont have all day to do that and this is not the place to put them but still, the game look like it should be in early access not fully release.

The space combat mechanic are annoying and long for no reason if you cant simply click and forget and hope for the best for your ship, you need to set the range of your ship every single time you do a battle you need to set the formation of your ship every single time you need to order your supply ship or support ship to retreat at the start of the battle every single time. Cant you save you setting so you dont have to do this every single time??? And when you try to select your ship to give them order you almost always select another one if they are too close.
The ground combat could use improvement too, if you are colorblind you will have a hard time to see the range of your weapon and then you when you try to select one of your troop you better not have forgotten that you have your rocket launcher selected on the last dude you tried to shoot because boom you just lost 3 of your men because of that

The diplomacy is almost optional, if you have slightly less ship than the AI does (and you will since the AI can produce them faster than you can with all of your planet focusing production) the AI will ask for tribute at best and then war if you dont agree. After the war the AI will be mad at you because you defended yourself and will ask for tribute after the peace ended and if you dont agree he will declare war again. If you can, try to have trade route with him before he get angry so you can at least get some money before the war.
You cant even have an aliance there is no research to do so and the AI would problably just say no anyway

But i still have fun when the AI does not send 137 ship agaisnt me when my supply limit is 30 (not kidding) and when he bomb my planet without any bomb on his ship (i checked every single one of his ship and no bomb on his design!)
I wil play more game where i will rage when near the end because my ship just doesnt do what i tell them to do like attack or intercept the enemy fleet or use the wormhole because they keep ''overshooting''
I like the game but there is so much that can be done to improve the gameplay its great and it have a good potential but dont buy the game unless you realy want to play it, there is many other game where you can have more fun.
There is a lot of bad thing i have to say about the game but its only because i want it to be better!

Don't waste your money on this highly disappointing, poorly balanced game.

To think that a company which relies on it's yes/no votes would be foolish enough to put out a game that seems to be not play tested, the game looks fine, but it's woeful in it's balance.  Just as you're starting to expand you get smashed to pieces by enemy ships just so it can be 'challenging'.  To be challenging suggests that you have a chance and with the AI's supurb understanding of micromanagement and probably gigantic starting lead/cheating, even on the easier levels and even 'after' it was supposedly made easier on the easy levels.

I'm so insensed by how poor this game plays that I've even spent time writing a review [first time ever] to keep others from wasting their money on this unfinished piece of c$%#.

reviewText:
There's a lot to like about this game.
The ship design is in depth and works pretty great. It's great fun to design ships with specific roles since every decision were you put which parts matters.

But there are also a lot of issues and some of them show that this is an indie developer and not someone very adept at game design.
1. The combat is just boring. It has a lot of good things about it. The graphics are pretty, the ships move in cool ways and it's pretty tactical. But it just moves soooo slow. There is no option to speed of the passage of time which kills the pacing in these battles. First you position your troops, then you wait half a minute were they crawl across the map until their actually in firing range and then you wait till the ships slowly widdle down each others help until you're done. It's just too damn slow. I once had to wait two minutes being bored because my big ships turned too slowly and always missed a fast small ship of the enemy. The last one. The ship was way too weak to even get through my ships shields, but i still had to wait two whole minutes until my ships finally hit that little bugger.
2. The ground combat is even worse. It's designed in an Xcom sort of way were you move your units around a grid to attack and finally kill the enemies. But it's just not fun. It takes way too long to finish any mission, because the enemies always have about 10 times your numbers and all you can do is crawl through the level.
Rule number one of game design: If you can't implement a feature properly don't implement it. These ground battles, which you can't auto resolve by the way, only add tedium to the game and are not fun to play.
3. This all would not have been terrible if the strategy part of the game would have been great, but it's not. The game crawls very slowly. Often you are just forced to end turn after turn without doing anything, because the pollution mechanics means your production is pretty much always ♥♥♥♥ and takes forever to finish anything. The research isn't all that interesting and worst of all it locks you out of technologies unless you make a creative race or use the horrible diplomacy to trade for the tech.
4. I heard from quite a few people that the AI cheats massively and stomps you with unkillable armies in the later game, but i didn't even get that far without growing bored.

Don't buy. It's not good.

reviewText: I find this to be a great game, but there are some issues. For one, there's no voice acting. This game could heavily benefit from voice acting in that it's very quiet, other than the amazing soundtrack. Secondly, the video options menu is painfully limited. You have the option to swap between preset video qualities ranging from Fastest" to "Best
date:
but they have no description of what changes what. You have your average AA options, 0-8 evens. You can set V-Sync and Fullscreen. Lastly you can change resolution. That's it, except for the option to turn off GNN, which it provides no explanation of. The only audio options you get are sliders for FX and Music, but no more. Not even a keybind menu.

Unfortunately, you are also left in the dark when it comes to information on ships, at least from what I can see. When lookign at the ships I can construct, I am not given any explanation of what they are or what they can do. The best I can do is guess based on the name.

The positives include great combat. It's easy to learn and very fluid. You can even go so far as to change the engage distance on individual ships, something that I haven't found before. Granted, I've never really played 4x games too often.

Another positive is the interface. The interface is neat and well designed, and allows for quick access to many things, with preset shortcuts to certain menus. I also found the art style for most things to be very beautiful, and even animations for the characters are present.

Overall, I would give this game a 7/10, and I recommend it to any who like the 4x genre.

reviewText:
Having played the first StarDrive, I am a little disappointed with the second so far. I feel like I have less direct control when its comes to research and commerce, and that the AI even on easy is vastly ahead in terms of expansion.  But this is only a little under two hours into the game, so things could change. It's not a bad game in and of itself, but it feels more hands off (except on the damn space bar) than the first.

I have to add that the developer is a one man army, so take the following with a grain of salt. The first game was left with some issues that were never addressed, which is unfortunate because as I mentioned above, StarDrive was more fun to play than its successor. I can only hope the developer will stay with the second game, and make the steam workshop an option. Mods could benefit the game quite a bit.

I can't recommend the game, not yet. Wait until the summer sale, check on its price and its update status, and maybe take a chance then.

reviewText:
4x space empire building game which uses mechanics which are similar to those found in Master of Orion 2. Looks nice, works well under Linux and can be challenging to play.

One of the nicest features is being able to design your own ships based on 5 types of hulls, where each race has their own hull configuration. Meaning that each race has to think about which configuration of weapons, armor and systems is best suited for their ships. Knowing what your opponent is using and how to counter their ship designs is important.

Downside of the current game is that there is basically only one way to win the game, by conquering the other races. However in the coming DLC different victory types will be added, alongside a sectors mechanic and a revamped ground combat mechanic.

reviewText:
So with all of the 4x clones coming out recently (MoO, Stellaris, etc.) it is hard to know what is truly good and what is failing. SD2 is turning out to be very much like the MoO2 from back in the day with one noteable difference, ship design is much more sophisticated. It seems that none of the current 4x games offer much in terms of tactical battles, but at least this one does cut away from the game so you can fight the fight and send out some fodder or advance screen ships while your big guns start hammering.

StarDrive 2 started out a bit shakey with a alot of bugs, but has come a long way. The DLC had added significately to the game but came with its own problems. Most of those seem to be sorted out and for the most part, the game now seems stable.

As for the balance and end game pacing, the game like so many seems to be more about your early choices, some placement and experience. This game seems to be more engaging than Stellaris from my point of view due to my personal taste in designing ships. Stellaris is more of a plug and play style, lacking in creativity. MoO is more along the lines of the old school MoO, ship wieght capacity vs weapon wieght. SD2 copies from ship design of Galactic Empires. If you can put up with the 10 year old graphics, then GE is superior.

Overall, this game has something the other newer games don't, a more intriguing ship design, with Stellaris lacking tactical battles as well. Other than that, all three are very similar. As of right now, I rate SD2 > MoO > Stellaris. Until the others implement more features, this one gets my positive review.

reviewText: I guess the bottom line is that I would've rather had a remake than this version of the game. "\n\nFor the purposes of this review
date: I'm going to ignore the fiasco that happened with the first game. From here on out
recommended: let's continue with the assumption that had the first game been finished as it was intended
hoursPlayed: it would have gone on to become a great game - if you don't already consider it to be one. Why am I bringing this up? Stardrive 2 is a sequel. It is NOT a remake of the first game. And as a sequel
voteText:
I"m going to compare it to the first one just like I would any other sequel.

So first things first:

Stardrive 2 is turn based - not real time. While some people might like this change
helpfulPercent: I for one HATE it. I personally feel that a sequel should try to be somewhat similar to its predecessors and this change is a bit overwhelming for me. I mean we went from RTS to Turn Based
votesHelpful: and while I do genuinely like some turn based games (Civilization comes to mind)
votesTotal: it felt very awkward for this game because I just wasn't expecting it I suppose.\n\nThe planetary menu/information screen has changed quite a bit. All the planets have hexes (instead of tiles) you can build on now and all hexes are unlocked where before Biospheres were important for unlocking all tiles on any given planet. I actually like this change quite a bit. Tiles that were disabled seemed too arbitrary before and this hex system seems much more balanced. Furthermore I LOVE the citizen/workers. You can now quite easily reassign any citizen(s) to a different role (Farmer
votesFunny: Scientist
commentsCount: etc.) and I think overall this change was extremely well done. It is far less tedious trying to get a new planet established than the original Stardrive which had major issues when you got "Bad Starting Territory."\n\nOf course the space battles and ship design have always been the major attraction to the Stardrive series and this game does not fall short in that department. I feel like the ship design has been tweaked slightly from the first game and I also consider this to be an improvement. Since the game is now turn based
column16: you get encounters when engaging in space combat. There is first a deployment stage where you can move your ships around and decide what positions/formation you want them to be in
column17:
followed by the actual battle. You may NOT give attack orders during the initial phase. I find this to be quite frustrating for someone who likes to micromanage the entire fight but overall combat is still done very well.

Now on to a few matters that really drive me nuts!

CP stands for command points. Ships cost command points to maintain every turn and if you go over your CP limit
column18: you now have to pay a heavy BC fee (BC stands for Billions of Credits IIRC). This forces one of two things: you either maintain an ENORMOUS empire
column19: or you are forced to have a small fleet. Small as in compared to the first game. Hell I remember the nerf from the original Stardrive. I never actually looked up the patch notes
column20: I just remember loading up one of my files where a had a huge fleet and looking at my massively negative income. I don't know if credit income was nerfed or ship maintenance fees were increased but I truly loved the massive fleet sizes you could attain in the original Stardrive before that patch. Even after it you could still field a somewhat large fleet. But that's the problem. I played the Original first and I know how much fun it is to watch that many ships having a chaotic space battle. In Stardrive 2 a LARGE battle is something like 20 vs 20. CP is a soft cap due to BC paying for ships but.... your economy probably can't handle even tens of ships past the limit.\n\nThe best way to increase your CP is to build new starbases (or their upgrade/Battlestations) on all your planets. So what this comes down to is not how much money you make
column21: but is much more about how many planets you control. Therein lies another problem.\n\nI feel like the interface isn't very good for managing a large empire. After playing a few games I quickly learned I was having more fun on cluster settings with the minimum number of systems - 20.  Even at 5 systems you typically control somewhere around 10-15 planets. I can't stand just using the galaxy map at that point. Maybe I'm missing something or maybe the layout of the Empire Overview just isn't what I"m looking for. But ultimately in the original game I wanted a HUGE
column22: MASSIVE EMPIRE! ...But in this game I just want to be small civilization :(\n\nLast but not least due to the fact that the number of ships for each race is so small
column23: the initial fight seems to decide the outcome of the entire war. You kill their fleet
column24: you go on to take over all their planets with little difficulty (Neuro Toxic Bombs quite easily wipe out the local ground oppostion). The last thing I want in a 4x game during combat is to have only ONE definitive space battle against any one race. Ships are hard to spam fast enough to recover from a loss that quickly
column25: even with a Gaia world.\n\nOverall I feel the original game was much better
column26: though there were obvious problems completing the game due to what happened. I guess the bottom line is that I would've rather had a remake than this version of the game.\n\nNote that I didn't quite go over EVERYTHING (like leaders) but this review is already long enough and I want anyone who takes the time to read it to make up their own mind."

reviewText:
Maybe I have the game setup wrong, but every single time I try and play the game, I get forced to go into a battle long before I ever am able. Diplomacy works, you make a peace treaty with the aggressive AI, only to get hit with a message next turn that 'your people believe that the enemy is trying to take over your space and should be dealt with.'

If you agree with them, you get 500 gc, and subsequently annihilated because even 1 turn after negotiating peace you still arent freaking ready.

Or, you can tell them to screw off, and well what do you know? There is an uprising that whipes out your fledgling fleet entirely.

So, this game franchise goes from being really cool, to the second iteration which is impossible to play through.

tl;dr Your enemy can build things 10x faster than you, and either you attack them and lose, or your own people will attack you and you still lose the game.

reviewText: Не ожидал и был приятно удивлен увидеть в нераскрученном проекте интересный геймлей и глубину проработки идей. Подинный наследник идей Мастера Ориона, также есть реализация идей других проектов. Бои динамичные с возможностью ручного контроля. Основная фишка - крафт кораблей и их проверка боем. Квесты на глобальной карте дают неожиданные технологии. Наземные бои грешат яркими тонами в отображении сетки ходов, но терпимо. Наземные юниты также настраиваются в экипировке. Космический флот получает опыт и ранги, наземные - нет, но 4 грамотно настроенных юнита побеждают все бои с ИИ. В дополнение есть отдельный боевой режим. Очень интересный проект. Рекомендую, особенно тем, кто играл в Master of Orion 2.

reviewText:
Edit: After the release of the DLC I would recommend the game with the DLC or without.
Most of the bugs are fixed (though some appeared for the DLC vrsion but it was to be expected.
Actually it's not really a DLC but an expansion which adds deep and interesting mechanics to the game and improve it a lot.
Ground combat has been fixed for the most part (as it has been revamped), balance is still not optimum but we're getting there.
Zero is still not the best communicator with detractors but he actually personally helped me and fixed a bug I had (and that some other people had to) in mere minutes.
I can't yet judge the change to the AI but it seems that it is more involved diplomatically which hopefully will give it an edge. Overall I would recommend now.

Pros:

- Great Visuals for a 4X game.
- One of the best ship designs there is in a 4X games.
- Good tactical combats.
- Interesting lore reminiscent of MoO.
- Interesting 4X game with a gameplay similar to MoO.
- Mod friendly. It's very easy to tweak some Xml files to tweak some stuff out.
- DLC is coming and it looks very interesting and improving many areas of the game.

Cons:

- DLC is coming and yet the game doesn't feel like finished.
- Modding community is very small and seem to have deserted the game. There are actually very few functional mods left.
- Ground combat is not very interesting.
- Balance is lacking in tactical fights. It's too easy to have one type of ship designed and stick with that, obliterating the poorly designed AI ships.
- Unbalanced races. Some races have much smaller hulls than others for the same ship categories. They then must rely in more ships to have a chance to win but the more ships you have the harder it will be on your economy.
- AI is poor. It's just plain dumb and only manages to keep you on your toes at higher difficulty levels because it cheats (I think).
- The game feels like rushed. Lots of bugs still exist after almost a year of release.
- The updates are few and far between with amost if any changes to the game and the existing bugs. After almost a year of being released the game saw less than 5 updates (if my memory serves me right).
- The developer. Zero seems to lack communication and as such he appears as lazy and not caring about his community. I couldn't say that it is true as I do not know him but it appears to be.


In conclusion I cannot recommend the game in its state. I hope that the next DLC will fix and improve many things that are wrong with the game. I do believe that the game is interesting to play and has interesting mechanics for any 4X games fan  but shouldn't be considered a complete game. Definetly not worth 30 bucks, would buy for less than 10.

reviewText:
Since Master of Orion II I have experienced a few notable contenders that have tried to recapture the same magic. Sword of The Stars, Endless Space, and now StarDrive 2. StarDrive 2 is the closest direct copy with (semi) modern visuals with the majority of its gameplay lifted strait from MOO2. Corn/Hammers/Beakers with Civ style buildings make up the majority of colony management. This is an exact replica only slightly tweaked by the maintenance cost of buildings forcing actual choices (that the AI is unprepared to make). Design wise this comes off as a fan patch that makes sense in the context of MOO2 but has no life of its own.

The stolen content is the best part of the game.

Anything that was not mathematically or superficially lifted from the original is incredibly unpolished. The entire experience is like a house built with only a photograph as a reference. The AI does not know how to design ships or manage its empire, The new ground combat is a tedious slog of looped animations, and the real time" space battles (though nice looking)  are not decided by player commands just the ships you carefully designed. It is reminiscent of gratuitous space battles except because you designed decent ships you can take on 5x the chaff that the AI is stuck with.

I can not recommend this game to anyone who has never played Master of Orion II and even then not at full price. On the outside it looks and feels exactly like the MOO2 you may fondly remember while running on modern hardware. It scratches the itch in a way that irritates as much as it satisfies. At the time I write this the developer is making severe content and balance changes and this game may become a late blooming gem like Sword of The Stars one was. However
date:
the developer ditched fixing StarDrive to make StarDrive2 and the problems above may just get dropped for StarDrive3.

*Breaking news*
$10 DLC to address gameplay shortfalls of an unfinished early access game. Buy now! Buy later!  Buy until StarDrive1 is finished in StarDrive4"

reviewText:
So far no fun has been had. I can't believe this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ scrapped Stardrive 1 and left us hanging with so much unfinished stuff there to then, sort of, start from scratch and squeeze out this turd. One of the best things about Stardrive 1--it was still a lot of fun despite the lackluster support and polishing--was that you could speed up and down time and that battles were integrated with the solar systems map. So with the speed up button, you sped up everything. No dull moments there.

Somwhat short story: I can't find speed up button in battle mode, and the campaign when starting out has been an endless clicking end turn to wait for your scout to find you more useless system and nothing happening in those turns. Few turns in pirates show up and destroy your ships.

MEH! Go back and finish Stardrive, you ♥♥♥♥ing idiot. Why squeeze out a turd and try to make a diamond out of it when you had a diamond in the rough right in your hands?

reviewText:
What MoO3 should have been.


StarDrive 2 seems to take the best elements of many of the 4x games to come out in the past decade:

Smooth and intuitive interface (Endless Space)
Easy to learn, hard to master economy (MoO 2)
Fantastic real time space battles (Armada 2526)
Deep and choice-intensive tech tree (MoO 2, and better! - love the experimental and special projects branches)
Ship customization! (Space Empires IV/V, and better!)
Good galaxy lore and interesting races (Galactic Civilizations)
And, ground combat! Sure, it's not the best or most polished part of the game, but NO other 4x to my knowledge has anything at all. It's almost always badly abstracted - so this is a step in the right direction.

Out the box, with the TLC it has received from Zero, being careful to have a polished product out of the gate, as a 4X fan I'd give it an 8/10, and with some DLC and more polish, I think this could solidly, finally, dethrone MoO2.

No more nights of waxing nostolgia playing MoO2 to scratch the 4X itch. The replacement is here.  (Galciv 3 is coming along pretty sexy though to!)

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME IF YOU VALUE MONEY
Buy StarDrive 1, it's a far more playable game and is actually enjoyable

I realize I'm going to be bashed in the comments by a bunch of fan boys and that's fine because personally after painfully trying to play this game for as long as I did and that I struggled to attempt to enjoy it I don't mind people insulting me, at least I didn't waste perfectly good drinking money on them.

Let me start off with saying I loved StarDrive, it still remains one of my favorite games I've played. The dev had quite the gem with it and because of StarDrive, I had no hesitation whatsoever to purchase StarDrive 2, especially after the wonderful discovery of ground combat being added, even bought the digital deluxe one just to show support. I also tried so very hard to enjoy this game, I really did.

This game is a sham and a huge letdown, I haven't been this disappointed in a game since Unity came out after Black Flag, and CA tried to pass off Rome 2 as a playable game on launch.

Pros
-Customizable ships (Although was far superior in StarDrive 1 as well)
-Ground combat (Or well, the idea of it anyways.)
-4x space game worth playing (When talking about StarDrive 1)

Cons
-Ground combat (As it's far too easy and seems to be more of an aesthetic feature than anything serious)
-Space Combat (StarDrive 1 was far superior to this drivel of a combat simulator, again this is far too easy. Also to mention that in StarDrive 1 you were able to move your ships into systems and they would automatically battle to the death with aliens, not some little battle screen that takes away the fun of the old combat system)
-Tech Tree (Now I understand the thrill of being able to only choose one tech from a branch at a time and having to plan it out ahead of time but it gets way too old, far too fast. Being able to build onto previous techs is far more realistic than saying Oh hey
date: should we focus on a rover bay or xeno mine?" Then you choose one
hoursPlayed: why should we bother with the other?" Now I didn't get too far in detail in the tech tree and if you are capable of going back to research the ones you didn't pick please leave an insulting comment down below although according to the tutorial you had to pick the other ones up through espionage or diplomacy which is fine if you want to get them that way but let us build on as in the first StarDrive)\n-Turn based (Now the beauty of StarDrive 1 was that it was automatic turns that happened every 4 seconds if I recall correctly (Please leave an insulting comment down below if I'm wrong) having to manually click to the next turn gets irritating because it allows you to ensure everything is done before you want to move on. In my opinion this makes the game far too easy because you never get caught out of sync and have to deal with a random invasion out of the blue
voteText: and holding the space button is just demented
helpfulPercent:
they should have added a feature in the menu that lets you select continuous play or turn based. That feature actually set StarDrive 1 apart from Gal Civ for me and pushed it to my favorite.)
-Customizable Ships (It feels like the ship design has been modified to make it "Easier" but far less creative and worthwhile)
-Feels like a dummed down version of the original StarDrive with some aesthetic looks to make it smell less foul.

I really am disappointed in Zero and sad to say he's been added to the list of terrible devs. If you have any soul or self respect left

reviewText: I went into Stardrive 2 with high hopes that it would improve upon the old game that was basically abandoned and had missing features. What did I get? a game that tried so desperately to be different from the first that the smooth science tree is replaced with a clunky pick 1 thing lose out on the other two options. Ship designing that was nothing like the trailers, it offered limited choices and felt bizarre and all around poorly done. Which was a shame  because I loved ship designing in the first game, it was my favorite aspect. Then we get to freighters and population growth, apparently I can't send my freighters on trade missions, a planet needs to be starving for food to be sent to them automatically, taking even more control away from the player. Next is the turns, in the first Stardrive time passed and ever 5 seconds was a turn, you had the option of speeding up or slowing time, and even stopping it all together to make choices. Now time is paused from the get go and you have to hold down the space bar, wait a matter of seconds, and then it moved to the next turn as things jump ahead. Yet the game advertises as real time, to em this is a blatant lie as it is clearly a next turn button. This is all I could stomach of the game before closing it to play the original, as I don't want to be miserable on my birthday.  In summary, a soul crushing level of underwhelming game play and sheer disappointment, with the only perk being that the game wooks pwettyer than the first.

As the DLC is set to launch today I thought I would update my review.

If you like 4x games and held off on this one I think its polished enough now to be a good buy, especially when it goes on sale. The ship building is fun the music is good. Combat is very fun, at least space combat. The Hero system is good and exploration is fun. Ground combat has been lacking but I read that the DLC is supposed to improve that so I can't wait to try it out.

Does it have mods? The main game forums (linked below) has a mod section and there have been some very good ones listed there and which have been updated to work with the most recent patch. I had been using the Stardrive 2 Expansion Mod for 1.1e and it had made the game even more fun.

http://stardrivegame.com/forum/viewforum.php?f=13&sid=02418df2b7056b20c6b86f5fe7fa1325

I would say that many of the issues that were there at the beginning are gone. I have not experienced crashes or performance issues. Overall I have found the game to be fun.

If you like 4x games and held off on this one I think its polished enough now to be a good buy, especially when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Patch H has really messed this game up. The AI does not respect Core Space. I've started several games and the narrative is always the same. Opteris colonizes beside me, sends a colony ship to Sol system. If I try to block it, its war and it sends wave after wave of fleets 7 and 8 ships strong.  Even if I manage to build a fleet of ten ships it always has more. If I allow it to build the colony then soon after I get a message telling me that I am in its space and need to vacate.  In which case its war and I have fight wave after wave of superior ships.

The AI seems to muster resources quicker that I can ever manage.  In all, these are 15 to 45 minute games with the outcome always the same.  It does not seem to suffer the same penalties for building ships as players do. The only weapon that was somewhat effective, the mass driver, now is useless because of the newly introduced aiming penalty.

One of the missions right off the bat is to colonize three systems for which you get 500 bc. However it seems that colonizing three systems really pisses the AI off and so it makes a bee line to my cololnies to take care of business. Doing this takes away valuable resources that could be used to build fighters.  However not  colonizing only postpones the inevitable.

It is obvious that there is no fog of war for the AI as it always goes for the weakest colonies and when it knows it has the advantage it swoops in and destroys everything.

I like a challenge, but so far have not been able to find a way to stay alive against an enemy that knows all, builds faster and gets all the tech before me. Yes I've traded for tech. Other players have mentionted how the Ai does not attack with updated ship designs.  I have not found this. For me it is always a case of fighting outgunned and in the end completely outnumbered.

I like where the game is going but hope some of the AI related issues get worked out. I feel that backing things off to give players time to figure things out a little more would make the game that much more enjoyable.

reviewText:
A giant step back from StarDrive 1 - the development of which was abandoned before I and many others felt it was actually finished.

My gripes:
The interface has regressed in almost every way - this feels like it was designed for consoles
Ships now have sections, so if you enjoyed setting up your own firing arcs you'll find that the customization available from the first iteration of the game is gone
Ground combat is completely uninteresting and feels like a solution in search of a problem
The tutorial isn't great - it suggested I colonize a planet in my home system where I couldn't produce any food
The 'Battle Arena' scenarios are often an exercise in frustration
No difficulty adjustment for the Battle Arena
Weapons and Armor/Shields aren't very well balanced yet
I'm currently almost 20 hours in, and every time after I quit a session I just feel underwhelmed.

reviewText:
Stardrive 2 is what Master of Orion 3 should have been.

The space combat engine is probably the best ever created, the space battles are spectaculars, and once you know what you are doing with the ship designer, the tactical part is really present. It's a pure jewel. The economy and research system are an improved and modernised copy/paste from Master of Orion 2, so it's very good and also very solid. This part of the game is also quite well balanced for release, that's worth mentionning.

However, as all 4x release, it's not perfect, the game has also some flaws due to its youth. The different ship modules are not as well balanced as the economy, some work is still needed here. The ground combat system is not as bad as it could look, but still, it need some work also (espescially the ground combat IA). The diplomacy lack some obvious options, like the 'Alliance' and 'Declare war to' ones. There is also some small bugs here or there (quite rare, no crash), and some optimisation to do for big battles.

On the overall, despite its youth's flaws, Stardrive 2 is wonderfull. Since release I have put nearly +70hrs in it, and enjoy it like crazy. It reminds me of the MoO2 birth in the old days : the game had lot of bugs (far more than SD2), and still I couldnt stop playing during nearly a month, it was a so good time.. as it is now with SD2 actually!

To end this review, and to be fair with you, readers, I would not say that it is the best space 4x ever created yet, as for me Distant Worlds, which is in real time and quite different on many aspects, has still the title. But trust me, considering all the passion Zero (the lone dev) put in SD2, it's only a matter of time before Stardrive 2 take the title. Six months? One year? I dont know, but for sure, it will happen! ;)

Thank for reading.
Gut/Gorko/Kruos

reviewText:
[This is for the linux version, which has not recieved all updates]

As said by many others my current impressions are as follows:

The idea of the game is great, but there are to many flaws with the execution. Gameplay wise: Suddenly AI Armada comes out of nowhere while you cannot keep up a high fleet because its too expensive. Everyone declares war on you and you loose.

OK maybe im a bad player you say, but whats worse though are the bugs. You have to restart every second fight because when you win an enemy ship will wander out of the battlefield and force you to retreat to finish the battle. (which then somehow counts as lost).

You have to micromanage every little battle. If you just start the battle and retreat you often can save all you ships. The enemy needs more then 25 seconds to get you. But when you autoresolve, you loose all ships. Even when you win by playing by hand you loose with autoresolve.

It gets really tedious. If the game gets patched it could get fun.

As I said though I hope in afew weeks I will be telling all my friends to give it a go.

reviewText:
Well, after one day and nearly 5 hrs on record I feel comfortable giving this game a review. Since others have described their own problems with the game, which generally reflect my own, I want instead to use an analogy.

StarDrive 2 is that really hot girl at the bar that everyone tries to hit on, but give up after about 10 minutes. Sure, she's gorgeous, but she's kind of a c*nt, only drinks martinis, and to be frank, she has no soul.

See that's the thing, StarDrive 1 was the slightly nerdy girl you found in the back of the library that could kick your ♥♥♥ in chess. O.K. maybe her teeth weren't perfectly straight, but she knows who Arthur Schopenhauer is, can have some seriously deep conversations with you over a beer, and speaking of beer; did I mention she crafts her own ale's in the basement of her house? And in bed, she does this thing with her .... anyway I digress.

In short, the kind of person you are will determine whether or not I recommend this game to you. Its superficial and as a result, lacks the depth of its predecessor. Some people like beautiful things, some people prefer the profound.

As for me, give me StarDrive 1.

reviewText:
Stardrive 2 is the sequel to Stardrive 1, by the same developer. To understand why this review is negative, you need to understand Stardrive 1.

This was a game with high hopes and moddability, with support from an up-and-coming indie developer who interacted with the community.
For...awhile. And then support dropped off, and contact became sparse, and despite the game not being in a decently-finished state, it was abandoned, and Stardrive 2 was announced.

Stardrive 2 is a space RTS like its predecessor, like Master of Orion, you outfit ships, you manage planets, you enact ground invasions, you manage your empire, etc. The races are decently-mixed and have varied ship appearances, the story and characters are mostly light-hearted, the art style is appealing...the game play is unfinished, and buggy, despite patches meant to improve it. Some of these bugs are quite game-breaking, immersion-breaking, and some features are incomplete or end up rough around the edges. What is there is much like Stardrive 1: Full of potential, ready to be built upon, ready to be expanded...ready to be finished.

Well, the game is finished. If you buy the $9.99 Sector Zero DLC, which essentially finishes up the content and fixes a fair amount of bugs, and changes some mechanics in the game.

Unfortunately, it's paid DLC. Paid DLC to fix and finish the game. As someone who went the extra mile and bought the deluxe" edition

It is a great game with the potential to get even better.

reviewText:
I recommend the game to any people who enjoy strategy 4x space. That said I share the disapointments among the community.

There are bugs, interface bugs are the ones that I have noticed the most. I feel like the game hasnt had enough testing before release. It is still playable at least for me.

My biggest complaint about he game:
There are tons of different research options and weapons in the game. Most of the time you speed through research before even needing to use the things you have unlocked. I guess what happens is that you move along this research path too fast. By the time you get to fighting you never used those missiles, or that powerplant because now you have way better ones. Almost as if the research to those things served no purpose. It is like you can skip from tier 1 weapons to tier 10 weapons before you actually need to fight anything.

Also the pirates and the aliens that attack you are pretty ridiculous... They dont attack the ai as far as I can tell only you. The ground combat is poorly coded from what I can tell. The longer you are on the ground view the more memory gets leaked or whatever it is that is happening. The defensive base cannon does nothing.

I mean the list goes on and on. Shady development is what it looks like. Cutting corners here and there to rush something out.

Either way it is still a 4X game and it has a lot of cool things about it.
The exploration of new systems is good. The ship module builder is great. The combat is eye candy. Lots of great stuff but the overall balance and feel of the game needs work and the bugs need to be sorted out. If it is just one developer then perhaps the developer would consider spending some of the fortune on some help.

reviewText:
This game is NOT recommended for one reason, and one reason only, but I feel it is a very important one.  The game is the first I have encountered that abandons support for 1024 x 768 and lower resolution.  This may sound trivial, but I believe it may be the start of an ominous trend.  Because of this withdrawal of support gamers using still good gas plasma displays will not be able to play the game.

If the game succeeds in getting away with this move it could be the beginning of the end for all players using gas plasma displays.  Other developers will quickly follow suit, and soon GPD users will find that their computer rigs are useless for any and all new games.   This progression will soon follow to higher and higher resolutions, finally leaving players in a frantic and never ending quest to own systems with the highest possible resolution.  What Microsoft has done to operating systems, games like this will do to monitors.  Each new game out will see a new set of resolutions and monitor types rendered obsolete.

This movement needs to be squashed before it has a chance to take root.  I urge all prospective buyers to refuse to purchase the game until it extends support to all currently used resolutions.

reviewText: I liked the original star drive a lot. The 2nd I was disappointed in, however upon seeing the positive reviews for the new DLC I thought I'd give it another try. Unfortunately I think this game needs more optimisation as I find everything in the game slow and jerky despite having a powerful rig. When it runs better I'll gladly give this game another look.
